events.text_segment:
Very well. In half an hour we shall go on board.”
“But poor Passepartout?” urged Aouda, who was much disturbed by the servant’s disappearance.
“I shall do all I can to find him,” replied Phileas Fogg.
While Fix, in a feverish, nervous state, repaired to the pilot-boat, the others directed their course to the police-station at Hong Kong. Phileas Fogg there gave Passepartout’s description, and left a sum of money to be spent in the search for him. The same formalities having been gone through at the French consulate, and the palanquin having stopped at the hotel for the luggage, which had been sent back there, they returned to the wharf.
It was now three o’clock; and pilot-boat No. 43, with its crew on board, and its provisions stored away, was ready for departure.
The “Tankadere” was a neat little craft of twenty tons, as gracefully built as if she were a racing yacht. Her shining copper sheathing, her galvanised iron-work, her deck, white as ivory, betrayed the pride taken by John Bunsby in making her presentable. Her two masts leaned a trifle backward; she carried brigantine, foresail, storm-jib, and standing-jib, and was well rigged for running before the wind; and she seemed capable of brisk speed, which, indeed, she had already proved by gaining several prizes in pilot-boat races. The crew of the “Tankadere” was composed of John Bunsby, the master, and four hardy mariners, who were familiar with the Chinese seas. John Bunsby, himself, a man of forty-five or thereabouts, vigorous, sunburnt, with a sprightly expression of the eye, and energetic and self-reliant countenance, would have inspired confidence in the most timid.
Phileas Fogg and Aouda went on board, where they found Fix already installed. Below deck was a square cabin, of which the walls bulged out in the form of cots, above a circular divan; in the centre was a table provided with a swinging lamp. The accommodation was confined, but neat.
“I am sorry to have nothing better to offer you,” said Mr. Fogg to Fix, who bowed without responding.
The detective had a feeling akin to humiliation in profiting by the kindness of Mr. Fogg.
“It’s certain,” thought he, “though rascal as he is, he is a polite one!”
The sails and the English flag were hoisted at ten minutes past three. Mr. Fogg and Aouda, who were seated on deck, cast a last glance at the quay, in the hope of espying Passepartout. Fix was not without his fears lest chance should direct the steps of the unfortunate servant, whom he had so badly treated, in this direction; in which case an explanation the reverse of satisfactory to the detective must have ensued. But the Frenchman did not appear, and, without doubt, was still lying under the stupefying influence of the opium.
John Bunsby, master, at length gave the order to start, and the “Tankadere,” taking the wind under her brigantine, foresail, and standing-jib, bounded briskly forward over the waves.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
This statement marks a pivotal moment in Jules Verne's classic novel, "Around the World in Eighty Days." The protagonist, Phileas Fogg, a meticulous and unflappable English gentleman, has embarked on an ambitious journey to circumnavigate the globe in just eighty days. This challenge is set against the backdrop of the 19th century, a time when such a feat was considered nearly impossible due to the limitations of transportation and communication.

Fogg's journey begins as a result of a wager made at the Reform Club in London. He bets half of his fortune, £20,000, that he can complete the journey within the specified time frame. Accompanied by his newly hired French valet, Passepartout, Fogg sets off on this daring adventure, which takes them through various countries and continents, each presenting its own set of challenges and obstacles.

The phrase "In half an hour we shall go on board" signifies a moment of transition and anticipation. It is a reminder of Fogg's unwavering commitment to his schedule and his determination to adhere to the precise timing required to win the bet. This moment also highlights the dynamic between Fogg and Passepartout, as the latter must quickly adapt to the fast-paced and unpredictable nature of their journey.

Throughout the novel, Fogg's character is defined by his calm demeanor and rational approach to problem-solving. He is a man of few words, preferring action over discussion, and his ability to remain composed under pressure is a key factor in the success of their journey. Passepartout, on the other hand, provides a contrast to Fogg's stoicism with his lively and expressive personality. His resourcefulness and loyalty prove invaluable as they navigate the various challenges they encounter.

As they prepare to board the next leg of their journey, the reader is reminded of the broader themes of the novel, including the exploration of time, technology, and the human spirit. Verne's work is a celebration of the advancements of the Industrial Revolution, showcasing the possibilities that arise from the intersection of innovation and human determination.

The journey is not without its complications, as Fogg and Passepartout face numerous setbacks, including delays, misunderstandings, and even a pursuit by Detective Fix, who mistakenly believes Fogg to be a bank robber. Despite these challenges, Fogg's steadfast adherence to his plan and his ability to adapt to unforeseen circumstances ultimately lead to the successful completion of the journey.

"Around the World in Eighty Days" remains a timeless tale of adventure and perseverance, capturing the imagination of readers with its vivid descriptions and engaging narrative. The phrase "In half an hour we shall go on board" encapsulates the spirit of the novel, serving as a reminder of the relentless pursuit of a seemingly impossible goal and the triumph of human ingenuity and resilience.

Very well. In half an hour we shall go on board.”

But poor Passepartout! Where was he at that moment?

He was actually on the quay at a few steps from the "Tankadere," in a sort of drunkenness caused by the stupefying effects of the opium. He was not himself, and he had forgotten everything, even the fact that he was expected to return to the hotel.

At the same time that Mr. Fogg was leaving the police station, Fix was getting into a cab and was going to the wharf. His mind was in a state of extreme agitation. He was afraid that he might be recognized and arrested. He was also afraid that Passepartout might appear and denounce him. He was in a state of feverish anxiety.

Mr. Fogg and Aouda, after having left the police station, went to the French consulate, where they repeated the same proceedings. They then returned to the hotel, where they took their luggage and went to the wharf.

It was then three o'clock. The "Tankadere" was ready to sail. The pilot-boat was a neat little craft of twenty tons, as lightly built as a racing yacht. Her masts leaned a trifle aft. She carried a brigantine foremast, and was rigged like a schooner. Her crew consisted of John Bunsby, the master, and four men.

John Bunsby, himself, was a man of about forty-five, a vigorous, sunburnt fellow, with a sprightly expression and intelligent eyes. He was a man of great experience, and was well acquainted with the navigation of the Chinese seas.

Aouda was anxious, but Mr. Fogg reassured her. He told her that everything would be done to find Passepartout.

At ten minutes past three, the sails were hoisted, and the "Tankadere," under a small head of steam, slipped down the river. Mr. Fogg and Aouda, seated on the deck, cast a last glance at the quay, in the hope of seeing Passepartout.

Fix was on board, and was keeping himself aloof. He was thinking of the future. He was hoping that Passepartout would not appear, for he would have been embarrassed to explain his conduct to him.

Passepartout did not appear. It was probable that he was still under the influence of the opium.

John Bunsby, at the helm, carefully steered the "Tankadere" among the numerous craft which crowded the river. He avoided collisions with skill, and the pilot-boat soon reached the open sea.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXI. IN WHICH THE MASTER OF THE “TANKADERE” RUNS GREAT RISK OF LOSING A REWARD OF TWO HUNDRED POUNDS

events.title: Perilous Voyage Begins and Fix's Contemplation
detailed_summary: The journey from Hong Kong to Shanghai is presented as extremely dangerous due to the small size of the vessel, the 'Tankadere', and the volatile November weather in the Chinese seas, known for gales and equinoctial storms.
Despite the risks, the pilot, John Bunsby, trusts his boat's seaworthiness, even though proceeding to Yokohama would have been more profitable but far too dangerous.
The 'Tankadere' successfully navigates Hong Kong's channels and sails well in favourable winds upon reaching open water.
Phileas Fogg instructs the pilot to maximize speed, expressing confidence in the pilot's expertise.
Fogg stands steadily on deck observing the sea, unaffected by the motion.
Aouda, seated aft, feels overwhelmed looking at the vast, darkening ocean, perceiving the sails like large wings carrying the frail boat.
As night falls and the moon provides limited light, clouds gather, and the pilot activates the boat's lights for safety in the busy shipping lanes.
Fix remains isolated in the bow, reflecting on his situation. He avoids interaction with Fogg due to Fogg's reserved nature and Fix's discomfort at accepting Fogg's generosity.
Fix speculates that Fogg intends to proceed directly to San Francisco from Yokohama, using the vastness of America to escape justice with the stolen bank money.
He reaffirms his commitment to pursuing Fogg until extradition is secured, feeling it's his duty.
Fix finds solace in Passepartout's absence, realizing the importance of preventing any conversation between the servant (to whom he revealed much) and his master.

events.text_segment:
This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales of wind, and especially during the equinoxes; and it was now early November.
It would clearly have been to the master’s advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama, since he was paid a certain sum per day; but he would have been rash to attempt such a voyage, and it was imprudent even to attempt to reach Shanghai. But John Bunsby believed in the “Tankadere,” which rode on the waves like a seagull; and perhaps he was not wrong.
Late in the day they passed through the capricious channels of Hong Kong, and the “Tankadere,” impelled by favourable winds, conducted herself admirably.
“I do not need, pilot,” said Phileas Fogg, when they got into the open sea, “to advise you to use all possible speed.”
“Trust me, your honour. We are carrying all the sail the wind will let us. The poles would add nothing, and are only used when we are going into port.”
“It’s your trade, not mine, pilot, and I confide in you.”
Phileas Fogg, with body erect and legs wide apart, standing like a sailor, gazed without staggering at the swelling waters. The young woman, who was seated aft, was profoundly affected as she looked out upon the ocean, darkening now with the twilight, on which she had ventured in so frail a vessel. Above her head rustled the white sails, which seemed like great white wings. The boat, carried forward by the wind, seemed to be flying in the air.
Night came. The moon was entering her first quarter, and her insufficient light would soon die out in the mist on the horizon. Clouds were rising from the east, and already overcast a part of the heavens.
The pilot had hung out his lights, which was very necessary in these seas crowded with vessels bound landward; for collisions are not uncommon occurrences, and, at the speed she was going, the least shock would shatter the gallant little craft.
Fix, seated in the bow, gave himself up to meditation. He kept apart from his fellow-travellers, knowing Mr. Fogg’s taciturn tastes; besides, he did not quite like to talk to the man whose favours he had accepted. He was thinking, too, of the future. It seemed certain that Fogg would not stop at Yokohama, but would at once take the boat for San Francisco; and the vast extent of America would ensure him impunity and safety. Fogg’s plan appeared to him the simplest in the world. Instead of sailing directly from England to the United States, like a common villain, he had traversed three quarters of the globe, so as to gain the American continent more surely; and there, after throwing the police off his track, he would quietly enjoy himself with the fortune stolen from the bank. But, once in the United States, what should he, Fix, do? Should he abandon this man? No, a hundred times no! Until he had secured his extradition, he would not lose sight of him for an hour. It was his duty, and he would fulfil it to the end. At all events, there was one thing to be thankful for; Passepartout was not with his master; and it was above all important, after the confidences Fix had imparted to him, that the servant should never have speech with his master.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The sea was rough, the winds were capricious, and the weather was unpredictable. Yet, the crew was determined, and their spirits were high, driven by the promise of adventure and the challenge of the unknown.

The vessel, though small, was sturdy and well-equipped for the journey. It had been meticulously prepared for the voyage, with every detail attended to by the captain, who was a seasoned sailor with years of experience navigating treacherous waters. The crew, though not large, was composed of skilled and dedicated men who had faced many a storm and knew the sea's caprices well.

As they set sail, the sky was overcast, and a brisk wind filled the sails, propelling the craft forward with a steady speed. The captain stood at the helm, his eyes scanning the horizon, ever watchful for signs of changing weather or hidden dangers beneath the waves.

The first few days passed without incident, the sea remaining relatively calm, and the wind holding steady. The crew settled into the rhythm of the voyage, each man performing his duties with precision and care. They were well aware of the risks involved, but their confidence in the captain and the vessel kept their fears at bay.

However, as they ventured further from the safety of the coast, the weather began to change. Dark clouds gathered on the horizon, and the wind picked up, whipping the sea into a frenzy of white-capped waves. The vessel pitched and rolled, the deck slick with spray as the crew worked tirelessly to keep her on course.

The storm hit with a fury, the wind howling through the rigging, and the sea crashing over the bow. The captain barked orders, his voice barely audible over the roar of the elements, as the crew fought to keep the vessel from being overwhelmed. It was a test of their skill and endurance, each man pushing himself to the limit as they battled the storm.

For hours they struggled, the storm showing no sign of abating. The vessel was tossed about like a toy, the men clinging to the rigging as the waves threatened to sweep them overboard. But they held on, their determination unyielding, driven by the knowledge that their survival depended on their ability to work together and trust in their captain's leadership.

Finally, after what seemed an eternity, the storm began to abate. The wind lessened, the sea calmed, and the clouds parted to reveal a sky filled with stars. Exhausted but relieved, the crew took stock of the situation, grateful to have weathered the storm without serious damage to the vessel or loss of life.

As dawn broke, the sea was calm once more, the sun rising to cast a golden glow over the water. The crew, though weary, was in good spirits, their confidence renewed by their successful navigation through the storm. They knew that the journey was far from over, but they were ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead, united in their resolve to complete the voyage and return safely home.

The captain, standing at the helm, allowed himself a moment of satisfaction. They had faced the sea's wrath and emerged victorious, a testament to their skill and courage. With a steady hand, he guided the vessel onward, the promise of adventure still calling them forward into the unknown.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales of wind, and especially during the equinoxes; and it was now early November. It would clearly have been to the pilot’s advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama, since he was paid a certain sum per day; but he would have been rash to attempt such a voyage, and it was imprudent even to attempt to reach Shanghai. But John Bunsby believed in the Tankadere, which rode on the waves like a seagull; and perhaps he was not wrong. Late in the day they passed through the capricious channels of Hong Kong, and the Tankadere, impelled by favourable winds, conducted herself admirably. 

“I do not need to urge you,” said Phileas Fogg to the pilot. “I am not afraid.” 

“Mr. Fogg,” replied the pilot, “you are a brave man.” 

The passengers were seated on the deck. Aouda, who was intensely interested in the dangerous navigation, lay aft, and was absorbed in the magnificent spectacle. The dark waves foamed and dashed against the vessel’s sides, and the wind whistled through the rigging; the sails rose and fell like the breast of a gigantic bird. 

The moon was in her first quarter, and her insufficient light rendered the sea misty and vague. The shadows were deepened by the foggy atmosphere, and the horizon was indistinct. But at a distance, in the midst of the waters, a great black mass was seen, a coal-black shadow, which seemed to be moving towards the Tankadere. It was a steamer, which was rapidly approaching. 

The pilot put the helm hard-a-port, and the Tankadere veered sharply to starboard, and the steamer passed by, to the great relief of the pilot and his passengers. 

Fix, seated in the bow, did not speak a word. He was thinking of the bank robbery, and was as much absorbed as Aouda in the spectacle of the ocean. 

At midnight the weather changed; the sea ran high, the wind blew a gale, and the rain fell in torrents. It was a squall. The little craft was lifted like a feather by the wind, an idea of the danger of which can scarcely be given. 

Aouda was seized with terror, and clasped her protector’s arm; but the pilot, at once taking his precautions, had all the sails furled, and the vessel was brought to the wind. 

During the squall the night was very dark. It was impossible to see the Tankadere even at a short distance. The steamer had disappeared, and the pilot, with his eyes fixed on the compass, kept the vessel to the wind. 

The storm lasted till morning, and the Tankadere was in a pitiful condition. The sails were torn, the rigging damaged, and the hull leaked. But the damage was repaired as well as possible, and the vessel was again put on the course to Shanghai. 

The passengers had gone below; but they were still uneasy, and the pilot kept on deck all night. At daybreak the weather was clear, and the wind was blowing from the south-east. The Tankadere was again under full sail, and was making rapid progress. 

The day passed without accident. The pilot, who was familiar with the navigation of these seas, avoided the numerous vessels which passed on the way to Shanghai. 

Towards evening the Tankadere was within thirty miles of Shanghai. The night was dark, and the wind was blowing a gale. The pilot, who was on the lookout, saw a light in the distance, and steered towards it. 

The light was that of a steamer, which was coming from Shanghai. The pilot hailed the steamer, and asked for a passage for his passengers. The captain of the steamer consented, and the passengers were transferred to the steamer, which was bound for Yokohama. 

The Tankadere was left to continue her voyage to Shanghai, and the passengers were soon on their way to Yokohama. 

Phileas Fogg had won his wager, and had saved Aouda. 

Fix, who had followed him to the end, was obliged to acknowledge that he had been wrong, and that Phileas Fogg was an honest man. 

The steamer reached Yokohama on the 14th of November, and Phileas Fogg was in time to take the steamer for San Francisco.

events.title: Concerns for Passepartout and Night Sailing
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg contemplates Passepartout's sudden disappearance, considering it possible that his servant mistakenly boarded the 'Carnatic' at the last minute.
Aouda shares this view, expressing sadness over the loss of Passepartout, to whom she feels indebted.
They entertain the hope of finding Passepartout in Yokohama by checking the 'Carnatic's' passenger list.
Around ten o'clock, a strong breeze develops, but the pilot decides against reducing sail after assessing the sky, confident in the 'Tankadere's' stability.
At midnight, Fogg and Aouda retire to the cabin, where Fix is already resting, leaving the pilot and crew on deck overnight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The pilot and crew remained on deck all night.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared. Looking at the matter from every point of view, it did not seem to him impossible that, by some mistake, the man might have embarked on the “Carnatic” at the last moment; and this was also Aouda’s opinion, who regretted very much the loss of the worthy fellow to whom she owed so much. They might then find him at Yokohama; for, if the “Carnatic” was carrying him thither, it would be easy to ascertain if he had been on board.
A brisk breeze arose about ten o’clock; but, though it might have been prudent to take in a reef, the pilot, after carefully examining the heavens, let the craft remain rigged as before. The “Tankadere” bore sail admirably, as she drew a great deal of water, and everything was prepared for high speed in case of a gale.
Mr. Fogg and Aouda descended into the cabin at midnight, having been already preceded by Fix, who had lain down on one of the cots. The pilot and crew remained on deck all night.

Passepartout had been a reliable companion throughout their travels, and his disappearance left Fogg feeling uneasy. He wondered if Passepartout had encountered trouble or if something more sinister was at play.

Fogg's mind raced with possibilities. Could Passepartout have been detained by the authorities, or had he fallen victim to some unforeseen danger? The thought of losing his trusted valet weighed heavily on him, as Passepartout had become more than just a servant; he was a friend.

Despite his worry, Fogg knew he had to remain focused on the task at hand. The wager to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days was still at stake, and time was of the essence. He resolved to continue with the journey, hoping that Passepartout would find a way to rejoin him.

As the train sped towards their next destination, Fogg kept a vigilant eye on the passing scenery, his thoughts never straying far from his missing companion.

events.title: Good Progress and Fix's Awkward Offer
detailed_summary: By sunrise on November 8th, the boat has covered over a hundred miles, averaging eight to nine miles per hour.
The 'Tankadere' continues at maximum speed under full sail, indicating favourable prospects if the wind persists.
The boat stays close to the coast to benefit from favourable currents, keeping the irregular shoreline within about five miles.
The sea remains relatively calm due to the offshore wind, advantageous for the small vessel.
The wind briefly weakens around noon, prompting the pilot to raise poles, but they are soon lowered as the wind strengthens again.
Fogg and Aouda handle the sea well and eat heartily.
Fix is invited to join their meal but accepts with resentment, disliking being dependent on Fogg.
After eating, Fix privately approaches Fogg, expressing discomfort and offering to pay his share for the passage.
Fogg firmly refuses, stating the cost is part of his overall travel expenses, leaving no room for argument.
Feeling rebuffed and stifled, Fix retreats to the bow and remains silent for the rest of the day.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fix, as he bowed, had a stifled feeling, and, going forward, where he ensconced himself, did not open his mouth for the rest of the day.

events.text_segment:
At sunrise the next day, which was 8th November, the boat had made more than one hundred miles. The log indicated a mean speed of between eight and nine miles. The “Tankadere” still carried all sail, and was accomplishing her greatest capacity of speed. If the wind held as it was, the chances would be in her favour. During the day she kept along the coast, where the currents were favourable; the coast, irregular in profile, and visible sometimes across the clearings, was at most five miles distant. The sea was less boisterous, since the wind came off land—a fortunate circumstance for the boat, which would suffer, owing to its small tonnage, by a heavy surge on the sea.
The breeze subsided a little towards noon, and set in from the south-west. The pilot put up his poles, but took them down again within two hours, as the wind freshened up anew.
Mr. Fogg and Aouda, happily unaffected by the roughness of the sea, ate with a good appetite, Fix being invited to share their repast, which he accepted with secret chagrin. To travel at this man’s expense and live upon his provisions was not palatable to him. Still, he was obliged to eat, and so he ate.
When the meal was over, he took Mr. Fogg apart, and said, “sir”—this “sir” scorched his lips, and he had to control himself to avoid collaring this “gentleman”—“sir, you have been very kind to give me a passage on this boat. But, though my means will not admit of my expending them as freely as you, I must ask to pay my share—”
“Let us not speak of that, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“But, if I insist—”
“No, sir,” repeated Mr. Fogg, in a tone which did not admit of a reply. “This enters into my general expenses.”
Fix, as he bowed, had a stifled feeling, and, going forward, where he ensconced himself, did not open his mouth for the rest of the day.

The "Tankadere," impelled by the wind, seemed to be flying over the waves. The wind was in the pilot's favour, and blew steadily from the south-west. The little craft, which was so light, seemed to be as nimble as a bird, and the passengers could not help feeling confident of success. John Bunsby was a careful man, and he knew how to handle his boat. He kept as near the coast as possible, and the "Tankadere" was never more than five miles from the shore. The sea was not very rough, and the wind was favourable, so that the little vessel was able to make good progress. The wind, however, began to weaken about noon, and an hour later it fell to a calm. The sails drooped, and the boat was motionless on the water. The pilot raised the poles, but they were of little use, for the wind soon sprang up again, and the sails were once more filled. Phileas Fogg and Aouda were not seasick, and they ate heartily of the provisions which had been brought on board. Fix, however, was not so fortunate. He was not accustomed to the sea, and he felt very uncomfortable. He was invited to share the meal, but he accepted with a bad grace, for he did not like to be under any obligation to Fogg. After the meal, Fix approached Fogg, and said, "Sir, I have a request to make of you." "What is it?" replied Fogg. "I wish to pay my share of the passage," said Fix. "I have no objection," said Fogg, "but I cannot accept your money. The cost of the passage is included in my expenses, and I cannot allow you to pay anything." Fix was not satisfied with this answer, but he could not insist, and he retired to the bow of the boat, where he remained silent for the rest of the day.

events.title: Rapid Progress Meets Rising Storm
detailed_summary: The 'Tankadere' makes excellent progress, fueling John Bunsby's optimism about reaching Shanghai on time, which Fogg calmly acknowledges.
The crew works diligently, motivated by the promised reward, ensuring every sail is perfectly set and the steering is precise.
By evening, they have traveled 220 miles from Hong Kong, bolstering Fogg's hope of reaching Yokohama without further delays impacting his schedule.
During the night, the boat enters the rough Straits of Fo-Kien, encountering challenging eddies and choppy waves that make standing difficult.
At daybreak, the wind intensifies, and the sky signals an impending gale, confirmed by erratic barometer readings and large swells from the south-east.
The previous sunset had been ominous, occurring amidst a red mist and phosphorescent ocean.
John Bunsby observes the worsening weather with concern and informs Fogg that a squall is approaching.
Fogg calmly inquires about the wind direction.
Bunsby confirms it's a southern wind, warning of an oncoming typhoon.
Fogg pragmatically notes that a southerly typhoon will actually help push them forward.
Bunsby, taken aback by Fogg's perspective, accepts his view, though his own meteorological knowledge indicates a violent winter typhoon is likely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At a less advanced season of the year the typhoon, according to a famous meteorologist, would have passed away like a luminous cascade of electric flame; but in the winter equinox it was to be feared that it would burst upon them with great violence.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He several times assured Mr. Fogg that they would reach Shanghai in time; to which that gentleman responded that he counted upon it. The crew set to work in good earnest, inspired by the reward to be gained. There was not a sheet which was not tightened, not a sail which was not vigorously hoisted; not a lurch could be charged to the man at the helm. They worked as desperately as if they were contesting in a Royal yacht regatta.
By evening, the log showed that two hundred and twenty miles had been accomplished from Hong Kong, and Mr. Fogg might hope that he would be able to reach Yokohama without recording any delay in his journal; in which case, the many misadventures which had overtaken him since he left London would not seriously affect his journey.
The “Tankadere” entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the island of Formosa from the Chinese coast, in the small hours of the night, and crossed the Tropic of Cancer. The sea was very rough in the straits, full of eddies formed by the counter-currents, and the chopping waves broke her course, whilst it became very difficult to stand on deck.
At daybreak the wind began to blow hard again, and the heavens seemed to predict a gale. The barometer announced a speedy change, the mercury rising and falling capriciously; the sea also, in the south-east, raised long surges which indicated a tempest. The sun had set the evening before in a red mist, in the midst of the phosphorescent scintillations of the ocean.
John Bunsby long examined the threatening aspect of the heavens, muttering indistinctly between his teeth. At last he said in a low voice to Mr. Fogg, “Shall I speak out to your honour?”
“Of course.”
“Well, we are going to have a squall.”
“Is the wind north or south?” asked Mr. Fogg quietly.
“South. Look! a typhoon is coming up.”
“Glad it’s a typhoon from the south, for it will carry us forward.”
“Oh, if you take it that way,” said John Bunsby, “I’ve nothing more to say.” John Bunsby’s suspicions were confirmed. At a less advanced season of the year the typhoon, according to a famous meteorologist, would have passed away like a luminous cascade of electric flame; but in the winter equinox it was to be feared that it would burst upon them with great violence.

Phileas Fogg, ever the picture of calm and composure, stood on deck, his gaze fixed ahead. He was a man of few words, but his presence was commanding. Beside him, Passepartout, his loyal servant, was bustling about, ensuring everything was in order. Passepartout was a man of action, always ready to assist his master in any way possible.

The journey had been a whirlwind of events, each more thrilling than the last. From the bustling streets of London to the exotic locales of India and Hong Kong, Fogg and his companions had faced numerous challenges. Yet, Fogg's unyielding determination and meticulous planning had seen them through each obstacle.

As the Tankadere sailed on, the crew worked diligently, adjusting sails and maintaining the course. The air was filled with the salty tang of the sea, and the rhythmic sound of the waves provided a soothing backdrop to their voyage. The sun was beginning to set, casting a golden glow over the water, and the sky was painted with hues of orange and pink.

Bunsby, ever vigilant, kept a close watch on the weather. He knew that the sea could be unpredictable, and a sudden change in conditions could spell disaster. But for now, everything was in their favor, and he allowed himself a moment of optimism.

Passepartout, ever curious, took the opportunity to learn more about the workings of the schooner. He asked questions of the crew, eager to understand the intricacies of sailing. His enthusiasm was infectious, and the sailors were more than happy to share their knowledge with him.

As night fell, the stars emerged, twinkling in the clear sky. The Tankadere continued its journey, a small vessel in the vast expanse of the ocean, yet driven by the determination of its passengers and crew. Fogg, with his unwavering resolve, knew that every moment counted. The race against time was relentless, but he was undeterred.

The journey was far from over, and challenges still lay ahead. But with the wind in their sails and hope in their hearts, they pressed on, ever closer to their goal. The world was vast, but Fogg's ambition was greater, and he was determined to see his journey through to the end.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He was not without good reason, for the tankadere was a swift vessel, and had the wind been favorable, she would have made the trip in less than the time required by the steamer. The crew, too, were of good stock, and all were working with a will, for they knew that the reward of two hundred pounds was promised to the one who should first sight the Carnatic. Thus, every sail was set, and the steering was as precise as possible. By evening, they had traveled two hundred and twenty miles from Hong Kong, and Phileas Fogg might hope that he would be able to reach Yokohama without further delay. If the wind held, the chances were in his favor. During the night, however, the weather changed. The wind, veering to the south-east, blew in fitful gusts, and the sea rose. It was a squally weather, and the long waves broke heavily. The little vessel pitched violently, and the passengers could scarcely keep their places. But the tempest did not yet reach its height. It was a premonition of a gale. The barometer, as if in sympathy with the elements, seemed to go mad. It fell from ten to nine and a half inches. At daybreak, the wind began to blow hard, and the sky was overcast. The sun rose in a mist, red as blood, and the sea was strewn with foam. The wind was from the south-east, and it was evident that a typhoon was coming up. John Bunsby, the pilot, said so, and he was not mistaken. At noon, the barometer indicated a state of the atmosphere which was beyond the limits of the scale. In the meantime, the wind had increased, and the waves rose to a frightful height. The tankadere, although it was a good sea-boat, was not large enough to brave such a storm. The crew were seized with a panic, and the pilot was obliged to take the helm himself. The storm, however, did not last long, and the wind veered again to the south-west. The tankadere, now running before the wind, kept up her speed, and John Bunsby was able to keep her on her course. But he was still in great fear of losing the reward of two hundred pounds, for the Carnatic might reach Yokohama before them. Phileas Fogg, however, was not disheartened, and he continued to hope that he would be able to reach his destination in time.

events.title: Battling the Typhoon's Fury
detailed_summary: The pilot takes immediate storm precautions: reefing sails, removing poles, and positioning the crew at the bows.
A small, strong triangular storm-jib is hoisted to maintain some control.
Bunsby advises passengers to go below, but Fogg, Fix, and Aouda refuse, disliking the confinement and preferring to stay on deck despite the danger.
Around 8 o'clock, the storm hits with intense rain and wind, tossing the 'Tankadere' like a feather at incredible speed.
The boat is driven northward all day by monstrous waves, managing to keep pace with them.
It narrowly avoids being swamped multiple times due to the pilot's skillful maneuvering.
The passengers are frequently soaked by spray but endure it; Fix is inwardly frustrated, Aouda observes Fogg's calmness with admiration, and Fogg remains unfazed, treating the typhoon as expected.
Towards evening, the wind shifts to the north-west, causing the boat to roll violently in the wave troughs.
As darkness falls, the storm intensifies further, filling Bunsby with dread.
After consulting his crew, Bunsby suggests to Fogg that they should seek shelter in a coastal port.
Fogg agrees with the idea of heading to a port.
When Bunsby asks which port, Fogg calmly and resolutely insists on continuing towards their original destination: Shanghai.
The pilot is initially stunned by Fogg's determination but ultimately agrees, directing the 'Tankadere' back onto its northward course despite the severe conditions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The pilot took his precautions in advance.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So the “Tankadere” kept steadily on her northward track.

events.text_segment:
The pilot took his precautions in advance. He reefed all sail, the pole-masts were dispensed with; all hands went forward to the bows. A single triangular sail, of strong canvas, was hoisted as a storm-jib, so as to hold the wind from behind. Then they waited.
John Bunsby had requested his passengers to go below; but this imprisonment in so narrow a space, with little air, and the boat bouncing in the gale, was far from pleasant. Neither Mr. Fogg, Fix, nor Aouda consented to leave the deck.
The storm of rain and wind descended upon them towards eight o’clock. With but its bit of sail, the “Tankadere” was lifted like a feather by a wind, an idea of whose violence can scarcely be given. To compare her speed to four times that of a locomotive going on full steam would be below the truth.
The boat scudded thus northward during the whole day, borne on by monstrous waves, preserving always, fortunately, a speed equal to theirs. Twenty times she seemed almost to be submerged by these mountains of water which rose behind her; but the adroit management of the pilot saved her. The passengers were often bathed in spray, but they submitted to it philosophically. Fix cursed it, no doubt; but Aouda, with her eyes fastened upon her protector, whose coolness amazed her, showed herself worthy of him, and bravely weathered the storm. As for Phileas Fogg, it seemed just as if the typhoon were a part of his programme.
Up to this time the “Tankadere” had always held her course to the north; but towards evening the wind, veering three quarters, bore down from the north-west. The boat, now lying in the trough of the waves, shook and rolled terribly; the sea struck her with fearful violence. At night the tempest increased in violence. John Bunsby saw the approach of darkness and the rising of the storm with dark misgivings. He thought awhile, and then asked his crew if it was not time to slacken speed. After a consultation he approached Mr. Fogg, and said, “I think, your honour, that we should do well to make for one of the ports on the coast.”
“I think so too.”
“Ah!” said the pilot. “But which one?”
“I know of but one,” returned Mr. Fogg tranquilly.
“And that is—”
“Shanghai.”
The pilot, at first, did not seem to comprehend; he could scarcely realise so much determination and tenacity. Then he cried, “Well—yes! Your honour is right. To Shanghai!”
So the “Tankadere” kept steadily on her northward track.

He understood that in their quest to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days, every precaution was necessary to maintain their tight schedule.

His experience and expertise were evident in the calm and confident manner in which he handled the airship.

Phileas Fogg, ever the gentleman, thanked the pilot for his professionalism and dedication. He knew that their successful journey was due in no small part to the pilot's careful planning and execution. With another leg of their journey complete, Fogg and his companions prepared to continue their adventure, confident that they would reach their final destination on time.

The pilot, satisfied with a job well done, began preparing the airship for its next flight. He knew that each successful journey was a testament to his skills and the trust placed in him by his passengers. As he watched Fogg and his companions depart, he felt a sense of pride in having contributed to their remarkable journey around the world.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The pilot took his precautions in advance. He reefed all sail, the pole-masts were dispensed with; all hands went forward to the bows. A small, strong, triangular sail, of the storm-jib order, was hoisted, as a storm-jib would have been, to hold the vessel as much as possible head to wind. The passengers were advised to go below; but this imprisonment in so narrow a space, with little air, and the boat bouncing in the gale, was far from pleasant. Neither Mr. Fogg, Fix, nor Aouda consented to leave the deck.

The storm of wind and rain descended upon them towards eight o'clock. With but its bit of sail, the "Tankadere" was lifted like a feather by a wind, an idea of whose violence can scarcely be given. To compare her speed to four times that of a locomotive going on full steam would be below the truth.

The boat scudded thus northward during the whole day, borne on by monstrous waves, preserving always, fortunately, a speed equal to theirs. The waves came from the windward, and every time the "Tankadere" rose on their crest she was carried forward as by a hurricane. The crew kept to the post of duty, the pilot at the helm, and the sailors at the fore. But they could not prevent the vessel from pitching frightfully. The waves tore her open, and she was often on the point of being engulfed. The lady, who was naturally nervous, was nearly overcome by the violence of the storm. Fix tightly clenched his teeth, and Fogg, who was holding Aouda's hand, encouraged her to keep up her courage.

The storm, however, did not abate its fury; it was a typhoon. The wind veered again to the north-west. This was a last effort, before it blew in from the south-west. The "Tankadere," now carried forward by the wind, was at last able to resume her course, and John Bunsby, feeling himself at last free, gave a long sigh of relief.

But the storm had been so frightful that the pilot was not yet able to trust himself. He consulted his crew, and, after a few moments' deliberation, Mr. Fogg, who had been listening to him, said, "I think we had better make for one of the ports on the coast."

"I think so too," replied Bunsby. "But which one?"

"I know of but one," returned Mr. Fogg tranquilly.

"And that is—"

"Shanghai."

events.title: Surviving the Night and Storm Abates
detailed_summary: The night is horrific, and the boat survives only through the crew's constant vigilance and near-miraculous escapes from foundering.
Aouda is exhausted but remains stoic, receiving protection from Fogg against the waves multiple times.
Daylight reveals the tempest continuing unabated, but the wind shifts back to the south-east, which is advantageous.
The 'Tankadere' resumes its rapid progress, though battered by crossing waves.
They spot the coast occasionally through mist but see no other ships.
Around noon, the storm begins to show signs of calming, which become more apparent as the sun sets.
The intense but brief storm passes, allowing the exhausted passengers to eat and rest.
The night becomes relatively calm, allowing more sails to be hoisted, increasing the boat's speed.
By the next morning's dawn, they sight the coast, and Bunsby estimates they are less than 100 miles from Shanghai.
They have only one day left to cover the remaining distance to catch the Yokohama steamer that evening.
The time lost during the storm means they are further behind schedule than they would have been.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Had there been no storm, during which several hours were lost, they would be at this moment within thirty miles of their destination.

events.text_segment:
The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder. Twice it could have been all over with her if the crew had not been constantly on the watch. Aouda was exhausted, but did not utter a complaint. More than once Mr. Fogg rushed to protect her from the violence of the waves.
Day reappeared. The tempest still raged with undiminished fury; but the wind now returned to the south-east. It was a favourable change, and the “Tankadere” again bounded forward on this mountainous sea, though the waves crossed each other, and imparted shocks and counter-shocks which would have crushed a craft less solidly built. From time to time the coast was visible through the broken mist, but no vessel was in sight. The “Tankadere” was alone upon the sea.
There were some signs of a calm at noon, and these became more distinct as the sun descended toward the horizon. The tempest had been as brief as terrific. The passengers, thoroughly exhausted, could now eat a little, and take some repose.
The night was comparatively quiet. Some of the sails were again hoisted, and the speed of the boat was very good. The next morning at dawn they espied the coast, and John Bunsby was able to assert that they were not one hundred miles from Shanghai. A hundred miles, and only one day to traverse them! That very evening Mr. Fogg was due at Shanghai, if he did not wish to miss the steamer to Yokohama. Had there been no storm, during which several hours were lost, they would be at this moment within thirty miles of their destination.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg, calm and composed as ever, stood on the deck, his eyes fixed on the horizon, as if willing the storm to abate. The wind howled with a ferocity that seemed to challenge the very existence of the vessel, and the waves rose like mountains, crashing down with a force that shook the ship to its core.

Passepartout, though usually full of energy and optimism, found himself clinging to the railings, his knuckles white with the effort. He glanced at his master, drawing some comfort from Fogg's unyielding demeanor, but the fear in his heart was not so easily quelled.

The crew worked tirelessly, their movements a dance of survival against the elements. Orders were shouted, ropes were pulled, and sails were adjusted in a desperate attempt to keep the ship afloat. The captain, a seasoned sailor, barked commands with a voice that cut through the storm, his experience guiding them through the chaos.

Below deck, Aouda sat in her cabin, her hands clasped tightly together in silent prayer. She had placed her trust in Phileas Fogg, and though the situation seemed dire, she held onto the hope that they would reach their destination safely.

As the night wore on, the storm showed no signs of relenting. The ship creaked and groaned under the strain, but it held firm, a testament to the skill of its builders and the determination of its crew.

Finally, as dawn broke, the storm began to subside, the winds lessening and the waves calming. Exhausted but relieved, the passengers and crew emerged to survey the damage, grateful to have survived the night. Phileas Fogg, ever the stoic, simply nodded in acknowledgment of their survival, already planning their next move in the race against time.
