events.title: Reaching Yokohama and Locating Passepartout
detailed_summary: The group arrived in Yokohama on November 14th.
Phileas Fogg promptly went aboard the 'Carnatic'.
He learned that Passepartout, identified as a Frenchman, had arrived the previous day, much to Aouda's relief and possibly Fogg's, though he showed no emotion.
The steamer to San Francisco was scheduled to leave the same evening.
Finding Passepartout quickly became urgent.
Fogg unsuccessfully sought help from the French and English consulates.
After a lengthy and fruitless search through the city streets, Fogg began to lose hope.
Either by luck or intuition, he entered the theatre belonging to the Honourable Mr. Batulcar.
Fogg wouldn't have recognized his servant in the strange performer's attire.
However, Passepartout, performing on his back, spotted his master in the audience gallery.
His surprise caused an involuntary movement that dislodged his artificial nose, causing the human pyramid act to collapse.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He could not help starting, which so changed the position of his nose as to bring the “pyramid” pell-mell upon the stage.

events.text_segment:
They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November. Phileas Fogg lost no time in going on board the “Carnatic,” where he learned, to Aouda’s great delight—and perhaps to his own, though he betrayed no emotion—that Passepartout, a Frenchman, had really arrived on her the day before.
The San Francisco steamer was announced to leave that very evening, and it became necessary to find Passepartout, if possible, without delay. Mr. Fogg applied in vain to the French and English consuls, and, after wandering through the streets a long time, began to despair of finding his missing servant. Chance, or perhaps a kind of presentiment, at last led him into the Honourable Mr. Batulcar’s theatre. He certainly would not have recognised Passepartout in the eccentric mountebank’s costume; but the latter, lying on his back, perceived his master in the gallery. He could not help starting, which so changed the position of his nose as to bring the “pyramid” pell-mell upon the stage.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg, accompanied by his loyal servant Passepartout, disembarked from the train with a sense of urgency. The bustling city of New York lay before them, a crucial stop on their whirlwind journey around the globe. Fogg, ever the picture of composure, checked his pocket watch, calculating the time remaining to complete their ambitious circumnavigation.

Passepartout, though weary from the relentless pace, was invigorated by the prospect of nearing the journey's end. He marveled at the towering buildings and the throngs of people, a stark contrast to the quieter locales they had traversed.

Their next task was to secure passage across the Atlantic, a challenge that loomed large given the tight schedule. Fogg, with his characteristic decisiveness, led the way to the shipping offices, determined to find a vessel that would carry them to Liverpool.

As they navigated the crowded streets, the stakes of their wager weighed heavily on Fogg's mind, yet his resolve remained unshaken.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November. Phileas Fogg was one of the first to get aboard the Carnatic, and he inquired whether Passepartout had been there. To his great joy, he learned that Passepartout, a Frenchman, had really arrived on the Carnatic the day before. The Frenchman had indeed been on board, but he had gone ashore at Yokohama, and was now wandering about the streets of the Japanese city. Much to Aouda's relief, and perhaps to Fogg's as well, though he betrayed no emotion, Passepartout was found. The steamer which was to leave for San Francisco at five o'clock in the evening was ready to start. Phileas Fogg had only a few hours in which to find his servant, and he made every effort to do so. He applied in vain to the French and English consuls, and after a long and fruitless search, began to despair. Either chance or a kind of presentiment made him enter the Honourable Mr. Batulcar's theatre. He would not have recognized Passepartout in the eccentric mountebank's costume, but the latter, lying on his back, perceived his master in the gallery. He could not help starting, which so changed the position of his nose as to bring the "pyramid" pell-mell upon the stage.

events.title: Passepartout's Explanation and Reintegration
detailed_summary: Aouda informed Passepartout about their journey from Hong Kong to Shanghai aboard the 'Tankadere', including Fix's presence.
Passepartout showed no outward reaction upon hearing Fix's name.
He decided it wasn't the right moment to reveal his interactions with the detective to Fogg.
When explaining his absence, he attributed it solely to being overcome by opium intoxication at a Hong Kong tavern.
Mr. Fogg listened to the explanation impassively, without comment.
He then gave Passepartout money to buy clothes suitable for his role.
In less than an hour, Passepartout had removed his costume components (nose and wings) and no longer resembled the performer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: All this Passepartout learned from Aouda, who recounted to him what had taken place on the voyage from Hong Kong to Shanghai on the “Tankadere,” in company with one Mr. Fix.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Within an hour the Frenchman had cut off his nose and parted with his wings, and retained nothing about him which recalled the sectary of the god Tingou.

events.text_segment:
All this Passepartout learned from Aouda, who recounted to him what had taken place on the voyage from Hong Kong to Shanghai on the “Tankadere,” in company with one Mr. Fix.
Passepartout did not change countenance on hearing this name. He thought that the time had not yet arrived to divulge to his master what had taken place between the detective and himself; and, in the account he gave of his absence, he simply excused himself for having been overtaken by drunkenness, in smoking opium at a tavern in Hong Kong.
Mr. Fogg heard this narrative coldly, without a word; and then furnished his man with funds necessary to obtain clothing more in harmony with his position. Within an hour the Frenchman had cut off his nose and parted with his wings, and retained nothing about him which recalled the sectary of the god Tingou.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Passepartout listened intently as Aouda described the events that had unfolded. She explained how Mr. Fix, the detective who had been pursuing Phileas Fogg, had joined them on the small vessel. Despite his initial intentions to arrest Fogg, Fix had found himself in a peculiar situation. The stormy seas and the urgency of reaching Shanghai had forced them to work together, setting aside their differences temporarily.

Aouda recounted how the journey had been fraught with challenges, from navigating treacherous waters to dealing with the limited resources on board. Yet, through it all, a sense of camaraderie had developed among the passengers and crew. Passepartout was amazed at the resilience and determination they had shown, and he felt a renewed sense of admiration for both Aouda and his master, Phileas Fogg.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: All this Passepartout learned from Aouda, who recounted to him what had taken place on the voyage from Hong Kong to Shanghai on the "Tankadere," in company with one Mr. Fix. Passepartout did not change countenance on hearing this name. He thought it was not worth while to apprise his master of what had passed between the detective and himself. In the belief that Mr. Fogg would not be delayed by his absence, he had, indeed, left Hong Kong without the least regret. But now what should he do? He had an excuse for not having been present at the Hong Kong rendezvous, which he might make the most of. He had, in his hasty departure, left behind him his passport and his shoes. But it was of no use to worry his master with this story. He had to make up his mind to say nothing about it. When Passepartout had finished his story, Mr. Fogg replied, "I am sorry for you, Passepartout, but it is not your fault. You have been deceived, and you have been the victim of a trick. But I am glad to see you again." Passepartout was touched by this kindness, and resolved to devote himself entirely to his master’s service. He did not even seek to excuse himself to Aouda, who had pardoned him. Mr. Fogg, who had been carefully observing his servant, then said to him: "You have a passport, Passepartout?" "Yes, sir," replied Passepartout. "It is in my trunk, at the hotel." "Very well. Go and get it, and bring it to me." Passepartout obeyed, and returned with the passport. Mr. Fogg examined it attentively, and then handed it back to him, saying: "You have been a faithful servant, Passepartout, and I am satisfied with you. But you must be more careful in the future." Passepartout promised to be more careful, and Mr. Fogg gave him some money, saying: "Here is something for you to buy clothes with, for you must be properly dressed for the journey." Passepartout thanked his master, and went out to make his purchases. In less than an hour he had removed his nose and wings, and no longer resembled a performer.

events.title: Departure on the 'General Grant' for San Francisco
detailed_summary: The vessel for the Yokohama to San Francisco leg was the 'General Grant', operated by the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.
It was described as a large, 2,500-ton paddle-wheel steamer, well-appointed and fast.
Details of its engine mechanism, including the walking-beam, piston-rod, and connecting-rod driving the paddles, were noted.
The ship had three masts and substantial sail capacity to supplement its steam engine.
With a speed of twelve miles per hour, it was expected to complete the Pacific crossing in twenty-one days.
This schedule gave Phileas Fogg confidence in reaching San Francisco by December 2nd, New York by December 11th, and London by December 20th.
This timeline potentially offered a buffer of several hours before his December 21st deadline.

events.text_segment: The steamer which was about to depart from Yokohama to San Francisco belonged to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and was named the “General Grant.” She was a large paddle-wheel steamer of two thousand five hundred tons; well equipped and very fast. The massive walking-beam rose and fell above the deck; at one end a piston-rod worked up and down; and at the other was a connecting-rod which, in changing the rectilinear motion to a circular one, was directly connected with the shaft of the paddles. The “General Grant” was rigged with three masts, giving a large capacity for sails, and thus materially aiding the steam power. By making twelve miles an hour, she would cross the ocean in twenty-one days. Phileas Fogg was therefore justified in hoping that he would reach San Francisco by the 2nd of December, New York by the 11th, and London on the 20th—thus gaining several hours on the fatal date of the 21st of December.

The ship was bustling with activity as passengers boarded, each carrying their own hopes and dreams for the journey ahead. Among them was Phileas Fogg, the unflappable English gentleman, accompanied by his loyal servant, Passepartout.

Fogg, who was in the midst of his audacious attempt to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days, was keenly aware of the importance of this leg of the journey. The "General Grant" was scheduled to make the crossing in twenty-one days, a crucial segment in Fogg's meticulously planned itinerary. As the ship prepared to set sail, Fogg remained calm and composed, confident in his calculations and the reliability of the steamship to deliver him to the next stage of his adventure.

The massive walking-beam rose and fell above the deck; at one end a piston-rod worked up and down; and at the other was a connecting-rod which, in its circular motion, described an arc of a circle. It was driven by a powerful engine, and the high-pressure steam escaped in puffs from the escape-valves. The "General Grant" was rigged with three masts, giving a large capacity for sails, and thus materially aiding the steam power. By making twelve miles an hour, she would cross the ocean in twenty-one days. Phileas Fogg was therefore justified in hoping that he would reach San Francisco by the 2nd of December, New York by the 11th, and London on the 20th—thus gaining several hours on the fatal 21st of December.

events.title: Smooth Pacific Crossing and Developing Relationships
detailed_summary: The 'General Grant' carried a diverse group of passengers, including British, American, Chinese laborers heading to California, and East Indian officers on a world tour.
The voyage across the Pacific was uneventful.
The large paddle steamer remained stable, experiencing little rolling, living up to the ocean's peaceful reputation.
Mr. Fogg maintained his usual calm and reserved demeanor.
Aouda found her feelings for Fogg deepening beyond simple gratitude.
His quiet generosity made a strong impression on her, leading to developing emotions she acted upon almost unconsciously, which seemed unnoticed by him.
Aouda became deeply invested in Fogg's travel plans, growing anxious about any potential delays.
She frequently conversed with Passepartout.
Passepartout recognized Aouda's growing affection for Fogg.
As a loyal servant, he consistently praised Fogg's positive qualities: integrity, generosity, and dedication.
He actively sought to alleviate Aouda's anxieties about the journey's success, assuring her the hardest parts were over.
He expressed confidence that crossing America by train and the Atlantic by steamer would ensure they met the deadline.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a full complement of passengers on board, among them English, many Americans, a large number of coolies on their way to California, and several East Indian officers, who were spending their vacation in making the tour of the world.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A railway train from San Francisco to New York, and a transatlantic steamer from New York to Liverpool, would doubtless bring them to the end of this impossible journey round the world within the period agreed upon.

events.text_segment:
There was a full complement of passengers on board, among them English, many Americans, a large number of coolies on their way to California, and several East Indian officers, who were spending their vacation in making the tour of the world. Nothing of moment happened on the voyage; the steamer, sustained on its large paddles, rolled but little, and the “Pacific” almost justified its name. Mr. Fogg was as calm and taciturn as ever. His young companion felt herself more and more attached to him by other ties than gratitude; his silent but generous nature impressed her more than she thought; and it was almost unconsciously that she yielded to emotions which did not seem to have the least effect upon her protector. Aouda took the keenest interest in his plans, and became impatient at any incident which seemed likely to retard his journey.
She often chatted with Passepartout, who did not fail to perceive the state of the lady’s heart; and, being the most faithful of domestics, he never exhausted his eulogies of Phileas Fogg’s honesty, generosity, and devotion. He took pains to calm Aouda’s doubts of a successful termination of the journey, telling her that the most difficult part of it had passed, that now they were beyond the fantastic countries of Japan and China, and were fairly on their way to civilised places again. A railway train from San Francisco to New York, and a transatlantic steamer from New York to Liverpool, would doubtless bring them to the end of this impossible journey round the world within the period agreed upon.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The weather was fine, and the wind favorable. All on board hoped for a quick and pleasant voyage. The passengers were a diverse group, each with their own stories and reasons for traveling. The English passengers were mostly businessmen, eager to reach their destinations and attend to their affairs. The Americans were a mix of tourists and adventurers, some seeking fortune in the gold fields of California, others simply exploring the world.

The coolies, huddled together on the lower decks, were mostly silent, their thoughts perhaps on the new lives they hoped to build in a distant land. They were a hardy group, accustomed to hard work and harsh conditions, and they faced the journey with stoic determination.

The East Indian officers, in contrast, were jovial and relaxed, enjoying their time off from military duties. They spent their days on deck, chatting and playing games, their laughter often ringing out over the sound of the waves.

As the ship sailed on, the passengers settled into a routine. Meals were taken in the dining saloon, where the clatter of cutlery and the hum of conversation created a lively atmosphere. In the evenings, the passengers gathered on deck to watch the sunset, the sky ablaze with color as the sun dipped below the horizon.

Despite their differences, the passengers shared a common goal: to reach their destination safely and on time. And as the ship cut through the waves, they all hoped for fair winds and smooth seas ahead.

events.title: Mid-Ocean Calculation and Passepartout's Watch 'Triumph'
detailed_summary: Nine days out from Yokohama, Fogg had crossed half the planet's longitude.
On November 23rd, the 'General Grant' crossed the 180th meridian, the point directly opposite London.
Fogg noted that 52 of his allotted 80 days had passed, leaving only 28.
Although halfway by meridian, he had actually completed over two-thirds of the total travel distance (17,500 out of approx. 26,000 miles).

This discrepancy was due to the necessary detours taken earlier in the journey (London-Aden-Bombay-Calcutta-Singapore-Yokohama) compared to a direct route along London's latitude (approx. 12,000 miles).
The path forward was now direct, and Fix was presumed absent, removing a source of obstacles.
On the same day, November 23rd, Passepartout made what he considered a delightful discovery.
He had stubbornly kept his watch set to London time throughout the journey, dismissing local times.
He found that his watch now perfectly matched the ship's chronometers without any adjustment.
He was ecstatic, wishing Fix were present to witness this 'vindication'.
Passepartout mockingly recalled Fix's explanations about time zones, meridians, the sun, and the moon, dismissing them as nonsense.
He triumphantly declared his certainty that the sun would eventually align with his watch.

The narrative clarifies Passepartout's ignorance: if his watch had a 24-hour dial, it would show 9 PM (21:00), matching the time difference from London at the 180th meridian, thus revealing the true situation, not vindicating his London time.
It's noted that even if Fix could explain this, Passepartout likely wouldn't understand or accept it.
Furthermore, had Fix been present, Passepartout's confrontation would have been about different matters entirely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On the ninth day after leaving Yokohama, Phileas Fogg had traversed exactly one half of the terrestrial globe.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Moreover, if the detective had been on board at that moment, Passepartout would have joined issue with him on a quite different subject, and in an entirely different manner.

events.text_segment:
On the ninth day after leaving Yokohama, Phileas Fogg had traversed exactly one half of the terrestrial globe. The “General Grant” passed, on the 23rd of November, the one hundred and eightieth meridian, and was at the very antipodes of London. Mr. Fogg had, it is true, exhausted fifty-two of the eighty days in which he was to complete the tour, and there were only twenty-eight left. But, though he was only half-way by the difference of meridians, he had really gone over two-thirds of the whole journey; for he had been obliged to make long circuits from London to Aden, from Aden to Bombay, from Calcutta to Singapore, and from Singapore to Yokohama. Could he have followed without deviation the fiftieth parallel, which is that of London, the whole distance would only have been about twelve thousand miles; whereas he would be forced, by the irregular methods of locomotion, to traverse twenty-six thousand, of which he had, on the 23rd of November, accomplished seventeen thousand five hundred. And now the course was a straight one, and Fix was no longer there to put obstacles in their way!
It happened also, on the 23rd of November, that Passepartout made a joyful discovery. It will be remembered that the obstinate fellow had insisted on keeping his famous family watch at London time, and on regarding that of the countries he had passed through as quite false and unreliable. Now, on this day, though he had not changed the hands, he found that his watch exactly agreed with the ship’s chronometers. His triumph was hilarious. He would have liked to know what Fix would say if he were aboard!
“The rogue told me a lot of stories,” repeated Passepartout, “about the meridians, the sun, and the moon! Moon, indeed! moonshine more likely! If one listened to that sort of people, a pretty sort of time one would keep! I was sure that the sun would some day regulate itself by my watch!”
Passepartout was ignorant that, if the face of his watch had been divided into twenty-four hours, like the Italian clocks, he would have no reason for exultation; for the hands of his watch would then, instead of as now indicating nine o’clock in the morning, indicate nine o’clock in the evening, that is, the twenty-first hour after midnight precisely the difference between London time and that of the one hundred and eightieth meridian. But if Fix had been able to explain this purely physical effect, Passepartout would not have admitted, even if he had comprehended it. Moreover, if the detective had been on board at that moment, Passepartout would have joined issue with him on a quite different subject, and in an entirely different manner.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The journey had been a remarkable one so far, filled with unexpected challenges and adventures. Phileas Fogg, the unflappable English gentleman, had embarked on this ambitious voyage to circumnavigate the world in just eighty days, a feat that seemed impossible to many. Yet, with his characteristic calm and precision, Fogg had managed to keep to his schedule, overcoming obstacles with the help of his loyal servant, Passepartout.

As they sailed across the Pacific Ocean, Fogg took the opportunity to reflect on the journey thus far. The departure from London had been swift, with Fogg and Passepartout catching the train to Dover and then crossing the English Channel to Calais. From there, they had traveled through France and Italy, reaching Brindisi just in time to catch the steamer to Suez.

In Egypt, Fogg had encountered the first of many challenges. The Suez Canal, a marvel of modern engineering, had been a crucial link in their journey, allowing them to reach the Red Sea and continue on to Bombay. However, the journey through India had not been without its difficulties. Passepartout's inadvertent entry into a Hindu temple had nearly derailed their plans, but Fogg's quick thinking and resourcefulness had saved the day.

The journey from Bombay to Calcutta had been another test of their resolve. The railway line was incomplete, forcing them to find alternative means of transportation. It was during this leg of the journey that they had met Sir Francis Cromarty, who had become an invaluable ally. Together, they had navigated the challenges of the Indian subcontinent, including a daring rescue of a young woman named Aouda from a ritual sacrifice.

With Aouda now accompanying them, the group had continued on to Hong Kong, where they faced yet another setback. Passepartout had been separated from Fogg, leading to a frantic search and a narrow escape from the clutches of Detective Fix, who was determined to arrest Fogg on suspicion of robbery. Despite these challenges, Fogg had managed to board the steamer to Yokohama, where they were reunited with Passepartout.

Now, as they crossed the Pacific, Fogg remained focused on the task at hand. The journey was far from over, and the challenges ahead were daunting. The vast expanse of the United States lay before them, with its own set of trials and tribulations. Yet, Fogg was undeterred. His determination to win the wager and prove the feasibility of his journey was unwavering.

As the ship sailed steadily towards San Francisco, Fogg knew that time was of the essence. Every minute counted, and he was determined to make the most of each one. With half the world behind him, Phileas Fogg looked forward to the adventures that awaited him on the other side of the globe.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: On the ninth day after leaving Yokohama, Phileas Fogg had traversed exactly one half of the terrestrial globe. The "General Grant" was now crossing the 180th meridian, the line opposite to that of Greenwich. Passepartout was delighted to find that his watch, which he had stubbornly kept on London time, now agreed with the ship's chronometers. He had refused to change it, despite the various time zones they had crossed, and now felt vindicated. He wished that Detective Fix were there to see it, as he had often argued with him about the time differences. Passepartout, however, did not realize that his watch was only correct because they had crossed the International Date Line, and it was not a true reflection of the local time. Nevertheless, he was pleased with his discovery and continued to mock Fix's explanations about time zones and meridians, convinced that the sun would eventually align with his watch.

events.title: Fix's Pursuit Strategy Revealed
detailed_summary: The narrative poses the question of Fix's location.
It reveals that Fix was, in fact, aboard the 'General Grant'.
Upon arriving in Yokohama, Fix had gone directly to the English consulate, separating temporarily from Fogg.
There, he finally received the arrest warrant, which had trailed him from Bombay via the 'Carnatic'.
Fix was greatly disappointed, realizing the warrant was ineffective now that Fogg was no longer on British soil (Yokohama).
Extradition would now be required.
After a moment of frustration, Fix reasoned that the warrant would be valid again once Fogg reached England.
He concluded Fogg intended to return home, believing he had evaded the police.
Fix resolved to follow Fogg across the Atlantic.
He worried about the dwindling reward money, noting Fogg had already spent over £5,000 on various expenses, but took comfort in the Bank's wealth.
Having decided his course, Fix boarded the 'General Grant'.
He was present when Fogg and Aouda arrived.
To his shock, he recognized Passepartout despite his theatrical costume.
Fix quickly hid in his cabin to prevent a confrontation and relied on the crowded ship to remain unseen by Passepartout.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Where was Fix at that moment?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He quickly concealed himself in his cabin, to avoid an awkward explanation, and hoped—thanks to the number of passengers—to remain unperceived by Mr. Fogg’s servant.

events.text_segment:
Where was Fix at that moment?
He was actually on board the “General Grant.”
On reaching Yokohama, the detective, leaving Mr. Fogg, whom he expected to meet again during the day, had repaired at once to the English consulate, where he at last found the warrant of arrest. It had followed him from Bombay, and had come by the “Carnatic,” on which steamer he himself was supposed to be. Fix’s disappointment may be imagined when he reflected that the warrant was now useless. Mr. Fogg had left English ground, and it was now necessary to procure his extradition!
“Well,” thought Fix, after a moment of anger, “my warrant is not good here, but it will be in England. The rogue evidently intends to return to his own country, thinking he has thrown the police off his track. Good! I will follow him across the Atlantic. As for the money, heaven grant there may be some left! But the fellow has already spent in travelling, rewards, trials, bail, elephants, and all sorts of charges, more than five thousand pounds. Yet, after all, the Bank is rich!”
His course decided on, he went on board the “General Grant,” and was there when Mr. Fogg and Aouda arrived. To his utter amazement, he recognised Passepartout, despite his theatrical disguise. He quickly concealed himself in his cabin, to avoid an awkward explanation, and hoped—thanks to the number of passengers—to remain unperceived by Mr. Fogg’s servant.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Detective Fix was in Suez at that moment. He had been stationed there as part of his assignment to capture Phileas Fogg, who was suspected of robbing the Bank of England. Fix was eagerly awaiting the arrival of the steamer Mongolia, on which he believed Fogg was traveling. His mission was to intercept Fogg and arrest him as soon as he set foot on Egyptian soil. Fix was determined to fulfill his duty and was keeping a close watch on the passengers disembarking from the ship, hoping to identify and apprehend the elusive gentleman.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Where was Fix at that moment? He was actually on board the General Grant. On reaching Yokohama, Fix left Mr. Fogg, whom he had followed so faithfully, and hastened to the English consulate. He had at last secured the warrant of arrest, which, following him from Bombay, he had been unable to obtain at Hong Kong. But the consul, who was also a detective, was as disappointed as Fix himself. The warrant was useless, as long as Phileas Fogg was on foreign soil. The detective could only await his return to England to arrest him. Fix, thus discouraged, was about to return to the steamer, when he was fortunate enough to meet Passepartout, who was strolling about the streets of Yokohama in his Japanese costume. Fix recognized him at once, and, as he was about to make himself known to him, he was seized with a sudden idea. He would follow Passepartout, and thus learn what Phileas Fogg was doing. It was not difficult to keep Passepartout in sight, for he was walking with the easy gait of a man who was not pressed for time. Fix slipped into the crowd, and followed him at a distance. Passepartout went into a theatre, and Fix, who was not fond of the play, but who was curious to know what was going on, followed him. The detective was not long in ascertaining that the Frenchman was one of the performers in a Japanese troupe, and that he was acting in a play. Fix was astonished, but he was not surprised, for he had already seen Passepartout in a variety of disguises. He was, however, determined to keep an eye on him, and to follow him wherever he went. Passepartout, having finished his performance, left the theatre, and Fix followed him to the quay, where he saw him embark on the General Grant. Fix was now certain that Phileas Fogg was on board the steamer, and he resolved to follow him to America. He was not long in making up his mind, and he at once took passage on the General Grant. He was on board when Phileas Fogg and Aouda arrived, and he was not a little surprised to see Passepartout in his theatrical costume. Fix, however, did not make himself known to him, for he was afraid of being recognized, and he kept out of sight as much as possible. He was, however, determined to follow Phileas Fogg to the end of the world, if necessary, and to arrest him as soon as he set foot on English soil.

events.title: Confrontation and Uneasy Alliance Between Passepartout and Fix
detailed_summary: Despite Fix's efforts, he encountered Passepartout directly on the deck later that same day.
Without saying anything, Passepartout immediately attacked Fix.
He grabbed Fix by the throat and delivered a series of punches.
A group of American passengers watched with amusement, placing bets on the fight.
The assault demonstrated the superiority of French boxing technique.
After venting his anger, Passepartout felt relieved.
Fix, somewhat disheveled, stood up and coolly asked Passepartout if he was finished.
Passepartout confirmed he was done for the moment.
Fix requested a private conversation, stating it was in Fogg's interest.
Passepartout, seemingly swayed by Fix's composure, followed him to a secluded spot.
Fix acknowledged the beating, stating he had anticipated it.
He declared a shift in his strategy: previously Fogg's adversary, he was now supporting Fogg's journey.
Passepartout questioned if Fix now believed Fogg was innocent.
Fix coldly stated he still considered Fogg a criminal, urging Passepartout to listen.
He explained his past actions (using priests, intoxicating Passepartout, causing delays) were aimed at detaining Fogg on British territory until the warrant arrived.
Passepartout listened intently, fists clenched.
Fix continued, explaining that since Fogg seemed headed back to England, Fix's interest now lay in facilitating Fogg's return.
He argued their interests aligned, as only in England could Passepartout learn the truth about his master.
Passepartout carefully considered Fix's words and believed he was being sincere.
Fix proposed friendship.
Passepartout rejected friendship but agreed to an alliance, warning Fix against any betrayal.
Fix calmly accepted the terms.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On that very day, however, he met Passepartout face to face on the forward deck.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Agreed,” said the detective quietly.

events.text_segment:
On that very day, however, he met Passepartout face to face on the forward deck. The latter, without a word, made a rush for him, grasped him by the throat, and, much to the amusement of a group of Americans, who immediately began to bet on him, administered to the detective a perfect volley of blows, which proved the great superiority of French over English pugilistic skill.
When Passepartout had finished, he found himself relieved and comforted. Fix got up in a somewhat rumpled condition, and, looking at his adversary, coldly said, “Have you done?”
“For this time—yes.”
“Then let me have a word with you.”
“But I—”
“In your master’s interests.”
Passepartout seemed to be vanquished by Fix’s coolness, for he quietly followed him, and they sat down aside from the rest of the passengers.
“You have given me a thrashing,” said Fix. “Good, I expected it. Now, listen to me. Up to this time I have been Mr. Fogg’s adversary. I am now in his game.”
“Aha!” cried Passepartout; “you are convinced he is an honest man?”
“No,” replied Fix coldly, “I think him a rascal. Sh! don’t budge, and let me speak. As long as Mr. Fogg was on English ground, it was for my interest to detain him there until my warrant of arrest arrived. I did everything I could to keep him back. I sent the Bombay priests after him, I got you intoxicated at Hong Kong, I separated you from him, and I made him miss the Yokohama steamer.”
Passepartout listened, with closed fists.
“Now,” resumed Fix, “Mr. Fogg seems to be going back to England. Well, I will follow him there. But hereafter I will do as much to keep obstacles out of his way as I have done up to this time to put them in his path. I’ve changed my game, you see, and simply because it was for my interest to change it. Your interest is the same as mine; for it is only in England that you will ascertain whether you are in the service of a criminal or an honest man.”
Passepartout listened very attentively to Fix, and was convinced that he spoke with entire good faith.
“Are we friends?” asked the detective.
“Friends?—no,” replied Passepartout; “but allies, perhaps. At the least sign of treason, however, I’ll twist your neck for you.”
“Agreed,” said the detective quietly.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Passepartout was leaning against the railing, gazing out at the vast expanse of the ocean, lost in thought. The sea breeze ruffled his hair, and the sun cast a warm glow on his face. He seemed to be contemplating the journey they had embarked upon, the challenges they had faced, and the adventures that lay ahead.

Phileas Fogg approached him with his usual calm demeanor, his hands tucked into the pockets of his impeccably tailored coat. "Good day, Passepartout," he said, his voice steady and composed.

Passepartout turned to face his employer, a hint of surprise in his eyes. "Good day, Monsieur Fogg," he replied, straightening up and offering a respectful nod.

"I trust you are finding the voyage agreeable?" Fogg inquired, his gaze steady and penetrating.

"Indeed, monsieur," Passepartout replied, a smile breaking across his face. "The sea is magnificent, and the air is invigorating. It is a welcome change from the hustle and bustle of the cities."

Fogg nodded, his expression thoughtful. "We have made good progress thus far, but there is still much ground to cover."

Passepartout nodded in agreement, his mind drifting back to the various modes of transport they had utilized, from steamers to trains, and the myriad of cultures they had encountered along the way. "It is a remarkable journey, monsieur," he said, his voice filled with admiration.

Fogg allowed himself a rare smile, a subtle acknowledgment of the challenges they had overcome. "Indeed, it is," he said. "And with each passing day, we draw closer to our goal."

Passepartout felt a surge of determination, inspired by his employer's unwavering resolve. "We shall succeed, monsieur," he declared, his voice firm and confident.

Fogg regarded him with a look of approval. "I have no doubt, Passepartout," he said. "Your loyalty and resourcefulness have been invaluable."

Passepartout felt a swell of pride at the compliment, his spirits buoyed by the acknowledgment of his efforts. "Thank you, monsieur," he said, his voice filled with gratitude.

As they stood together on the deck, the ship cutting through the waves with steady purpose, both men felt a renewed sense of determination. The world lay before them, vast and full of possibilities, and they were ready to face whatever challenges awaited them on their journey around the world in eighty days.

'Hurrah! another for the Frenchman!' cried one. 'Bravo! the Frenchman is a fine fellow!' 'Hold him!' cried another. 'Take him off!' cried a third. events.title: Arrival in San Francisco
detailed_summary: Eleven days after the confrontation between Fix and Passepartout, the 'General Grant' arrived in San Francisco.
The date was December 3rd.
The ship sailed through the Golden Gate into the bay.
According to his schedule, Phileas Fogg was perfectly on time, having neither gained nor lost any days on this leg of the journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Eleven days later, on the 3rd of December, the “General Grant” entered the bay of the Golden Gate, and reached San Francisco.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg had neither gained nor lost a single day.

events.text_segment:
Eleven days later, on the 3rd of December, the “General Grant” entered the bay of the Golden Gate, and reached San Francisco.
Mr. Fogg had neither gained nor lost a single day.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Phileas Fogg had accomplished a significant portion of his journey, but challenges still lay ahead. The city was bustling with activity, and Fogg knew he had to remain vigilant to stay on schedule. Passepartout, his loyal servant, was eager to explore the vibrant streets, while Fogg focused on securing their next mode of transportation. The clock was ticking, and every moment counted in their race against time.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Eleven days later, on the 3rd of December, the "General Grant" entered the bay of the Golden Gate, and reached San Francisco. Phileas Fogg had neither gained nor lost a single day on this part of his journey. The "Carnatic" was due at Yokohama on the 14th of November; it arrived on the 13th; this was a gain of twelve hours. Mr. Fogg and his party had, therefore, twenty-four days in which to reach New York, and the "General Grant," setting sail on the 3rd of December, was due at San Francisco on the 11th. It arrived on the 3rd, and Mr. Fogg was therefore in advance of his time-table by eight days. Passepartout, the involuntary cause of this gain of time, was delighted. He was anxious to see the country, and was already thinking of the delights of San Francisco. Mr. Fogg, however, was not inclined to delay. He had no intention of stopping in San Francisco, but would proceed at once to New York. He had, therefore, only to find a means of conveyance to the American continent, and he was not long in doing so. The "General Grant" was a fine ship, and her captain, a worthy man, was ready to do anything to oblige Mr. Fogg. He offered to take him and his party to New York, and Mr. Fogg accepted the offer. The "General Grant" was to sail on the 4th of December, and Mr. Fogg and his party were to embark on that day. Passepartout was delighted at the prospect of seeing the great city of New York, and he was already planning how he would spend his time there. Mr. Fogg, however, was not inclined to delay, and he was anxious to reach New York as soon as possible. He had, therefore, only to find a means of conveyance to the American continent, and he was not long in doing so. The "General Grant" was to sail on the 4th of December, and Mr. Fogg and his party were to embark on that day. Passepartout was delighted at the prospect of seeing the great city of New York, and he was already planning how he would spend his time there.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXV. IN WHICH A SLIGHT GLIMPSE IS HAD OF SAN FRANCISCO

events.title: Arrival in San Francisco
detailed_summary: At 7 a.m., Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout arrived in America, disembarking onto a floating quay in San Francisco.
These quays adjusted with the tide, facilitating ship loading and unloading.
Various ships, including clippers, steamers, and multi-decked steamboats used on the Sacramento River, were docked alongside.
The quays held vast quantities of goods reflecting trade connections spanning continents and the Pacific islands.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was seven in the morning when Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout set foot upon the American continent, if this name can be given to the floating quay upon which they disembarked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There were also heaped up the products of a commerce which extends to Mexico, Chili, Peru, Brazil, Europe, Asia, and all the Pacific islands.

events.text_segment: It was seven in the morning when Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout set foot upon the American continent, if this name can be given to the floating quay upon which they disembarked. These quays, rising and falling with the tide, thus facilitate the loading and unloading of vessels. Alongside them were clippers of all sizes, steamers of all nationalities, and the steamboats, with several decks rising one above the other, which ply on the Sacramento and its tributaries. There were also heaped up the products of a commerce which extends to Mexico, Chili, Peru, Brazil, Europe, Asia, and all the Pacific islands.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The quay was bustling with activity, as passengers and goods were being unloaded from the steamer. Mr. Fogg, ever punctual and composed, led his companions through the throng with a determined stride. Aouda, though weary from the journey, maintained her grace and poise, while Passepartout, ever the curious and lively valet, marveled at the sights and sounds of this new land. Their adventure across America was about to begin.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was seven in the morning when Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout set foot upon the American continent, if this name can be given to the floating quay upon which they disembarked. These quays, rising and falling with the tide, thus facilitate the loading and unloading of vessels. Here were piled up the products of a commerce which extends to Mexico, Chile, Peru, Brazil, Europe, Asia, and all the Pacific islands. Passepartout, in his joy on reaching at last the American continent, thought he would manifest it by executing a perilous vault in fine style; but, tumbling upon some worm-eaten planks, he fell through them. It was a fortunate fall for him, for the planks, forming a kind of trap, let him through just as a heavy load of iron bars was passing over his head. He was not hurt, and soon reappeared, to the great delight of the crowd which had gathered around. Mr. Fogg, on reaching shore, proceeded to find out at what hour the first train left for New York, and learned that this was at six o'clock p.m.; he had, therefore, an entire day to spend in the Californian capital. He immediately repaired to the International Hotel, where he ordered breakfast for himself and his companions. The hotel was a spacious building, of a tolerably good style of architecture, and situated in the centre of Montgomery Street. Between the breakfast and dinner hours, the streets were crowded with people. The footpaths, side-walks, if they may be so called, were lined with booths, where all sorts of articles were sold: such as fruits, watches, revolvers, cutlery, and cigars. Some of these booths were even handsomely decorated. The streets were thronged with pedestrians, some of whom were in a great hurry, others were stopping at the windows of the stores; and there were many who seemed to be merely sauntering along. The city was alive with the bustle of trade, and the streets were filled with the noise of carriages and the cries of drivers. The processions of carts, carrying goods of all kinds, were incessant. The sidewalks were crowded with people, and the shops were filled with customers. The city was a hive of activity, and the air was filled with the sounds of commerce. Mr. Fogg and his companions spent the day in exploring the city, visiting its various attractions, and enjoying the sights and sounds of this bustling metropolis. They were impressed by the energy and vitality of the city, and by the diversity of its people and cultures. As the day drew to a close, they returned to the hotel to prepare for their journey to New York.

events.title: Passepartout's Mishap and First Impressions of the City
detailed_summary: Overjoyed to be in America, Passepartout attempted an acrobatic vault but fell through weak planks.
Embarrassed by his clumsy arrival, his resulting cry startled nearby birds.
Mr. Fogg inquired about the train schedule to New York and learned it departed at 6 p.m., leaving them a full day in San Francisco.
The trio took a carriage to the International Hotel, with Passepartout riding upfront.

From his vantage point, Passepartout observed San Francisco's wide streets, uniform houses, Gothic churches, docks, warehouses, and diverse population including Americans, Europeans, Chinese, and Indians.
He noted the city's transformation from its lawless Gold Rush past into a major center of commerce.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout, in his joy on reaching at last the American continent, thought he would manifest it by executing a perilous vault in fine style; but, tumbling upon some worm-eaten planks, he fell through them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was now a great commercial emporium.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout, in his joy on reaching at last the American continent, thought he would manifest it by executing a perilous vault in fine style; but, tumbling upon some worm-eaten planks, he fell through them. Put out of countenance by the manner in which he thus “set foot” upon the New World, he uttered a loud cry, which so frightened the innumerable cormorants and pelicans that are always perched upon these movable quays, that they flew noisily away.
Mr. Fogg, on reaching shore, proceeded to find out at what hour the first train left for New York, and learned that this was at six o’clock p.m.; he had, therefore, an entire day to spend in the Californian capital. Taking a carriage at a charge of three dollars, he and Aouda entered it, while Passepartout mounted the box beside the driver, and they set out for the International Hotel.
From his exalted position Passepartout observed with much curiosity the wide streets, the low, evenly ranged houses, the Anglo-Saxon Gothic churches, the great docks, the palatial wooden and brick warehouses, the numerous conveyances, omnibuses, horse-cars, and upon the side-walks, not only Americans and Europeans, but Chinese and Indians. Passepartout was surprised at all he saw. San Francisco was no longer the legendary city of 1849—a city of banditti, assassins, and incendiaries, who had flocked hither in crowds in pursuit of plunder; a paradise of outlaws, where they gambled with gold-dust, a revolver in one hand and a bowie-knife in the other: it was now a great commercial emporium.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He found himself in a dark and narrow passage, which was a part of the ship's hold. The sudden fall had left him momentarily stunned, but he quickly regained his senses and looked around, trying to understand where he had landed.

The hold was dimly lit by a few stray beams of light filtering through the cracks in the planks above. Dust motes danced in the air, and the smell of damp wood and sea salt was pervasive. Passepartout could hear the muffled sounds of the ship's crew and passengers above, oblivious to his predicament.

Realizing he needed to find a way back to the deck, Passepartout carefully navigated the cluttered space, avoiding piles of cargo and other obstacles. His heart raced with a mix of excitement and urgency; he couldn't afford to be left behind or miss any part of the journey.

After what felt like an eternity, he spotted a ladder leading upwards. Climbing it cautiously, he emerged back onto the deck, his clothes slightly disheveled but his spirits undampened. He brushed himself off, grateful for the adventure but even more thankful to be back in the open air.

Passepartout resolved to be more careful in his exuberance, but the thrill of the journey and the promise of new adventures ahead kept his spirits high as he rejoined his companions.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Passepartout, in his joy on reaching at last the American continent, thought he would manifest it by executing a perilous vault in fine style; but, tumbling upon some worm-eaten planks, he fell through them. Put out of countenance by the manner of his arrival, he uttered a loud cry, which so frightened the innumerable cormorants and pelicans that are always perched upon these rocks, that they flew noisily away. Mr. Fogg, as soon as he had ascertained the hour of the next train to New York, and had taken a room at the International Hotel, gave Passepartout the order to purchase some provisions. Passepartout, delighted to be able to resume his former occupation, mounted to the box of the carriage, and took a view of San Francisco. It was a large and handsome city, with its streets lined with fine houses, and seemed to have been entirely transformed since the days of the Californian gold fever. The Chinese, who are so numerous in the Celestial Empire, were there in great numbers, and Passepartout could not help observing that the city was inhabited by people of all nations, Americans, Europeans, Chinese, and Indians; and that it was the great commercial emporium of the Pacific, as well as a large and populous city.

events.title: Observations of San Francisco and the Hotel
detailed_summary: The City Hall tower provided a view of the grid-like streets, green squares, and a distinct Chinese district.
Traditional frontier attire was rare; instead, many formally dressed, active businessmen populated the city.
Streets like Montgomery Street boasted impressive stores displaying global goods, reminding Passepartout of major European thoroughfares.
Upon reaching the International Hotel, Passepartout felt as though he hadn't left England.
The hotel's ground floor featured a large, open bar offering complimentary snacks like dried beef and oyster soup, with payment required only for drinks.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The lofty tower of its City Hall overlooked the whole panorama of the streets and avenues, which cut each other at right-angles, and in the midst of which appeared pleasant, verdant squares, while beyond appeared the Chinese quarter, seemingly imported from the Celestial Empire in a toy-box.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This seemed “very American” to Passepartout.

events.text_segment:
The lofty tower of its City Hall overlooked the whole panorama of the streets and avenues, which cut each other at right-angles, and in the midst of which appeared pleasant, verdant squares, while beyond appeared the Chinese quarter, seemingly imported from the Celestial Empire in a toy-box. Sombreros and red shirts and plumed Indians were rarely to be seen; but there were silk hats and black coats everywhere worn by a multitude of nervously active, gentlemanly-looking men. Some of the streets—especially Montgomery Street, which is to San Francisco what Regent Street is to London, the Boulevard des Italiens to Paris, and Broadway to New York—were lined with splendid and spacious stores, which exposed in their windows the products of the entire world.
When Passepartout reached the International Hotel, it did not seem to him as if he had left England at all.
The ground floor of the hotel was occupied by a large bar, a sort of restaurant freely open to all passers-by, who might partake of dried beef, oyster soup, biscuits, and cheese, without taking out their purses. Payment was made only for the ale, porter, or sherry which was drunk. This seemed “very American” to Passepartout.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The city was a bustling hub of activity, with its streets teeming with people from all walks of life. The air was filled with the sounds of commerce, as vendors shouted their wares and the clatter of horse-drawn carriages echoed off the buildings. The architecture was a mix of old and new, with stately brick buildings standing alongside more modern structures.

In the Chinese quarter, the scene was even more vibrant. Lanterns hung from the eaves of the buildings, casting a warm glow over the narrow streets. The aroma of exotic spices and freshly cooked food wafted through the air, enticing passersby to stop and sample the culinary delights on offer. Shops were filled with an array of goods, from silk garments to intricate jade carvings, each item a testament to the rich cultural heritage of the community.

This diverse and dynamic city was a microcosm of the world, a place where different cultures and traditions coexisted in harmony.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The lofty tower of its City Hall overlooked the whole panorama of the streets and avenues, which cut each other at right-angles, and in the midst of which appeared pleasant, verdant squares, while beyond appeared the Chinese quarter, seemingly imported from the Celestial Empire in a toy-box. He was surprised to find that the traditional attire of the frontier was not prevalent; instead, the streets were filled with well-dressed businessmen, bustling with activity. The shops on Montgomery Street were filled with goods from all over the world, giving Passepartout the impression of being on a major European boulevard. When he arrived at the International Hotel, he felt as though he had not left England. The ground floor of the hotel featured a spacious bar, where snacks such as dried beef and oyster soup were offered for free, with only the drinks requiring payment.

events.title: Breakfast, Security Concerns, and an Unexpected Reunion with Fix
detailed_summary: Fogg and Aouda settled comfortably in the hotel dining area and were served breakfast by black waiters.
After breakfast, Fogg and Aouda planned to visit the English consulate for a passport visa.
As Fogg was leaving, Passepartout, influenced by stories of train attacks by Native American tribes, asked if they should purchase firearms like rifles and revolvers.
Fogg deemed it unnecessary but allowed Passepartout to acquire weapons if he wished, then proceeded towards the consulate.
Shortly after departing, Fogg encountered Detective Fix, seemingly by chance.
Fix feigned surprise, claiming they hadn't seen each other on the Pacific crossing, expressed pleasure at the reunion, and mentioned his own business required him to return to Europe.
Fix asked to join Fogg and Aouda on their walk through San Francisco, intending to keep Fogg under surveillance.
Fogg politely agreed to Fix's company.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg replied that the honour would be his; and the detective—who was determined not to lose sight of him—begged permission to accompany them in their walk about San Francisco—a request which Mr. Fogg readily granted.

events.text_segment:
The hotel refreshment-rooms were comfortable, and Mr. Fogg and Aouda, installing themselves at a table, were abundantly served on diminutive plates by negroes of darkest hue.
After breakfast, Mr. Fogg, accompanied by Aouda, started for the English consulate to have his passport visaed. As he was going out, he met Passepartout, who asked him if it would not be well, before taking the train, to purchase some dozens of Enfield rifles and Colt’s revolvers. He had been listening to stories of attacks upon the trains by the Sioux and Pawnees. Mr. Fogg thought it a useless precaution, but told him to do as he thought best, and went on to the consulate.
He had not proceeded two hundred steps, however, when, “by the greatest chance in the world,” he met Fix. The detective seemed wholly taken by surprise. What! Had Mr. Fogg and himself crossed the Pacific together, and not met on the steamer! At least Fix felt honoured to behold once more the gentleman to whom he owed so much, and, as his business recalled him to Europe, he should be delighted to continue the journey in such pleasant company.
Mr. Fogg replied that the honour would be his; and the detective—who was determined not to lose sight of him—begged permission to accompany them in their walk about San Francisco—a request which Mr. Fogg readily granted.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
After satisfying their hunger, they proceeded to the station, where they found the train ready to depart. Mr. Fogg, with his usual punctuality, ensured that their luggage was properly stowed, and they took their seats in a first-class carriage.

As the train began its journey, Aouda gazed out of the window, watching the landscape change from the bustling city to the serene countryside. She marveled at the vastness of the land, a stark contrast to the crowded streets of London she had left behind.

Mr. Fogg, ever the picture of composure, sat quietly, occasionally glancing at his watch to ensure they were on schedule. His mind was a whirlwind of calculations, each minute accounted for in his meticulous plan to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days.

Aouda, sensing his focus, did not disturb him, but her thoughts wandered to the adventures they had already experienced and the ones yet to come. She felt a sense of excitement mixed with apprehension, knowing that their journey was far from over.

The rhythmic clatter of the train wheels provided a soothing backdrop to their thoughts, as the miles slipped away beneath them, bringing them ever closer to their next destination.

After breakfast, Mr. Fogg, accompanied by Aouda, started for the English consulate to have his passport visaed. As he was leaving the hotel, he met Passepartout, who asked him if it would not be prudent, before taking the train, to purchase some dozens of Enfield rifles and Colt's revolvers. Passepartout had been listening to stories of attacks upon the trains by the Sioux and Pawnees. Mr. Fogg said it was unnecessary, but told him to do as he thought best, and went on to the consulate. He found Fix, who had arrived the evening before, and made a great show of surprise when he met Mr. Fogg. Fix expressed his pleasure at seeing him again, and, as he was going to Europe, begged to accompany him. Mr. Fogg agreed, and the party soon found themselves in the streets of San Francisco.

events.title: Observing a Tumultuous Political Rally
detailed_summary: Fogg, Aouda, and Fix reached Montgomery Street, finding it packed with people on sidewalks, streets, and even rooftops.
Individuals carried large posters, flags flew, and shouts for competing figures, Camerfield and Mandiboy, filled the air.
Fix identified the gathering as a political meeting and cautioned Fogg about potential danger within the crowd.
Fogg acknowledged the risk, wryly noting that political blows were still physical blows.
To get a better view without being caught in the throng, the group positioned themselves on a staircase overlooking the street.
Opposite them, a large outdoor platform was the focal point of the crowd's attention.
Fogg couldn't discern the specific purpose of the meeting, though he suspected it might be for nominating an official.
The crowd grew agitated, with hands raised (possibly voting) and people pushing; banners swayed and reappeared tattered.
The crowd's movement surged towards the steps where Fogg's party stood.
Fix speculated the meeting might concern the settled 'Alabama' issue or involve a confrontation between two rivals, whom he identified as Mr. Camerfield and Mr. Mandiboy.

events.text_segment:
They soon found themselves in Montgomery Street, where a great crowd was collected; the side-walks, street, horsecar rails, the shop-doors, the windows of the houses, and even the roofs, were full of people. Men were going about carrying large posters, and flags and streamers were floating in the wind; while loud cries were heard on every hand.
“Hurrah for Camerfield!”
“Hurrah for Mandiboy!”
It was a political meeting; at least so Fix conjectured, who said to Mr. Fogg, “Perhaps we had better not mingle with the crowd. There may be danger in it.”
“Yes,” returned Mr. Fogg; “and blows, even if they are political, are still blows.”
Fix smiled at this remark; and, in order to be able to see without being jostled about, the party took up a position on the top of a flight of steps situated at the upper end of Montgomery Street. Opposite them, on the other side of the street, between a coal wharf and a petroleum warehouse, a large platform had been erected in the open air, towards which the current of the crowd seemed to be directed.
For what purpose was this meeting? What was the occasion of this excited assemblage? Phileas Fogg could not imagine. Was it to nominate some high official—a governor or member of Congress? It was not improbable, so agitated was the multitude before them.
Just at this moment there was an unusual stir in the human mass. All the hands were raised in the air. Some, tightly closed, seemed to disappear suddenly in the midst of the cries—an energetic way, no doubt, of casting a vote. The crowd swayed back, the banners and flags wavered, disappeared an instant, then reappeared in tatters. The undulations of the human surge reached the steps, while all the heads floundered on the surface like a sea agitated by a squall. Many of the black hats disappeared, and the greater part of the crowd seemed to have diminished in height.
“It is evidently a meeting,” said Fix, “and its object must be an exciting one. I should not wonder if it were about the ‘Alabama,’ despite the fact that that question is settled.”
“Perhaps,” replied Mr. Fogg, simply.
“At least, there are two champions in presence of each other, the Honourable Mr. Camerfield and the Honourable Mr. Mandiboy.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The throng was so dense that it was difficult to move forward, and the air was filled with the hum of voices and the clatter of hooves and wheels. It was a scene of bustling activity, with vendors shouting their wares and newsboys crying out the latest headlines. The atmosphere was charged with excitement and anticipation, as if something momentous was about to occur.

Phileas Fogg and his companions, Passepartout and Detective Fix, navigated through the crowd with some difficulty. Passepartout, ever curious and eager to understand the local customs, asked a bystander what the commotion was about.

"It's the arrival of the new steamship," the man replied, gesturing towards the harbor. "Everyone's eager to catch a glimpse of it. It's said to be the fastest vessel yet, capable of crossing the Pacific in record time."

Passepartout relayed this information to Mr. Fogg, who nodded thoughtfully. The mention of speed and record times piqued his interest, as it aligned with his own quest to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days.

As they continued to make their way through the throng, Detective Fix kept a watchful eye on Fogg. He was still convinced that Fogg was the bank robber he had been pursuing, and he was determined not to let him out of his sight.

Eventually, they reached a vantage point where they could see the harbor. The steamship was indeed an impressive sight, its sleek lines and towering smokestacks a testament to the advances in engineering and technology. The crowd cheered as it came into view, its whistle blowing a triumphant note.

Fogg, ever the man of precision and calculation, checked his watch and made a mental note of the ship's schedule. He knew that every minute counted in his journey, and he was always on the lookout for opportunities to gain an advantage.

As the excitement in the street began to subside, Fogg and his companions continued on their way, their minds focused on the next leg of their journey. The world was full of wonders and challenges, and they were determined to meet them all head-on.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: They soon found themselves in Montgomery Street, where a great crowd was collected; the side-walks, street, horsecar rails, the shop-doors, the windows of the houses, and even the roofs, were full of people. Men were going about carrying large posters, and flags and streamers were floating in the wind; while loud cries, in which the names of Camerfield and Mandiboy were prominently heard, were uttered by the crowd. From the character of the shouts, and the movement of the crowd, Fix guessed that they were engaged in a political meeting; but he was not sure. He asked a man near him what the cause of the assembly was. Before the man could reply, a fresh agitation arose; hurrahs and excited shouts were heard; the staffs of the banners began to be used as offensive weapons; and fists flew about in every direction. Thumps were exchanged from the tops of the carriages and omnibuses which had been blocked up in the crowd. Boots and shoes went whirling through the air, and Mr. Fogg thought he even heard the crack of revolvers mingling in the din, the rout approaching the stairway, and the crowd swaying back and forth. "The gentlemen," said Fix to Mr. Fogg, "are evidently engaged in a political meeting; but it is not to be feared that they will proceed to extremes." "It is a meeting," replied Phileas Fogg, "but it is not a political meeting." "What is it, then?" "A meeting of the Camerfield and Mandiboy parties." "Ah!" said Fix, "I understand. The Camerfield and Mandiboy parties are the two great political parties of San Francisco, and they are holding a meeting to nominate a candidate for the next election." "I see," said Mr. Fogg; "but we shall do well to avoid this crowd." "It is too late," said Fix; "the crowd is already upon us."

events.title: Caught in the Political Brawl and Confrontation
detailed_summary: Aouda watched the chaotic scene with surprise, while Fix tried to ascertain the cause from a bystander.
Before getting an answer, the situation escalated further with renewed shouting and the use of banner staffs as weapons.
Fistfights broke out, projectiles like boots flew through the air, and Fogg thought he heard gunshots.
The crowd pushed towards the stairway, indicating one faction was being forced back, though it was unclear who.
Fix urged retreat, concerned for Fogg's safety and wary of anti-English sentiment if they were recognized.
As Fogg began to respond about being an English subject, a loud commotion erupted behind them.
A group supporting Mandiboy arrived, flanking the Camerfield supporters and trapping Fogg, Aouda, and Fix in the middle.
The rush of men armed with sticks was overwhelming; Fogg and Fix were jostled while trying to shield Aouda.
Fogg attempted to defend himself using his fists but was ineffective against the mob.
A large, red-bearded man, apparently the leader, raised his fist to strike Fogg.
Fix intervened, taking the blow meant for Fogg, resulting in a large bruise and a crushed hat.
Fogg contemptuously identified the attacker as a "Yankee".
The attacker retorted "Englishman!" and vowed they would meet again.
Fogg coolly agreed and exchanged names: Phileas Fogg and Colonel Stamp Proctor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda, leaning upon Mr. Fogg’s arm, observed the tumultuous scene with surprise, while Fix asked a man near him what the cause of it all was.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Colonel Stamp Proctor.”

events.text_segment:
Aouda, leaning upon Mr. Fogg’s arm, observed the tumultuous scene with surprise, while Fix asked a man near him what the cause of it all was. Before the man could reply, a fresh agitation arose; hurrahs and excited shouts were heard; the staffs of the banners began to be used as offensive weapons; and fists flew about in every direction. Thumps were exchanged from the tops of the carriages and omnibuses which had been blocked up in the crowd. Boots and shoes went whirling through the air, and Mr. Fogg thought he even heard the crack of revolvers mingling in the din, the rout approached the stairway, and flowed over the lower step. One of the parties had evidently been repulsed; but the mere lookers-on could not tell whether Mandiboy or Camerfield had gained the upper hand.
“It would be prudent for us to retire,” said Fix, who was anxious that Mr. Fogg should not receive any injury, at least until they got back to London. “If there is any question about England in all this, and we were recognised, I fear it would go hard with us.”
“An English subject—” began Mr. Fogg.
He did not finish his sentence; for a terrific hubbub now arose on the terrace behind the flight of steps where they stood, and there were frantic shouts of, “Hurrah for Mandiboy! Hip, hip, hurrah!”
It was a band of voters coming to the rescue of their allies, and taking the Camerfield forces in flank. Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Fix found themselves between two fires; it was too late to escape. The torrent of men, armed with loaded canes and sticks, was irresistible. Phileas Fogg and Fix were roughly hustled in their attempts to protect their fair companion; the former, as cool as ever, tried to defend himself with the weapons which nature has placed at the end of every Englishman’s arm, but in vain. A big brawny fellow with a red beard, flushed face, and broad shoulders, who seemed to be the chief of the band, raised his clenched fist to strike Mr. Fogg, whom he would have given a crushing blow, had not Fix rushed in and received it in his stead. An enormous bruise immediately made its appearance under the detective’s silk hat, which was completely smashed in.
“Yankee!” exclaimed Mr. Fogg, darting a contemptuous look at the ruffian.
“Englishman!” returned the other. “We will meet again!”
“When you please.”
“What is your name?”
“Phileas Fogg. And yours?”
“Colonel Stamp Proctor.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The man replied that it was a political meeting, and that the people were expressing their opinions on a recent government decision. The crowd was animated, with individuals shouting slogans and waving banners, each trying to make their voice heard above the din.

Aouda, unfamiliar with such public displays of political fervor, watched with a mixture of curiosity and concern. She had never seen such a passionate assembly of people, and the intensity of their emotions was both fascinating and a little intimidating.

Mr. Fogg, on the other hand, remained calm and composed, as was his nature. He observed the scene with a detached interest, as if it were merely another spectacle to be noted in his journey around the world. His demeanor was one of quiet confidence, and he seemed unperturbed by the chaos around him.

Fix, ever the detective, was more interested in the potential for disorder. He scanned the crowd, looking for any signs of trouble or any familiar faces that might indicate the presence of the man he was pursuing. His mind was always on his mission, and he was determined not to let anything distract him from his goal.

As the crowd continued to swell, the noise grew louder, and the atmosphere became more charged. Aouda tightened her grip on Mr. Fogg's arm, seeking reassurance in his steady presence. She was grateful for his calmness, which seemed to shield her from the tumult around them.

"It seems we have stumbled upon quite the event," Mr. Fogg remarked, his voice barely audible above the clamor.

"Indeed," Fix replied, his eyes still scanning the throng. "One must always be cautious in such situations."

Aouda nodded, though her attention was drawn back to the crowd. She marveled at the diversity of people gathered, each with their own story and reason for being there. It was a vivid reminder of the vastness and complexity of the world they were traversing.

As they moved through the crowd, Mr. Fogg guided Aouda with a gentle but firm hand, ensuring they stayed together amidst the jostling bodies. Fix followed closely, his mind still racing with thoughts of his quarry and the task at hand.

In the midst of the chaos, the trio continued on their journey, each with their own thoughts and concerns, but united in their determination to reach their destination.

Boots and shoes flew about in the air, and Mr. Fogg thought he even heard the crack of revolvers mingling in the din, the rout approached the stairway, and flowed into the street. It was evident that the Camerfielders had been repulsed, but the cause of the disorder was not yet known. Fix, in his position as a detective, was more anxious than Mr. Fogg, and was determined to find out what the cause of the commotion was. He was soon informed by a bystander that it was a political meeting, and that the Camerfielders and Mandiboyers were fighting for the possession of the hall. events.title: Aftermath and Attire Repair
detailed_summary: The crowd moved past, knocking Fix down momentarily; he quickly recovered, though his clothes were torn.
Fix was bruised but not seriously injured; his coat was ripped, and his trousers damaged.
Aouda remained unharmed.
Fogg thanked Fix for his intervention.
Fix dismissed the thanks and suggested they find a tailor.
The visit was necessary as both Fogg's and Fix's clothing were in tatters.
They spent an hour getting suitably re-dressed before returning with Aouda to the hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The human tide now swept by, after overturning Fix, who speedily got upon his feet again, though with tattered clothes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: An hour after, they were once more suitably attired, and with Aouda returned to the International Hotel.

events.text_segment:
The human tide now swept by, after overturning Fix, who speedily got upon his feet again, though with tattered clothes. Happily, he was not seriously hurt. His travelling overcoat was divided into two unequal parts, and his trousers resembled those of certain Indians, which fit less compactly than they are easy to put on. Aouda had escaped unharmed, and Fix alone bore marks of the fray in his black and blue bruise.
“Thanks,” said Mr. Fogg to the detective, as soon as they were out of the crowd.
“No thanks are necessary,” replied Fix; “but let us go.”
“Where?”
“To a tailor’s.”
Such a visit was, indeed, opportune. The clothing of both Mr. Fogg and Fix was in rags, as if they had themselves been actively engaged in the contest between Camerfield and Mandiboy. An hour after, they were once more suitably attired, and with Aouda returned to the International Hotel.

Meanwhile, Phileas Fogg, with his usual composure, navigated the bustling streets with Passepartout and Aouda close behind. The city was alive with noise and movement, a stark contrast to the serene journey they had experienced on the train. Fogg's mind was focused on the task at hand, calculating the time they had left and the distance still to cover.

Passepartout, ever vigilant, kept a watchful eye on their surroundings, aware that Fix was likely not far behind. Aouda, though weary, maintained her pace, trusting in Fogg's leadership.
