events.title: Reconciliation, Departure Preparations, and Boarding the Train
detailed_summary: Passepartout awaited Fogg at the hotel, having acquired several revolvers.
He initially frowned upon seeing Fix with his master.
Aouda quickly explained the events of the political rally and Fix's actions.
Hearing this, Passepartout's demeanor changed, accepting Fix as an ally who was upholding his promise.
After dinner, a coach arrived to take them to the train station.
As they boarded, Fogg asked Fix if he had encountered Colonel Proctor again, which Fix denied.
Fogg calmly stated his intention to return to America specifically to find Proctor and retaliate for the insult.
Fix smiled silently, recognizing Fogg's adherence to a code of honor regarding such confrontations abroad.
At 5:45 p.m., they reached the station where the train was ready.
Before boarding, Fogg asked a porter about the day's disturbance in San Francisco.
The porter explained it was just a political meeting for an election.
Fogg inquired if it was for a high office like general-in-chief.
The porter clarified it was only for the election of a justice of the peace.
Fogg boarded the train, which immediately departed at high speed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout was waiting for his master, armed with half a dozen six-barrelled revolvers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg got into the train, which started off at full speed.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout was waiting for his master, armed with half a dozen six-barrelled revolvers. When he perceived Fix, he knit his brows; but Aouda having, in a few words, told him of their adventure, his countenance resumed its placid expression. Fix evidently was no longer an enemy, but an ally; he was faithfully keeping his word.
Dinner over, the coach which was to convey the passengers and their luggage to the station drew up to the door. As he was getting in, Mr. Fogg said to Fix, “You have not seen this Colonel Proctor again?”
“No.”
“I will come back to America to find him,” said Phileas Fogg calmly. “It would not be right for an Englishman to permit himself to be treated in that way, without retaliating.”
The detective smiled, but did not reply. It was clear that Mr. Fogg was one of those Englishmen who, while they do not tolerate duelling at home, fight abroad when their honour is attacked.
At a quarter before six the travellers reached the station, and found the train ready to depart. As he was about to enter it, Mr. Fogg called a porter, and said to him: “My friend, was there not some trouble to-day in San Francisco?”
“It was a political meeting, sir,” replied the porter.
“But I thought there was a great deal of disturbance in the streets.”
“It was only a meeting assembled for an election.”
“The election of a general-in-chief, no doubt?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“No, sir; of a justice of the peace.”
Phileas Fogg got into the train, which started off at full speed.

He was prepared for any eventuality, knowing that their journey around the world had been fraught with unexpected challenges and dangers. The revolvers were a precaution, a means to ensure their safety as they traversed unfamiliar territories.

As he stood there, his mind wandered back to the various adventures they had encountered. From the bustling streets of Bombay to the serene landscapes of Japan, each location had presented its own set of trials. Passepartout recalled the time they had narrowly escaped a band of robbers in the American West, and how his quick thinking had saved them from a precarious situation.

Despite the dangers, Passepartout felt a sense of excitement and purpose. He had always been a man of action, and this journey had given him the opportunity to prove his mettle. He admired his master, Phileas Fogg, for his calm demeanor and unwavering determination. Fogg's confidence was infectious, and Passepartout found himself inspired to rise to the occasion, no matter what obstacles lay ahead.

As he waited, Passepartout checked the revolvers, ensuring they were loaded and ready. He knew that their journey was nearing its end, but he also understood that the final leg could be the most perilous. The stakes were high, and the world was watching to see if they would complete the journey in the allotted eighty days.

Passepartout's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of footsteps. He turned to see Phileas Fogg approaching, his expression as composed as ever. With a nod, Passepartout fell into step beside his master, ready to face whatever challenges awaited them on the final stretch of their incredible journey.

It was clear that Mr. Fogg was one of those Englishmen who, while they do not tolerate duelling at home, fight abroad when their honour is attacked. At a quarter before six, the travellers reached the station, and found the train ready to depart. As he was about to enter it, Mr. Fogg called a porter, and said to him: "My friend, was there not some trouble to-day in San Francisco?" "It was a political meeting, sir," replied the porter. "But I thought there was a great deal of disturbance in the streets." "It was only a meeting assembled for an election." "The election of a general-in-chief, no doubt?" asked Mr. Fogg. "No, sir; of a justice of the peace." Phileas Fogg got into the train, which started off at full speed.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXVI. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AND PARTY TRAVEL BY THE PACIFIC RAILROAD

events.title: The Great American Railway Network
detailed_summary: The term "From ocean to ocean" signifies the primary railway line spanning the United States.
This Pacific Railroad system is composed of two main sections: the Central Pacific (San Francisco to Ogden) and the Union Pacific (Ogden to Omaha).
Omaha connects to New York via five principal railway lines.
An unbroken railway line of 3,786 miles connects New York and San Francisco.
The section between Omaha and the Pacific crosses territories inhabited by Indigenous peoples and wildlife, as well as lands settled by Mormons after their expulsion from Illinois in 1845.
The railway drastically reduced the coast-to-coast journey time from a minimum of six months to just seven days.
The decision to build the railway between the 41st and 42nd parallels was made in 1862, despite opposition from Southern representatives advocating a more southern route.
President Lincoln designated Omaha, Nebraska, as the line's terminus.
Construction commenced immediately with notable American speed and efficiency, achieving roughly 1.5 miles of track laid per day on the prairies.
Locomotives used the newly laid tracks to transport materials for the next day's construction.
The Pacific Railroad integrates with several branch lines across Iowa, Kansas, Colorado, and Oregon.

The route from Omaha follows the Platte River, crosses the Laramie territory and Wahsatch Mountains, skirts the Great Salt Lake reaching Salt Lake City, traverses the Tuilla Valley, American Desert, Cedar and Humboldt Mountains, and the Sierra Nevada, finally descending through Sacramento to the Pacific.
The railway's grade, even through the Rocky Mountains, does not exceed 112 feet per mile.
This seven-day railway journey was essential for Phileas Fogg's plan to reach New York by December 11th to board the steamer for Liverpool.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “From ocean to ocean”—so say the Americans; and these four words compose the general designation of the “great trunk line” which crosses the entire width of the United States.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Such was the road to be traversed in seven days, which would enable Phileas Fogg—at least, so he hoped—to take the Atlantic steamer at New York on the 11th for Liverpool.

events.text_segment:
“From ocean to ocean”—so say the Americans; and these four words compose the general designation of the “great trunk line” which crosses the entire width of the United States. The Pacific Railroad is, however, really divided into two distinct lines: the Central Pacific, between San Francisco and Ogden, and the Union Pacific, between Ogden and Omaha. Five main lines connect Omaha with New York.
New York and San Francisco are thus united by an uninterrupted metal ribbon, which measures no less than three thousand seven hundred and eighty-six miles. Between Omaha and the Pacific the railway crosses a territory which is still infested by Indians and wild beasts, and a large tract which the Mormons, after they were driven from Illinois in 1845, began to colonise.
The journey from New York to San Francisco consumed, formerly, under the most favourable conditions, at least six months. It is now accomplished in seven days.
It was in 1862 that, in spite of the Southern Members of Congress, who wished a more southerly route, it was decided to lay the road between the forty-first and forty-second parallels. President Lincoln himself fixed the end of the line at Omaha, in Nebraska. The work was at once commenced, and pursued with true American energy; nor did the rapidity with which it went on injuriously affect its good execution. The road grew, on the prairies, a mile and a half a day. A locomotive, running on the rails laid down the evening before, brought the rails to be laid on the morrow, and advanced upon them as fast as they were put in position.
The Pacific Railroad is joined by several branches in Iowa, Kansas, Colorado, and Oregon. On leaving Omaha, it passes along the left bank of the Platte River as far as the junction of its northern branch, follows its southern branch, crosses the Laramie territory and the Wahsatch Mountains, turns the Great Salt Lake, and reaches Salt Lake City, the Mormon capital, plunges into the Tuilla Valley, across the American Desert, Cedar and Humboldt Mountains, the Sierra Nevada, and descends, viâ Sacramento, to the Pacific—its grade, even on the Rocky Mountains, never exceeding one hundred and twelve feet to the mile.
Such was the road to be traversed in seven days, which would enable Phileas Fogg—at least, so he hoped—to take the Atlantic steamer at New York on the 11th for Liverpool.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
This railway, which is more than three thousand miles long, starts at New York on the Atlantic coast and ends at San Francisco on the Pacific coast. It is a marvel of engineering, traversing vast plains, scaling mountain ranges, and bridging mighty rivers. The line is a testament to human ingenuity and determination, connecting the bustling cities of the East with the burgeoning towns of the West.

The journey across this great expanse is an adventure in itself, offering passengers a glimpse of the diverse landscapes and cultures that make up the United States. From the industrial heartlands of the East, the train speeds through the fertile farmlands of the Midwest, where endless fields stretch to the horizon. As it continues westward, the terrain becomes more rugged, with the majestic Rocky Mountains rising in the distance, their snow-capped peaks a stark contrast to the flatlands left behind.

Crossing the Rockies is a feat of engineering prowess, with the railway winding through narrow passes and over towering trestles. The views from the train are breathtaking, with deep valleys and towering cliffs providing a dramatic backdrop to the journey. Once over the mountains, the train descends into the arid landscapes of the Great Basin, where the vast deserts and salt flats offer a stark beauty of their own.

Finally, the train reaches the lush valleys and rolling hills of California, where the climate is milder and the land is rich with vineyards and orchards. The journey ends in San Francisco, a city of hills and fog, where the Pacific Ocean stretches out to the horizon, a vast expanse of blue that seems to go on forever.

This transcontinental railway is more than just a means of transportation; it is a symbol of the unity and progress of a nation. It represents the spirit of exploration and the desire to connect distant places, bringing people and ideas together across vast distances. For those who travel its length, it is a journey of discovery, a chance to see the country in all its varied glory, and to experience the thrill of crossing from ocean to ocean.

events.title: Aboard the Transcontinental Train
detailed_summary: The train car Phileas Fogg traveled in resembled a lengthy, open-plan bus mounted on eight wheels.
Inside, seats were arranged in two rows along the sides, separated by a central aisle leading to platforms at both ends.
These platforms were standard throughout the train, permitting passengers to move freely between cars.
The train boasted various amenities, including saloon cars, balcony cars, restaurants, and smoking cars; only theatre cars were absent, though anticipated in the future.
Vendors selling books, newspapers, food, beverages, and cigars constantly moved through the aisles, finding many buyers.
The train departed from Oakland station at 6:00 PM.
The evening was cold and gloomy, with overcast skies suggesting imminent snow.
The train proceeded at a moderate pace, averaging about twenty miles per hour including stops, deemed sufficient to arrive in Omaha on schedule.
Conversation among passengers was minimal, and many quickly drifted off to sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was but little conversation in the car, and soon many of the passengers were overcome with sleep.

events.text_segment:
The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior. It was supplied with two rows of seats, perpendicular to the direction of the train on either side of an aisle which conducted to the front and rear platforms. These platforms were found throughout the train, and the passengers were able to pass from one end of the train to the other. It was supplied with saloon cars, balcony cars, restaurants, and smoking-cars; theatre cars alone were wanting, and they will have these some day.
Book and news dealers, sellers of edibles, drinkables, and cigars, who seemed to have plenty of customers, were continually circulating in the aisles.
The train left Oakland station at six o’clock. It was already night, cold and cheerless, the heavens being overcast with clouds which seemed to threaten snow. The train did not proceed rapidly; counting the stoppages, it did not run more than twenty miles an hour, which was a sufficient speed, however, to enable it to reach Omaha within its designated time.
There was but little conversation in the car, and soon many of the passengers were overcome with sleep.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was a single, spacious cabin, with a stove, at one end, and a bar at the other, where passengers could obtain refreshments. A number of benches, placed at intervals, served as seats. A few passengers only occupied this car, and were wrapped in their travelling cloaks. Passepartout, who had been anxiously watching all that was going on, was suddenly startled by a loud cry, which was followed by a report of a gun. The train was being attacked by a band of Sioux.

These formidable warriors had been watching the train for some time, and, riding at full gallop alongside, had taken advantage of the stoppage to make a bold attack. They were armed with rifles, and had already wounded several passengers. Passepartout, not being a man to let himself be intimidated, rushed from the car, and soon discovered that the train was in great danger. The Sioux had already climbed the engine, and were fighting the engineer and stoker. Passepartout seized a revolver, and, getting upon the top of the car, proceeded to give battle to the savages.

events.title: Nightfall, Tension, and Transformation
detailed_summary: Passepartout was seated near Detective Fix, but avoided conversation due to the cooling of their relations after recent incidents.
Any previous mutual understanding or closeness between them had dissipated.
While Fix's outward behavior remained unchanged, Passepartout adopted a reserved stance, feeling hostile towards his former acquaintance.
About an hour into the journey, a fine snow began to fall, but it wasn't heavy enough to hinder the train's progress.
Visibility through the windows was limited to a vast expanse of white, against which the locomotive's smoke appeared greyish.
At 8:00 PM, a steward announced it was time to prepare for bed.
The car rapidly transformed into a sleeping compartment.
Seatbacks were adjusted, cleverly stored bedsteads were deployed, and berths were quickly set up.
Each traveler soon had access to a comfortable bed equipped with clean sheets, soft pillows, and thick curtains for privacy.
Passengers settled in for the night as the train continued its journey through California.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout found himself beside the detective; but he did not talk to him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It only remained to go to bed and sleep which everybody did—while the train sped on across the State of California.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout found himself beside the detective; but he did not talk to him. After recent events, their relations with each other had grown somewhat cold; there could no longer be mutual sympathy or intimacy between them. Fix’s manner had not changed; but Passepartout was very reserved, and ready to strangle his former friend on the slightest provocation.
Snow began to fall an hour after they started, a fine snow, however, which happily could not obstruct the train; nothing could be seen from the windows but a vast, white sheet, against which the smoke of the locomotive had a greyish aspect.
At eight o’clock a steward entered the car and announced that the time for going to bed had arrived; and in a few minutes the car was transformed into a dormitory. The backs of the seats were thrown back, bedsteads carefully packed were rolled out by an ingenious system, berths were suddenly improvised, and each traveller had soon at his disposition a comfortable bed, protected from curious eyes by thick curtains. The sheets were clean and the pillows soft. It only remained to go to bed and sleep which everybody did—while the train sped on across the State of California.

Since the evening before, Fix had been a changed man, and it was to Passepartout's advantage to avoid any conversation with him. The detective was, however, not wanting in politeness, and in his way, he tried to make himself agreeable. Passepartout, however, was not in the mood to be agreeable, and he was determined to keep his distance. The train was speeding across the vast plains of Nebraska, and the snow, which had begun to fall, was not heavy enough to impede its progress. The passengers could see nothing but a vast white expanse through which the locomotive was hurrying, its smoke trailing behind it. At eight o'clock a steward came to announce that it was time to prepare for bed, and the car, which had been transformed into a sleeping compartment, was soon filled with the sound of passengers settling in for the night. The seats were turned into beds, and the travelers, wrapped in their blankets, were soon asleep, while the train continued its journey through the night.

events.title: Through California and the Sierra Nevada
detailed_summary: The landscape between San Francisco and Sacramento featured gentle hills.
The Central Pacific line originates in Sacramento and extends eastward.
The route from San Francisco to Sacramento followed a north-easterly path along the American River.
This 120-mile stretch was covered in six hours.
Passengers passed through Sacramento, the state capital, around midnight while asleep, thus seeing none of its notable features like quays, streets, hotels, or public buildings.
Departing Sacramento, the train travelled through several junctions and towns (Roclin, Auburn, Colfax) before ascending into the Sierra Nevada mountain range.
The train reached Cisco at 7:00 AM.
An hour later, the sleeping car was converted back into a regular passenger car.
Travelers could then admire the striking mountain scenery.

The railway track navigated the mountain passes, sometimes running close to slopes, sometimes overhanging precipices, using bold curves to manage sharp angles and passing through narrow, seemingly dead-end defiles.
The locomotive, with its distinctive light, bell, and cow-catcher, produced loud sounds that echoed alongside the noises of mountain streams, its smoke drifting among large pine trees.
The route featured few bridges or tunnels, instead winding along the contours of the mountains rather than taking more direct, nature-altering paths.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The railway turned around the sides of the mountains, and did not attempt to violate nature by taking the shortest cut from one point to another.

events.text_segment:
The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly. The Central Pacific, taking Sacramento for its starting-point, extends eastward to meet the road from Omaha. The line from San Francisco to Sacramento runs in a north-easterly direction, along the American River, which empties into San Pablo Bay. The one hundred and twenty miles between these cities were accomplished in six hours, and towards midnight, while fast asleep, the travellers passed through Sacramento; so that they saw nothing of that important place, the seat of the State government, with its fine quays, its broad streets, its noble hotels, squares, and churches.
The train, on leaving Sacramento, and passing the junction, Roclin, Auburn, and Colfax, entered the range of the Sierra Nevada. ’Cisco was reached at seven in the morning; and an hour later the dormitory was transformed into an ordinary car, and the travellers could observe the picturesque beauties of the mountain region through which they were steaming. The railway track wound in and out among the passes, now approaching the mountain-sides, now suspended over precipices, avoiding abrupt angles by bold curves, plunging into narrow defiles, which seemed to have no outlet. The locomotive, its great funnel emitting a weird light, with its sharp bell, and its cow-catcher extended like a spur, mingled its shrieks and bellowings with the noise of torrents and cascades, and twined its smoke among the branches of the gigantic pines.
There were few or no bridges or tunnels on the route. The railway turned around the sides of the mountains, and did not attempt to violate nature by taking the shortest cut from one point to another.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It is characterized by a series of rolling plains and fertile valleys, which are part of the larger Central Valley of California. This region is known for its agricultural productivity, with vast expanses of farmland dedicated to crops such as fruits, vegetables, and nuts. The climate is typically Mediterranean, with hot, dry summers and mild, wet winters, making it ideal for farming.

As the train travels through this area, passengers can observe the changing landscape, from the bustling urban environment of San Francisco to the more rural and pastoral scenes of the countryside. The journey offers a glimpse into the diverse geography of California, showcasing the transition from coastal cityscapes to inland agricultural heartlands.

The route between San Francisco and Sacramento is also historically significant, as it follows part of the path of the first transcontinental railroad, completed in the 19th century. This railroad was a monumental engineering feat that connected the eastern United States with the Pacific Coast, facilitating commerce, travel, and the expansion of the American frontier.

In "Around the World in Eighty Days," the journey through this region would have been a part of Phileas Fogg's ambitious attempt to circumnavigate the globe in a mere eighty days. The novel, written by Jules Verne, captures the spirit of adventure and the technological advancements of the time, highlighting the impact of rail travel on global connectivity.

Overall, the area between San Francisco and Sacramento serves as a vital link in the transportation network of California, bridging the gap between major cities and supporting the state's economy through its agricultural output.

events.title: Buffalo Herd Causes Major Delay
detailed_summary: Around 9:00 AM, the train crossed into Nevada via the Carson Valley, continuing its northeast trajectory.
At noon, it arrived in Reno, pausing for a twenty-minute breakfast stop.
From Reno, the railway followed the Humboldt River north for some distance before turning eastward, staying near the river until reaching the Humboldt Range at Nevada's eastern edge.
After breakfast, Mr. Fogg and his companions returned to their seats, observing the changing scenery of prairies, distant mountains, and streams.
Occasionally, immense herds of buffalo appeared in the distance like moving barriers.
These vast herds frequently posed significant obstacles to trains, sometimes halting them for hours as thousands of animals crossed the tracks in dense formations.
Around midday, the train encountered such an obstacle: a massive herd of ten to twelve thousand buffalo blocking the way.
The locomotive reduced speed and attempted to nudge the animals aside with its cow-catcher, but the sheer number of buffalo made this impossible.
The animals proceeded calmly, occasionally letting out loud bellows, their movement seemingly unstoppable like a 'torrent of living flesh'.
Passengers observed this unusual sight from the train's platforms.
Phileas Fogg, despite having the most pressing schedule, remained seated, calmly and philosophically awaiting the herd's passage.
Passepartout grew increasingly agitated by the delay, expressing a desire to use his revolvers on the animals.
He exclaimed about the absurdity of mere cattle halting trains and wondered aloud if Fogg had factored such an event into his plans.
He also criticized the train's engineer for not attempting to force a passage through the herd.

The engineer, however, acted prudently by not confronting the buffalo, understanding that while the initial impact might clear some animals, the locomotive would quickly be overwhelmed, leading to derailment and immobilization.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

events.text_segment:
The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast.
From this point the road, running along Humboldt River, passed northward for several miles by its banks; then it turned eastward, and kept by the river until it reached the Humboldt Range, nearly at the extreme eastern limit of Nevada.
Having breakfasted, Mr. Fogg and his companions resumed their places in the car, and observed the varied landscape which unfolded itself as they passed along the vast prairies, the mountains lining the horizon, and the creeks, with their frothy, foaming streams. Sometimes a great herd of buffaloes, massing together in the distance, seemed like a moveable dam. These innumerable multitudes of ruminating beasts often form an insurmountable obstacle to the passage of the trains; thousands of them have been seen passing over the track for hours together, in compact ranks. The locomotive is then forced to stop and wait till the road is once more clear.
This happened, indeed, to the train in which Mr. Fogg was travelling. About twelve o’clock a troop of ten or twelve thousand head of buffalo encumbered the track. The locomotive, slackening its speed, tried to clear the way with its cow-catcher; but the mass of animals was too great. The buffaloes marched along with a tranquil gait, uttering now and then deafening bellowings. There was no use of interrupting them, for, having taken a particular direction, nothing can moderate and change their course; it is a torrent of living flesh which no dam could contain.
The travellers gazed on this curious spectacle from the platforms; but Phileas Fogg, who had the most reason of all to be in a hurry, remained in his seat, and waited philosophically until it should please the buffaloes to get out of the way.
Passepartout was furious at the delay they occasioned, and longed to discharge his arsenal of revolvers upon them.
“What a country!” cried he. “Mere cattle stop the trains, and go by in a procession, just as if they were not impeding travel! Parbleu! I should like to know if Mr. Fogg foresaw this mishap in his programme! And here’s an engineer who doesn’t dare to run the locomotive into this herd of beasts!”
The engineer did not try to overcome the obstacle, and he was wise. He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Leaving Reno, they kept on the way to the east, and at a quarter past twelve they passed the Humboldt River, which was then frozen. The road lay along its banks, and Phileas Fogg and his companions could see the curious landscape unroll before their eyes. Vast plains, dotted with scanty shrubs and isolated clumps of trees, stretched away to the horizon, with the mountains in the distance, their peaks covered with snow.

The train sped on with great speed, and soon they were in the midst of the Great Salt Lake Desert. This desert, which is about one hundred and twenty miles long and eighty wide, is covered with a layer of white salt, which glistens in the sun like a sheet of ice. It is a dreary, desolate place, with no vegetation, no water, and no sign of life.

The train continued its journey across the desert, and by evening they had reached the Great Salt Lake, a vast inland sea, which is about seventy miles long and thirty-five wide. The lake is surrounded by mountains, and its waters are so salty that no fish can live in them.

The train stopped at Ogden, where there was a delay of half an hour. Here, the passengers had an opportunity to stretch their legs and get some fresh air. Phileas Fogg and his companions took advantage of the stop to walk about the station and observe the bustling activity around them.

After leaving Ogden, the train continued its journey through the Rocky Mountains. The scenery was magnificent, with towering peaks, deep gorges, and rushing streams. The train wound its way through the mountains, sometimes passing through long tunnels, and at other times crossing high bridges over deep ravines.

As they traveled through the mountains, the weather grew colder, and the passengers wrapped themselves in their warmest clothing. The train climbed higher and higher, and soon they were in the midst of a snowstorm. The snow fell thick and fast, covering the tracks and making it difficult for the train to proceed.

Despite the snow, the train pressed on, and by morning they had reached the summit of the Rocky Mountains. From there, it was a downhill journey to the plains of Colorado. The train descended rapidly, and soon they were speeding across the flat, open country, leaving the mountains behind them.

Phileas Fogg and his companions were now well on their way to their next destination, and they settled back in their seats, confident that they would reach their goal on time.

There was no use of interrupting them, for, having taken a particular direction, nothing can moderate and change their course; it is a torrent of living flesh which no dam could contain. The travellers gazed on this curious spectacle from the platforms; but Phileas Fogg, who had the most reason of all to be in a hurry, remained there as composed as ever. He did not betray the least vexation. Yet Passepartout could not help muttering his impatience, and he longed to discharge his arsenal of revolvers upon them. "What a country!" he cried. "Mere cattle stop the trains, and go by in a procession, just as if they were not impeding travel! Parbleu! I should like to know if Mr. Fogg foresaw this mishap in his programme! And here’s an engineer who doesn’t dare to run the locomotive into this herd of beasts!" The engineer did not try to overcome the obstacle, and he was wise. He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

events.title: Resuming the Journey into Utah
detailed_summary: The most sensible approach was to wait for the obstruction to clear and then make up the lost time by increasing the train's speed.
The buffalo procession continued for three full hours.
The railway track was finally clear as night began to fall.
The last of the buffalo herd crossed the rails just as the front ranks disappeared over the southern horizon.
At 8:00 PM, the train navigated through the narrow passages of the Humboldt Range.
By 9:30 PM, it had entered the territory of Utah, noted as the area of the Great Salt Lake and the distinctive Mormon settlement.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was eight o’clock when the train passed through the defiles of the Humboldt Range, and half-past nine when it penetrated Utah, the region of the Great Salt Lake, the singular colony of the Mormons.

The last ranks of the herd were now passing over the rails, while the first had already disappeared below the southern horizon.
It was eight o’clock when the train passed through the defiles of the Humboldt Range, and half-past nine when it penetrated Utah, the region of the Great Salt Lake, the singular colony of the Mormons.

This mindset was crucial in his quest to win the wager.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXVII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT UNDERGOES, AT A SPEED OF TWENTY MILES AN HOUR, A COURSE OF MORMON HISTORY

events.title: Passepartout Encounters a Mormon Missionary
detailed_summary: The train altered course, heading towards the Great Salt Lake.
Around 9 AM, Passepartout went onto the platform for fresh air, noting the cold, grey weather and the sun appearing as a large golden ring through the mist.
He was distracted from estimating the sun's value by the appearance of a peculiar man.
This man, who boarded at Elko, was tall, dark, and dressed entirely in black, resembling a clergyman.
He moved through the train, posting handwritten notices on each car door.
Passepartout read a notice announcing a lecture on Mormonism by Elder William Hitch in car No. 117.
The notice invited those interested in learning about the 'Latter Day Saints' to attend.
Intrigued and knowing little about Mormonism beyond polygamy, Passepartout decided he would go.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He knew nothing of Mormonism except the custom of polygamy, which is its foundation.

events.text_segment:
During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake.
Passepartout, about nine o’clock, went out upon the platform to take the air. The weather was cold, the heavens grey, but it was not snowing. The sun’s disc, enlarged by the mist, seemed an enormous ring of gold, and Passepartout was amusing himself by calculating its value in pounds sterling, when he was diverted from this interesting study by a strange-looking personage who made his appearance on the platform.
This personage, who had taken the train at Elko, was tall and dark, with black moustache, black stockings, a black silk hat, a black waistcoat, black trousers, a white cravat, and dogskin gloves. He might have been taken for a clergyman. He went from one end of the train to the other, and affixed to the door of each car a notice written in manuscript.
Passepartout approached and read one of these notices, which stated that Elder William Hitch, Mormon missionary, taking advantage of his presence on train No. 48, would deliver a lecture on Mormonism in car No. 117, from eleven to twelve o’clock; and that he invited all who were desirous of being instructed concerning the mysteries of the religion of the “Latter Day Saints” to attend.
“I’ll go,” said Passepartout to himself. He knew nothing of Mormonism except the custom of polygamy, which is its foundation.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Passepartout, who had been anxiously watching the progress of the train, was relieved to see that they were making good time. The vast, open landscape of the American West stretched out before them, a seemingly endless expanse of plains and mountains. The train chugged along, its rhythmic clatter a constant companion to the travelers.

Phileas Fogg, as usual, remained calm and composed, his eyes occasionally glancing at his watch to ensure they were on schedule. He was a man of precision, and every minute counted in his quest to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days.

The Great Salt Lake, a vast inland sea, was a sight to behold. Its shimmering waters reflected the sky, creating a mirror-like effect that was both mesmerizing and surreal. The train skirted the lake's edge, offering passengers a panoramic view of its beauty.

As the train continued its journey, the passengers settled into their routines. Some read, others conversed, while a few dozed off, lulled by the gentle rocking of the train. Passepartout, ever curious, took the opportunity to learn more about the region they were passing through, engaging in conversation with fellow travelers and absorbing the sights and sounds of the American frontier.

The journey was far from over, but for now, they were on track, and that was all that mattered to Phileas Fogg.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake. Passepartout, about nine o'clock, went out upon the platform to take the air. The weather was cold, the sky grey, but it was not snowing. The sun's disc, enlarged by the mist, seemed an immense ring of gold, and Passepartout was amusing himself by calculating its value in pounds sterling, when he was diverted from this interesting study by a strange-looking personage who made his appearance on the platform. This person, who had taken the train at Elko, was tall and dark, with black moustache, black stockings, a black silk hat, a black waistcoat, black trousers, a white cravat, and dogskin gloves. He might have been taken for a clergyman. He went from one car to another, and, with a soft, oily, discreet voice, invited "gentlemen" to come and hear a "lecture" which he was going to deliver in car No. 117. He announced in the same tone, that he was Elder William Hitch, one of the Mormon missionaries, and that he would hold forth upon the subject of the "Mormon religion," inviting all who were desirous of being instructed concerning the mysteries of the "Latter Day Saints" to attend. Curiosity drew Passepartout to the lecture, and he went to car No. 117.

events.title: Elder Hitch's Fiery Lecture Begins
detailed_summary: Word of the lecture circulated among the train's approximately 100 passengers.
About thirty passengers gathered in car No. 117 for the lecture.
Passepartout secured a seat near the front.
Mr. Fogg and Fix chose not to attend the lecture.
Elder William Hitch began speaking at the scheduled time, his voice immediately irritated.
He proclaimed Joe and Hiram Smith as martyrs and suggested Brigham Young would also become one due to government persecution, challenging anyone to disagree.
No one contradicted him; his agitated tone seemed unusual for his calm appearance, likely stemming from the Mormons' recent struggles with the US government.

The narrative explains the government's recent subjugation of Utah and imprisonment of Brigham Young, leading to increased verbal resistance from Mormons like Elder Hitch, who sought converts on trains.

Using a loud voice and animated gestures, the Elder recounted Mormon history, starting from biblical times and the supposed discovery and translation of ancient religious texts by Joseph Smith, Jr. in 1825.
He described a divine messenger appearing to Smith in a forest with the sacred annals.
Some audience members lost interest and departed during this historical account.

Undeterred, Elder Hitch continued, describing the founding of the church, its international growth, the establishment of a colony and temple in Ohio, and Smith's venture into banking, including acquiring an ancient papyrus.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Several of the audience, not being much interested in the missionary’s narrative, here left the car; but Elder Hitch, continuing his lecture, related how Smith, junior, with his father, two brothers, and a few disciples, founded the church of the “Latter Day Saints,” which, adopted not only in America, but in England, Norway and Sweden, and Germany, counts many artisans, as well as men engaged in the liberal professions, among its members; how a colony was established in Ohio, a temple erected there at a cost of two hundred thousand dollars, and a town built at Kirkland; how Smith became an enterprising banker, and received from a simple mummy showman a papyrus scroll written by Abraham and several famous Egyptians.

events.text_segment:
The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. Passepartout took one of the front seats. Neither Mr. Fogg nor Fix cared to attend.
At the appointed hour Elder William Hitch rose, and, in an irritated voice, as if he had already been contradicted, said, “I tell you that Joe Smith is a martyr, that his brother Hiram is a martyr, and that the persecutions of the United States Government against the prophets will also make a martyr of Brigham Young. Who dares to say the contrary?”
No one ventured to gainsay the missionary, whose excited tone contrasted curiously with his naturally calm visage. No doubt his anger arose from the hardships to which the Mormons were actually subjected. The government had just succeeded, with some difficulty, in reducing these independent fanatics to its rule. It had made itself master of Utah, and subjected that territory to the laws of the Union, after imprisoning Brigham Young on a charge of rebellion and polygamy. The disciples of the prophet had since redoubled their efforts, and resisted, by words at least, the authority of Congress. Elder Hitch, as is seen, was trying to make proselytes on the very railway trains.
Then, emphasising his words with his loud voice and frequent gestures, he related the history of the Mormons from Biblical times: how that, in Israel, a Mormon prophet of the tribe of Joseph published the annals of the new religion, and bequeathed them to his son Mormon; how, many centuries later, a translation of this precious book, which was written in Egyptian, was made by Joseph Smith, junior, a Vermont farmer, who revealed himself as a mystical prophet in 1825; and how, in short, the celestial messenger appeared to him in an illuminated forest, and gave him the annals of the Lord.
Several of the audience, not being much interested in the missionary’s narrative, here left the car; but Elder Hitch, continuing his lecture, related how Smith, junior, with his father, two brothers, and a few disciples, founded the church of the “Latter Day Saints,” which, adopted not only in America, but in England, Norway and Sweden, and Germany, counts many artisans, as well as men engaged in the liberal professions, among its members; how a colony was established in Ohio, a temple erected there at a cost of two hundred thousand dollars, and a town built at Kirkland; how Smith became an enterprising banker, and received from a simple mummy showman a papyrus scroll written by Abraham and several famous Egyptians.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The excitement was palpable as the passengers settled into their seats, eager to witness the unfolding events. Among them were a variety of individuals, each with their own reasons for being on this journey, yet all momentarily united by the intrigue of the situation.

In the corner of the car, a group of businessmen discussed the implications of the news on their ventures, their voices a mix of concern and curiosity. Nearby, a family on vacation whispered animatedly, the children wide-eyed with anticipation, their imaginations running wild with possibilities.

A few rows back, a solitary traveler, a writer by profession, scribbled furiously in a notebook, capturing the scene with a keen eye for detail. The writer's mind raced with ideas, already envisioning how this moment might be woven into a future story.

As the train continued its journey, the passengers in car No. 117 found themselves drawn into conversations with strangers, sharing theories and speculations about the news that had brought them together. The air was thick with a sense of camaraderie, a shared experience that transcended their individual backgrounds and destinations.

Meanwhile, the train sped along the tracks, the rhythmic clatter of wheels on rails providing a steady backdrop to the lively discussions. Outside, the landscape blurred by, a testament to the speed and efficiency of modern travel, yet inside, time seemed to slow as the passengers became engrossed in their shared adventure.

As the journey progressed, the initial excitement began to give way to a more reflective mood. Some passengers turned their attention to the scenery outside, watching as the world unfolded beyond the windows. Others returned to their books or newspapers, their minds still buzzing with the earlier excitement.

In the midst of it all, the conductor moved through the car, checking tickets and ensuring that everything was in order. His presence was a reminder of the routine nature of the journey, even as the passengers remained caught up in the extraordinary circumstances that had brought them together.

As the train approached its next stop, the passengers in car No. 117 began to gather their belongings, preparing to disembark or continue on to their final destinations. The conversations that had filled the car gradually quieted, replaced by the sounds of zippers and rustling bags.

Yet, as they prepared to leave, there was a sense that this shared experience had left a lasting impression. For a brief moment, the passengers of car No. 117 had been part of something larger than themselves, a reminder of the unexpected connections that can arise in the most ordinary of circumstances.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. Passepartout took one of the front seats. Neither Mr. Fogg nor Fix cared to attend. At the appointed hour, Elder William Hitch rose, and in an irritated voice, as if he had already been contradicted, said: "I am going to tell you about the Mormons." He then proceeded to relate the history of the religion, beginning with that of Joseph Smith, its founder, and the persecutions which its adherents endured. He declared that the Mormons were the most persecuted sect in the world, and that they had been driven from their homes and forced to seek refuge in the far West. He recounted the martyrdom of Joe and Hiram Smith, the prophets, and the revelations of the Book of Mormon, which was published in 1830. He spoke of the persecutions they had suffered in Missouri and Illinois, and of the exodus to Utah, where the Mormons had founded a new state. He told of the prosperity of the community, which was due to the industry and thrift of its members, and of the persecutions they had again suffered at the hands of the United States government. He concluded by saying that the Mormons were a peaceful and law-abiding people, and that they only asked to be let alone. During the lecture, some of the passengers, not being much interested in the subject, left the car; but others, attracted by the speaker's fervor, remained. Passepartout was among the latter, and listened with all his ears. He was very much interested in the story of the Mormons, and he felt that he had learned something new about the world.

events.title: Lecture Audience Dwindles as Smith's Story Continues
detailed_summary: The lecture grew tedious, causing the audience to shrink to twenty people.
The Elder, unaffected by the departures, recounted Joseph Smith's bankruptcy in 1837 and subsequent tarring and feathering by creditors.
He described Smith's comeback years later, leading a large community in Independence, Missouri, before being driven out and heading west.
The audience dwindled further to only ten listeners, including Passepartout, who remained attentive.
Passepartout learned about Smith's later life: his return after persecutions, founding the large Nauvoo community in Illinois in 1839 where he held multiple leadership roles.
He heard about Smith's 1843 presidential candidacy.
Finally, the Elder recounted Smith's capture in Carthage, imprisonment, and assassination by masked attackers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus he learned that, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and in 1839 founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls, of which he became mayor, chief justice, and general-in-chief; that he announced himself, in 1843, as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States; and that finally, being drawn into ambuscade at Carthage, he was thrown into prison, and assassinated by a band of men disguised in masks.

events.text_segment:
The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers. But this did not disconcert the enthusiast, who proceeded with the story of Joseph Smith’s bankruptcy in 1837, and how his ruined creditors gave him a coat of tar and feathers; his reappearance some years afterwards, more honourable and honoured than ever, at Independence, Missouri, the chief of a flourishing colony of three thousand disciples, and his pursuit thence by outraged Gentiles, and retirement into the Far West.
Ten hearers only were now left, among them honest Passepartout, who was listening with all his ears. Thus he learned that, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and in 1839 founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls, of which he became mayor, chief justice, and general-in-chief; that he announced himself, in 1843, as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States; and that finally, being drawn into ambuscade at Carthage, he was thrown into prison, and assassinated by a band of men disguised in masks.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The Elder, undeterred by the dwindling crowd, continued his tale with the same fervor as when he began. His voice, though slightly hoarse from the hours of storytelling, carried a certain charm that kept the remaining listeners engaged. Among them was a young woman, her eyes wide with fascination, and an elderly gentleman who nodded occasionally, as if in agreement with the Elder's words.

The story wove through various lands and times, touching upon themes of adventure, love, and the relentless passage of time. The Elder spoke of distant places, where the sun set in hues of gold and crimson, and of people whose lives were as varied as the landscapes they inhabited. His narrative was rich with detail, painting vivid pictures in the minds of those who remained.

As the night wore on, the passengers, though fewer in number, found themselves drawn into the world the Elder created, their imaginations ignited by the tales of far-off lands and the promise of discovery.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers. But this did not disconcert the enthusiast, who proceeded with the story of Joseph Smith’s bankruptcy in 1837. This bankruptcy did not prevent him from continuing his religious work, and in 1839 he founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls. He was then elected mayor of the town, and chief justice of the court. But unluckily, the same year, the Mormons were driven out of Illinois, and had to seek a refuge in the Far West. Passepartout listened with all his ears to this history of the Mormons, which he heard for the first time. He learned how, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and in 1843 announced himself as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States; and how, finally, being drawn into the ambuscade at Carthage, he was thrown into prison, and assassinated by a band of masked men. Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder looked at him intently, and then continued his lecture with enthusiasm.

events.title: Passepartout Alone Hears Lecture's End and Refuses Conversion
detailed_summary: Eventually, only Passepartout remained in the audience.
The Elder addressed Passepartout directly, shifting focus to Brigham Young's succession after Smith's death.
He described Young leading the Mormons from Nauvoo to the Great Salt Lake.
He highlighted the colony's success in that fertile region along the emigrant trail, attributing its growth to the practice of polygamy.
The Elder passionately denounced the US government's actions against them, citing congressional jealousy, military intervention in Utah, and the imprisonment of Brigham Young as unjust.
He declared the Mormons would never yield to force, having been driven from multiple states, and would find a new independent territory.
Fixing his gaze upon Passepartout, the Elder directly asked if he, 'my brother,' would join them under their flag.
Passepartout bravely answered 'No!' and promptly left the car, leaving the Elder alone.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder, looking him full in the face, reminded him that, two years after the assassination of Joseph Smith, the inspired prophet, Brigham Young, his successor, left Nauvoo for the banks of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, directly on the route of the emigrants who crossed Utah on their way to California, the new colony, thanks to the polygamy practised by the Mormons, had flourished beyond expectations.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “No!” replied Passepartout courageously, in his turn retiring from the car, and leaving the Elder to preach to vacancy.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder, looking him full in the face, reminded him that, two years after the assassination of Joseph Smith, the inspired prophet, Brigham Young, his successor, left Nauvoo for the banks of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, directly on the route of the emigrants who crossed Utah on their way to California, the new colony, thanks to the polygamy practised by the Mormons, had flourished beyond expectations.
“And this,” added Elder William Hitch, “this is why the jealousy of Congress has been aroused against us! Why have the soldiers of the Union invaded the soil of Utah? Why has Brigham Young, our chief, been imprisoned, in contempt of all justice? Shall we yield to force? Never! Driven from Vermont, driven from Illinois, driven from Ohio, driven from Missouri, driven from Utah, we shall yet find some independent territory on which to plant our tents. And you, my brother,” continued the Elder, fixing his angry eyes upon his single auditor, “will you not plant yours there, too, under the shadow of our flag?”
“No!” replied Passepartout courageously, in his turn retiring from the car, and leaving the Elder to preach to vacancy.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Passepartout listened with a mixture of curiosity and skepticism. He had heard of the Mormons and their unique practices, but this was the first time he was hearing such a detailed account from someone who seemed to be a true believer. The Elder continued, explaining how the community had grown rapidly, attracting converts from all over the world, and how their industrious nature had turned the desert into a thriving settlement.

The Elder spoke of the challenges they faced, from harsh weather to conflicts with neighboring settlers, but emphasized their resilience and faith. Passepartout, though intrigued, couldn't help but think of his own journey and the pressing need to continue on his way with Mr. Fogg. He nodded politely, eager to rejoin his master and resume their adventure.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Passepartout was now the only person left in the car, and the Elder, looking him full in the face, reminded him that, two years after the assassination of Joseph Smith, the inspired prophet, Brigham Young, his successor, left Nauvoo for the banks of the Great Salt Lake, where, in the midst of that fertile region, directly on the route of the emigrants who crossed Utah on their way to California, the new colony, thanks to the polygamy practised by the Mormons, had flourished beyond expectations. And this, the Elder continued, was the reason why the jealousy of Congress had been aroused against us. Why have we been driven from state to state? Why has the government now resolved to persecute us? We are only a handful of men, driven from our homes, and we ask but to live in peace. But the government, by its acts, has declared war against us, and the Mormons have been compelled to take up arms. We have been driven from Missouri, from Illinois, and now we are threatened with being driven from Utah. But we will not yield; we will not give up the land which we have reclaimed from the desert; we will not abandon our homes; and we will find, if need be, a new territory, where we can live in peace. And, now, my brother, will you come with us? Will you join us under our flag? No! replied Passepartout courageously, in his turn retiring from the car, and leaving the Elder alone.

events.title: Arrival at Great Salt Lake and Description of Region
detailed_summary: While the lecture occurred, the train continued its journey.
Around 12:30 PM, the train arrived at the edge of the Great Salt Lake.
Passengers could view the large inland sea, also known as the Dead Sea, fed by an 'American Jordan'.
The lake was described as picturesque, surrounded by salt-encrusted cliffs, having shrunk over time, increasing its depth.
Specific details about the lake's dimensions (70 miles long, 35 wide) and high elevation (3,800 feet) were provided.
Its high salt content (specific weight 1,170) was noted, making it inhospitable to fish, unlike Lake Asphaltite.
The surrounding land was described as well-cultivated by Mormon farmers, anticipating features like ranches, crop fields, prairies, and various plants that would be visible in warmer months.
Currently, however, a light layer of snow covered the ground.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: During the lecture the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now the ground was covered with a thin powdering of snow.

events.text_segment:
During the lecture the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake. Thence the passengers could observe the vast extent of this interior sea, which is also called the Dead Sea, and into which flows an American Jordan. It is a picturesque expanse, framed in lofty crags in large strata, encrusted with white salt—a superb sheet of water, which was formerly of larger extent than now, its shores having encroached with the lapse of time, and thus at once reduced its breadth and increased its depth.
The Salt Lake, seventy miles long and thirty-five wide, is situated three miles eight hundred feet above the sea. Quite different from Lake Asphaltite, whose depression is twelve hundred feet below the sea, it contains considerable salt, and one quarter of the weight of its water is solid matter, its specific weight being 1,170, and, after being distilled, 1,000. Fishes are, of course, unable to live in it, and those which descend through the Jordan, the Weber, and other streams soon perish.
The country around the lake was well cultivated, for the Mormons are mostly farmers; while ranches and pens for domesticated animals, fields of wheat, corn, and other cereals, luxuriant prairies, hedges of wild rose, clumps of acacias and milk-wort, would have been seen six months later. Now the ground was covered with a thin powdering of snow.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
This immense inland sea, about seventy miles long and thirty-five wide, lay between the Utah and Nevada territories. The Great Salt Lake, and the surrounding region, is the result of a vast inland sea, which has gradually evaporated, leaving this great salt basin, and its picturesque cliffs, strange and fantastic crags, and its white shores, fringed with salt crystals. 

Around the lake there was a desert, and the train sped onward with a speed of twenty miles an hour. The road was smooth, the weather was fine, and Passepartout was delighted with the charming country. He was, however, surprised to see that the famous lake was not on the left, but on the right, and he could not understand how a lake could be on the south of the road. But the engineer explained that the road, turning around the lake, left it on the right, and that it was on the left that the lake was situated. 

The train, after leaving Ogden, passed the stations of Corinne, Blue Creek, and Promontory, and entered the valley of the Great Salt Lake. It was in this valley that the American engineers found the most difficult part of the road, and it was only by the most extraordinary efforts that they succeeded in laying the rails across it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: During the lecture the train had been making good progress, and towards half-past twelve it reached the northwest border of the Great Salt Lake. From this point the passengers could catch a glimpse of the vast lake, the largest in the United States, next to the Caspian Sea in size. It is a picturesque sheet of water, framed by mountains of a bold outline; the American Jordan, which empties into it, is a little river which rises in Utah Lake, a lake also fed by the waters of the great Salt Lake. The Great Salt Lake, seventy miles long and thirty-five wide, is situated three thousand eight hundred feet above the sea. Quite different from Lake Asphaltite, whose depression is twelve hundred feet below the sea, it contains considerable salt, and one quarter of the weight of its water is solid matter, its specific weight being 1,170, and after being distilled, 1,000. Fishes are, of course, unable to live in it, and those which descend through the Jordan, the Weber, and other streams soon perish. The border of the lake was inhabited by numerous colonies of Mormons, who, with the practice of polygamy, had made a flourishing state of the territory. The country around the lake was well cultivated, for the Mormons are mostly farmers; while ranches, large tracts of pasture land, fields of wheat, corn, and other cereals, luxuriant prairies, hedges of wild rose, clumps of acacias, and milkwort, would have been seen if the season had been propitious. Unfortunately, the ground was then covered with a thin powdering of snow, which, however, did not prevent the birds from flying about, nor the ploughs from turning up the fruitful soil. Farther on, the train passed the walls of Ogden, a town which was laid out like a checker-board, with the sombre sadness peculiar to all Mormon towns. A few miles further on, the train entered the territory of Wyoming—that vast tract of steppes, which the Mormons were endeavoring to convert into fields, and which is as large as the whole of England.

events.title: Excursion to Salt Lake City
detailed_summary: The train arrived at Ogden at 2 PM for a six-hour stop.
Mr. Fogg, Passepartout, and Fix took a branch line to visit Salt Lake City for two hours.
The city was characterized as typically American in its grid-like layout, invoking Victor Hugo's description of right-angled sobriety.
The narrator commented on the Anglo-Saxon preference for symmetry evident in the city's design.
At 3 PM, the travelers walked through the town, located between the Jordan River and the Wahsatch Mountains.
They observed few churches but noted significant buildings like the prophet's mansion, courthouse, and arsenal.
Houses were described as blue-brick with verandas and gardens, enclosed by a clay/pebble wall from 1853.
The main street featured a market and hotels.
The city felt sparsely populated, with deserted streets except near the temple area, which was enclosed by palisades.
A large number of women were present, attributed to the Mormon practice of polygamy.
The text clarified that not all Mormons practice polygamy, but Mormon women are particularly keen to marry due to religious beliefs about salvation.
The women observed did not appear particularly prosperous or content; their clothing varied from modest black silk dresses to attire resembling Native American fashion.
