events.text_segment:
The train reached Ogden at two o’clock, where it rested for six hours, Mr. Fogg and his party had time to pay a visit to Salt Lake City, connected with Ogden by a branch road; and they spent two hours in this strikingly American town, built on the pattern of other cities of the Union, like a checker-board, “with the sombre sadness of right-angles,” as Victor Hugo expresses it. The founder of the City of the Saints could not escape from the taste for symmetry which distinguishes the Anglo-Saxons. In this strange country, where the people are certainly not up to the level of their institutions, everything is done “squarely”—cities, houses, and follies.
The travellers, then, were promenading, at three o’clock, about the streets of the town built between the banks of the Jordan and the spurs of the Wahsatch Range. They saw few or no churches, but the prophet’s mansion, the court-house, and the arsenal, blue-brick houses with verandas and porches, surrounded by gardens bordered with acacias, palms, and locusts. A clay and pebble wall, built in 1853, surrounded the town; and in the principal street were the market and several hotels adorned with pavilions. The place did not seem thickly populated. The streets were almost deserted, except in the vicinity of the temple, which they only reached after having traversed several quarters surrounded by palisades. There were many women, which was easily accounted for by the “peculiar institution” of the Mormons; but it must not be supposed that all the Mormons are polygamists. They are free to marry or not, as they please; but it is worth noting that it is mainly the female citizens of Utah who are anxious to marry, as, according to the Mormon religion, maiden ladies are not admitted to the possession of its highest joys. These poor creatures seemed to be neither well off nor happy. Some—the more well-to-do, no doubt—wore short, open, black silk dresses, under a hood or modest shawl; others were habited in Indian fashion.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The streets were wide, lined with trees, and the houses, with their verandas, balconies, and gardens, seemed to be comfortable and pleasant. A notable feature of the city was the Temple, a vast edifice of grey stone, the principal sanctuary of the Mormons. It was here that the followers of the prophet Joseph Smith assembled for worship, and the building was a testament to their faith and perseverance.

Phileas Fogg and his companions took a carriage to explore the city. They observed the orderly nature of the town, the industriousness of its inhabitants, and the unique culture that had developed in this isolated part of the United States. The Mormons, known for their communal lifestyle and religious devotion, had created a thriving community in the midst of the desert.

As they toured the city, Passepartout was particularly struck by the contrast between the bustling streets and the serene atmosphere of the Temple Square. He marveled at the dedication of the people who had built such a city in such a remote location.

After their brief visit, the group returned to Ogden to continue their journey. The train was ready to depart, and they resumed their seats, reflecting on the unique experience they had just had. Salt Lake City had been a fascinating stop on their whirlwind tour of the world, offering a glimpse into a different way of life and a testament to the diverse cultures that could be found across the globe.

As the train pulled away from Ogden, Mr. Fogg remained as composed as ever, his mind focused on the journey ahead and the meticulous schedule he intended to keep. The adventure continued, with each stop bringing new sights and experiences.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The train reached Ogden at two o’clock, where it rested for six hours, Mr. Fogg and his party had time to pay a visit to Salt Lake City, connected with Ogden by a branch road; and they spent two hours in this strikingly American town, built on the pattern of other cities of the Union, like a checker-board, “with the sombre sadness of right-angles,” as Victor Hugo expresses it. The streets were wide, and the houses low, and the city was surrounded by a garden-like country, with fields of wheat, corn, and other cereals. The principal buildings were the temple, dedicated to the worship of the Lord, the prophet’s mansion, and the arsenal; others were the city hall, the courthouse, and the schoolhouse. The houses were mostly built of blue brick, with verandas and gardens, surrounded by palisades. The streets were almost deserted, except in the vicinity of the temple, where a large number of women could be seen. It was the hour of service, and these women were coming out of the sacred edifice. They were dressed in plain, homely attire, and some wore the costume of the aborigines. Passepartout could not behold without a certain fright these women, charged, in groups, with the care of a single husband. It seemed to him that he could see them, in the future, in the midst of the desert, with their husbands, in the pursuit of the promised land. Passepartout was not, however, inclined to judge the Mormons harshly. He thought that the sectarians were not so much to be blamed as the laws of the United States, which permitted such practices. Besides, he was not sorry to have seen the city, as he had heard much of it, and he was glad to have had the opportunity of visiting it. Mr. Fogg and his companions returned to the station at five o’clock, and resumed their journey.

events.title: Passepartout Reflects on Polygamy and Departs
detailed_summary: Passepartout felt a sense of fear observing the groups of women assigned to make one Mormon man happy.
His common sense led him to pity the husband most of all.
He considered the task of managing numerous wives through life and leading them collectively to the Mormon afterlife, alongside Joseph Smith, to be daunting.
The entire concept repelled him strongly.
He imagined, perhaps incorrectly, that some of the women in Salt Lake City were looking at him in an alarming way.
Fortunately for his peace of mind, their visit to the city was short.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout could not behold without a certain fright these women, charged, in groups, with conferring happiness on a single Mormon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Happily, his stay there was but brief.

events.text_segment: Passepartout could not behold without a certain fright these women, charged, in groups, with conferring happiness on a single Mormon. His common sense pitied, above all, the husband. It seemed to him a terrible thing to have to guide so many wives at once across the vicissitudes of life, and to conduct them, as it were, in a body to the Mormon paradise with the prospect of seeing them in the company of the glorious Smith, who doubtless was the chief ornament of that delightful place, to all eternity. He felt decidedly repelled from such a vocation, and he imagined—perhaps he was mistaken—that the fair ones of Salt Lake City cast rather alarming glances on his person. Happily, his stay there was but brief.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Their appearance, however, was not calculated to reassure him. They were women of various ages, from the young and fresh-faced to the older and more matronly, all dressed in a manner that seemed both modest and peculiar to his European eyes. Their expressions ranged from serene acceptance to a kind of resigned melancholy, as if they had long since come to terms with their unusual marital arrangements.

Passepartout, with his natural curiosity and open-mindedness, tried to understand the dynamics of such a society, but he could not help but feel a sense of unease. The idea of sharing a husband with so many others was foreign to him, and he wondered how such a system could truly bring happiness to all involved.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Passepartout could not behold without a certain fright these women, charged, in groups, with conferring happiness on a single Mormon. His common sense pitied above all the husband. It seemed to him a terrible thing to have to guide so many wives at once across the vicissitudes of life, and to conduct them, as it were, in a body to the Mormon paradise with the prospect of seeing them in the company of the glorious Smith, who doubtless was the chief ornament of that delightful place, to all eternity. He felt decidedly repelled by the idea of it. He imagined, perhaps mistakenly, that the fair ones of Salt Lake City cast rather alarming glances on his person. Happily, his stay there was but brief; and at half-past six in the evening, the "Henrietta" passed the promontory of the Great Salt Lake, and the city was soon lost to view behind the rocks.

events.title: A Belated Passenger and a Surprising Revelation
detailed_summary: By 4 PM, the group was back at the Ogden station and boarded the train.
As the train began to move, shouts of 'Stop!' were heard.
A Mormon man, clearly late, was seen running breathlessly.
Since the station lacked barriers, he ran along the track, managed to jump onto the rear platform, and collapsed into a seat, exhausted.
Passepartout had watched the man's frantic effort with keen interest.
He approached the man and learned that he had fled his home after a domestic argument.
Once the man regained his composure, Passepartout politely inquired about the number of wives he had, speculating it might be twenty given his desperate escape.
The Mormon, looking towards the sky, replied he had only one wife, emphatically stating that one was sufficient trouble.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At four the party found themselves again at the station, took their places in the train, and the whistle sounded for starting.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “One, sir,” replied the Mormon, raising his arms heavenward —“one, and that was enough!”

events.text_segment:
At four the party found themselves again at the station, took their places in the train, and the whistle sounded for starting. Just at the moment, however, that the locomotive wheels began to move, cries of “Stop! stop!” were heard.
Trains, like time and tide, stop for no one. The gentleman who uttered the cries was evidently a belated Mormon. He was breathless with running. Happily for him, the station had neither gates nor barriers. He rushed along the track, jumped on the rear platform of the train, and fell, exhausted, into one of the seats.
Passepartout, who had been anxiously watching this amateur gymnast, approached him with lively interest, and learned that he had taken flight after an unpleasant domestic scene.
When the Mormon had recovered his breath, Passepartout ventured to ask him politely how many wives he had; for, from the manner in which he had decamped, it might be thought that he had twenty at least.
“One, sir,” replied the Mormon, raising his arms heavenward —“one, and that was enough!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The journey was to continue, and Phileas Fogg, with his usual composure, settled into his seat, his eyes fixed on the horizon as if calculating the miles yet to be traversed. Passepartout, ever the attentive servant, ensured that their luggage was securely stowed and that his master had everything he might need for the journey ahead.

Aouda, seated beside Fogg, gazed out of the window, her thoughts a mixture of excitement and apprehension. The landscapes they passed were a blur of colors and shapes, each new scene a testament to the vastness of the world they were circumnavigating.

Detective Fix, still shadowing the group, took his place in a nearby carriage, his mind occupied with thoughts of his mission. He was determined to see Fogg brought to justice, convinced of his guilt in the robbery that had set this entire adventure in motion.

As the train chugged forward, the rhythmic clatter of the wheels on the tracks seemed to echo the ticking of a clock, a reminder of the relentless passage of time. Every mile brought them closer to their destination, and every moment was a step further in their race against the calendar. The journey was far from over, and the challenges yet to come were as unpredictable as the path they traveled.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At four the party found themselves again at the station, took their places in the train, and the whistle sounded for starting. Just at the moment, however, that the locomotive wheels began to move, cries of "Stop! stop!" were heard. A young man, carrying a travelling bag, rushed along the platform at full speed. He was evidently a Mormon, and was about to miss the train, which would have been an unpardonable offence on his part. He ran like a madman, and, happily for him, the station had neither gates nor barriers. He sprang upon the rear platform of the train, and fell, exhausted, into one of the seats. Passepartout, who had been anxiously watching this amateur gymnast, approached him with lively interest, and learned that he had taken flight after an unpleasant domestic scene. When the Mormon had recovered his breath, Passepartout ventured to ask him politely how many wives he had; for, from the manner in which he had decamped, it might be thought that he had twenty at least. "One, sir," replied the Mormon, raising his arms heavenward—"one, and that was enough!"

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXVIII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT DOES NOT SUCCEED IN MAKING ANYBODY LISTEN TO REASON

events.title: Traversing the Mountainous West
detailed_summary: The train journey proceeds north from Ogden before turning east into the challenging Wahsatch Mountains.
This section of the track presented significant engineering obstacles, warranting a much higher government subsidy compared to the plains.
Engineers prioritized navigating around natural barriers rather than blasting through them, requiring only one substantial tunnel to reach the great basin.
The railway line had peaked in elevation at Great Salt Lake and subsequently descended and ascended again towards the continental divide.
The mountainous terrain featured numerous creeks, necessitating the construction of culverts for crossings.
Passepartout's impatience mounted during this leg of the journey.
Fix shared a sense of urgency, eager to leave the difficult terrain behind and reach England without delays, his anxiety seemingly surpassing even Fogg's.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train, on leaving Great Salt Lake at Ogden, passed northward for an hour as far as Weber River, having completed nearly nine hundred miles from San Francisco.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout grew more and more impatient as they went on, while Fix longed to get out of this difficult region, and was more anxious than Phileas Fogg himself to be beyond the danger of delays and accidents, and set foot on English soil.

events.text_segment:
The train, on leaving Great Salt Lake at Ogden, passed northward for an hour as far as Weber River, having completed nearly nine hundred miles from San Francisco. From this point it took an easterly direction towards the jagged Wahsatch Mountains. It was in the section included between this range and the Rocky Mountains that the American engineers found the most formidable difficulties in laying the road, and that the government granted a subsidy of forty-eight thousand dollars per mile, instead of sixteen thousand allowed for the work done on the plains. But the engineers, instead of violating nature, avoided its difficulties by winding around, instead of penetrating the rocks. One tunnel only, fourteen thousand feet in length, was pierced in order to arrive at the great basin.
The track up to this time had reached its highest elevation at the Great Salt Lake. From this point it described a long curve, descending towards Bitter Creek Valley, to rise again to the dividing ridge of the waters between the Atlantic and the Pacific. There were many creeks in this mountainous region, and it was necessary to cross Muddy Creek, Green Creek, and others, upon culverts.
Passepartout grew more and more impatient as they went on, while Fix longed to get out of this difficult region, and was more anxious than Phileas Fogg himself to be beyond the danger of delays and accidents, and set foot on English soil.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
From this point it took a more easterly direction, and reached the charming valley of the Great Salt Lake. The railway line followed the southern shore of the lake, and the level of the track, rising gradually, reached an elevation of nine hundred and forty-two feet above the sea. The country was covered with vast expanses of salt, and the air was filled with a saline odor, which was not particularly agreeable.

The train continued its journey, passing through the towns of Ogden and Brigham City, and then entered the territory of Wyoming. The landscape changed as the train moved further east, with the salt flats giving way to rolling hills and rugged terrain. The passengers on board, including Phileas Fogg and his companions, were treated to breathtaking views of the American West, with its vast open spaces and dramatic scenery.

As the train sped along, the passengers settled into their routines, some reading, others conversing, and a few simply gazing out the windows at the passing landscape. The journey was long, but the promise of adventure and the thrill of the unknown kept their spirits high. Phileas Fogg, ever the picture of calm and composure, remained focused on his goal of circumnavigating the globe in eighty days, confident that he would succeed.

Passepartout grew more and more impatient as they went on, while Fix longed to get out of this difficult region, and was more anxious than Phileas Fogg himself to be beyond the danger of delays and accidents, and reach England as quickly as possible.

events.title: Aouda Spots Colonel Proctor
detailed_summary: The train made stops at Fort Bridger and later Green River station in Wyoming Territory.
Snowfall mixed with rain had occurred but didn't impede the train's progress.
Passepartout worried about the potential impact of worsening weather on Fogg's schedule, questioning the wisdom of winter travel.
While Passepartout focused on the weather, Aouda experienced anxiety from a different source.
During the stop at Green River, Aouda saw Colonel Stamp Proctor, the man who had insulted Fogg in San Francisco, among the passengers on the platform.
Deeply alarmed, she quickly moved away from the window to avoid recognition.
Her strong feelings for Fogg, characterized by his unwavering, albeit undemonstrative, devotion, intensified her fear.
She internally grappled with the nature of her feelings for Fogg, recognizing them potentially transcending gratitude.
The sight of Proctor, whom Fogg intended to confront eventually, caused her great distress.
She understood Proctor's presence was accidental but posed a grave threat if Fogg were to see him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At ten o’clock at night the train stopped at Fort Bridger station, and twenty minutes later entered Wyoming Territory, following the valley of Bitter Creek throughout.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Chance alone, it was clear, had brought Colonel Proctor on this train; but there he was, and it was necessary, at all hazards, that Phileas Fogg should not perceive his adversary.

events.text_segment:
At ten o’clock at night the train stopped at Fort Bridger station, and twenty minutes later entered Wyoming Territory, following the valley of Bitter Creek throughout. The next day, 7th December, they stopped for a quarter of an hour at Green River station. Snow had fallen abundantly during the night, but, being mixed with rain, it had half melted, and did not interrupt their progress. The bad weather, however, annoyed Passepartout; for the accumulation of snow, by blocking the wheels of the cars, would certainly have been fatal to Mr. Fogg’s tour.
“What an idea!” he said to himself. “Why did my master make this journey in winter? Couldn’t he have waited for the good season to increase his chances?”
While the worthy Frenchman was absorbed in the state of the sky and the depression of the temperature, Aouda was experiencing fears from a totally different cause.
Several passengers had got off at Green River, and were walking up and down the platforms; and among these Aouda recognised Colonel Stamp Proctor, the same who had so grossly insulted Phileas Fogg at the San Francisco meeting. Not wishing to be recognised, the young woman drew back from the window, feeling much alarm at her discovery. She was attached to the man who, however coldly, gave her daily evidences of the most absolute devotion. She did not comprehend, perhaps, the depth of the sentiment with which her protector inspired her, which she called gratitude, but which, though she was unconscious of it, was really more than that. Her heart sank within her when she recognised the man whom Mr. Fogg desired, sooner or later, to call to account for his conduct. Chance alone, it was clear, had brought Colonel Proctor on this train; but there he was, and it was necessary, at all hazards, that Phileas Fogg should not perceive his adversary.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The landscape was stark and rugged, with the vast, open plains stretching out under the moonlit sky. The passengers, weary from their long journey, settled into their seats, some dozing off while others gazed out the windows at the passing scenery.

Phileas Fogg, ever composed and unflappable, sat quietly in his seat, his eyes occasionally flicking to his pocket watch. He was a man of precision, and every minute counted in his quest to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days. His companion, Passepartout, was less composed, fidgeting slightly as he tried to find a comfortable position.

The train chugged steadily onward, the rhythmic clatter of the wheels on the tracks a constant backdrop to the night. As they moved deeper into Wyoming, the terrain began to change, with the plains giving way to rolling hills and distant mountain ranges.

The passengers were a diverse group, a mix of businessmen, adventurers, and families, each with their own reasons for making the journey westward. Conversations were muted, the late hour and the gentle rocking of the train lulling many into a state of quiet reflection.

As the train continued its journey, the conductor made his way through the carriages, checking tickets and ensuring all was in order. He paused briefly by Fogg and Passepartout, nodding politely before moving on.

Outside, the night was clear and crisp, the stars twinkling brightly in the vast expanse of the sky. The train pressed on, a lone beacon of light and motion in the otherwise still and silent landscape.

For Fogg, the journey was a test of endurance and resolve, each mile bringing him closer to his goal. He remained focused, his mind calculating the time and distance yet to be covered, confident in his ability to meet the challenge he had set for himself.

events.title: Conspiracy to Prevent a Confrontation
detailed_summary: Taking advantage of Fogg's nap, Aouda informed Fix and Passepartout about Colonel Proctor's presence on the train.
Fix reacted vehemently, declaring that Proctor would have to contend with him before settling matters with Fogg, as Fix felt more insulted.
Passepartout also volunteered to confront the colonel himself.
Aouda firmly stated that Fogg would insist on handling the matter personally and intended to seek Proctor out upon returning to America.
She emphasized the absolute necessity of keeping Fogg unaware of Proctor's presence to avert a potentially disastrous encounter.
Fix concurred, acknowledging that any confrontation, win or lose, would cause delays harmful to Fogg's tight schedule.
Passepartout pointed out that such a delay would directly benefit Fogg's opponents at the Reform Club.

They collectively decided that the best course of action was to ensure Fogg remained inside their train car for the next four days until reaching New York, thereby minimizing the chance of an encounter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda seized a moment when Mr. Fogg was asleep to tell Fix and Passepartout whom she had seen.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We must, if possible, prevent his stirring out of it.”

events.text_segment:
Aouda seized a moment when Mr. Fogg was asleep to tell Fix and Passepartout whom she had seen.
“That Proctor on this train!” cried Fix. “Well, reassure yourself, madam; before he settles with Mr. Fogg; he has got to deal with me! It seems to me that I was the more insulted of the two.”
“And, besides,” added Passepartout, “I’ll take charge of him, colonel as he is.”
“Mr. Fix,” resumed Aouda, “Mr. Fogg will allow no one to avenge him. He said that he would come back to America to find this man. Should he perceive Colonel Proctor, we could not prevent a collision which might have terrible results. He must not see him.”
“You are right, madam,” replied Fix; “a meeting between them might ruin all. Whether he were victorious or beaten, Mr. Fogg would be delayed, and—”
“And,” added Passepartout, “that would play the game of the gentlemen of the Reform Club. In four days we shall be in New York. Well, if my master does not leave this car during those four days, we may hope that chance will not bring him face to face with this confounded American. We must, if possible, prevent his stirring out of it.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
She described a man she recognized from her past, someone she had encountered during her time in India. Aouda was visibly shaken as she recounted the details, her voice barely above a whisper to avoid waking Mr. Fogg.

"I am certain it was him," she insisted, her eyes wide with a mix of fear and disbelief. "He was a merchant, a man of considerable influence in Bombay. I never thought I would see him again, especially not here."

Fix listened intently, his mind racing with the implications of Aouda's revelation. He knew that any unexpected encounter could potentially disrupt their journey, and he was already on edge due to his own secret mission.

Passepartout, on the other hand, was more concerned about Aouda's well-being. "Madame, are you sure?" he asked gently, trying to reassure her. "Perhaps it was someone who merely resembled him."

Aouda shook her head, her conviction unwavering. "No, it was him. I would recognize that face anywhere."

The conversation left Fix and Passepartout with a sense of unease, knowing that this unexpected encounter could have unforeseen consequences for their journey around the world.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Aouda seized a moment when Mr. Fogg was asleep to tell Fix and Passepartout whom she had seen. "Colonel Proctor on this train!" cried Fix. "Well, Mr. Fogg shall not meet him. If he does, we shall have a scene."

"Proctor is a man of the last century, and he will fight," said Passepartout.

"He will fight," replied Fix, "and Mr. Fogg will not be able to avoid a duel."

"We must prevent it," said Aouda. "Mr. Fogg will not allow himself to be insulted. He will not permit—"

"He will not permit it," said Fix, "and if he fights, he will be delayed, and that will be fatal to his journey."

"We must keep Mr. Fogg in ignorance of this," said Passepartout. "He must not know that Proctor is on board."

"You are right," said Fix. "A delay would ruin everything."

"And it would be to the advantage of his enemies at the Reform Club," added Passepartout.

"We must keep him in the car," said Aouda, "and not let him leave it until we reach New York."

events.title: The Whist Game Diversion
detailed_summary: Their discussion ceased as Fogg awoke and glanced out the window.
Passepartout quietly asked Fix if his offer to fight for Fogg was genuine.
Fix responded with determination, stating he would do whatever it took to get Fogg back to Europe alive, which slightly unnerved Passepartout, though his loyalty to Fogg didn't waver.
The challenge became finding a way to keep Fogg, who was naturally disinclined to move about, confined to the car.
Fix devised a plan, suggesting a game of whist to occupy Fogg, reminding him of his pastime on ships.
Fogg lamented the lack of cards and fellow players.
Fix countered that cards were readily available on American trains and proposed Aouda might join.
Aouda affirmed her knowledge of whist as part of a standard English upbringing.
Fix offered himself as the third player, completing the table with a theoretical fourth player (dummy).
Fogg happily accepted, glad for the chance to play his preferred game.
Passepartout procured cards, scoring materials, and a playing surface.
The game commenced; Aouda played proficiently, earning Fogg's praise, while Fix demonstrated considerable skill, proving a worthy opponent.
Passepartout felt relief, believing Fogg was now safely engrossed and unlikely to leave the compartment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The conversation dropped.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Now,” thought Passepartout, “we’ve got him. He won’t budge.”

events.text_segment:
The conversation dropped. Mr. Fogg had just woke up, and was looking out of the window. Soon after Passepartout, without being heard by his master or Aouda, whispered to the detective, “Would you really fight for him?”
“I would do anything,” replied Fix, in a tone which betrayed determined will, “to get him back living to Europe!”
Passepartout felt something like a shudder shoot through his frame, but his confidence in his master remained unbroken.
Was there any means of detaining Mr. Fogg in the car, to avoid a meeting between him and the colonel? It ought not to be a difficult task, since that gentleman was naturally sedentary and little curious. The detective, at least, seemed to have found a way; for, after a few moments, he said to Mr. Fogg, “These are long and slow hours, sir, that we are passing on the railway.”
“Yes,” replied Mr. Fogg; “but they pass.”
“You were in the habit of playing whist,” resumed Fix, “on the steamers.”
“Yes; but it would be difficult to do so here. I have neither cards nor partners.”
“Oh, but we can easily buy some cards, for they are sold on all the American trains. And as for partners, if madam plays—”
“Certainly, sir,” Aouda quickly replied; “I understand whist. It is part of an English education.”
“I myself have some pretensions to playing a good game. Well, here are three of us, and a dummy—”
“As you please, sir,” replied Phileas Fogg, heartily glad to resume his favourite pastime even on the railway.
Passepartout was dispatched in search of the steward, and soon returned with two packs of cards, some pins, counters, and a shelf covered with cloth.
The game commenced. Aouda understood whist sufficiently well, and even received some compliments on her playing from Mr. Fogg. As for the detective, he was simply an adept, and worthy of being matched against his present opponent.
“Now,” thought Passepartout, “we’ve got him. He won’t budge.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Mr. Fogg had gone to sleep. He was sleeping quietly, but Passepartout was unable to close his eyes for a moment. He kept thinking of the strange adventure in which he had embarked, and of the consequences which it might have for him. He was worried about the money he had left behind in London, and about the possibility of being dismissed by Mr. Fogg if anything went wrong.

The train sped on through the night, and Passepartout could hear the rhythmic clatter of the wheels on the tracks. He tried to calm his mind by focusing on the sound, but his thoughts kept returning to the events of the day. He thought about the bet that Mr. Fogg had made, and the incredible journey they were undertaking. He wondered if they would really be able to make it around the world in eighty days.

As the train continued its journey, Passepartout's thoughts turned to the people they had met along the way. He thought about the detective, Fix, who seemed to be following them, and he wondered what his true intentions were. He also thought about the kind people they had encountered, and the different cultures they had experienced.

Despite his worries, Passepartout felt a sense of excitement about the adventure. He had never imagined that he would have the opportunity to travel the world, and he was determined to make the most of it. He resolved to do everything he could to help Mr. Fogg win the bet, and to ensure that their journey was a success.

As the night wore on, Passepartout finally began to feel drowsy. He closed his eyes and let the sound of the train lull him to sleep. He dreamed of far-off lands and exciting adventures, and he awoke the next morning feeling refreshed and ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

Mr. Fogg replied that he was quite well, and that he hoped to reach New York in time to catch the steamer for Liverpool. Passepartout then asked Fix if he was still determined to arrest Mr. Fogg. Fix replied that he was, but that he would do nothing to prevent Mr. Fogg from reaching Europe. Passepartout was reassured by this, and he resolved to keep a close watch on Fix. Meanwhile, Fix was thinking of a way to keep Mr. Fogg occupied, so that he would not leave the train. He suggested a game of whist, which Mr. Fogg accepted with pleasure. Aouda, who had learned the game in England, agreed to join them, and Fix offered to be the third player. Passepartout procured a pack of cards, and the game began. Mr. Fogg played with his usual skill, and Aouda proved to be a worthy opponent. Fix, too, played well, and the game was closely contested. Passepartout watched the game with satisfaction, feeling that Mr. Fogg was now safely occupied and unlikely to leave the train.

events.title: Crossing the Continental Divide
detailed_summary: Around 11:00 AM, the train summited Bridger Pass, marking the highest elevation reached on its Rocky Mountain crossing.
After covering approximately two hundred more miles, the train emerged onto the vast plains stretching towards the Atlantic Ocean.
This terrain was described as naturally suited for railway construction.
The initial streams flowing towards the Atlantic basin, tributaries of the North Platte River, became visible.
The distant northern and eastern horizons were dominated by the sweeping curve of the southern Rocky Mountains, notably Laramie Peak.
Expansive, well-watered plains separated the railway from these mountains.
To the south (right side of the train), the lower ranges extended towards the headwaters of the Arkansas River.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At eleven in the morning the train had reached the dividing ridge of the waters at Bridger Pass, seven thousand five hundred and twenty-four feet above the level of the sea, one of the highest points attained by the track in crossing the Rocky Mountains.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On the right rose the lower spurs of the mountainous mass which extends southward to the sources of the Arkansas River, one of the great tributaries of the Missouri.

events.text_segment:
At eleven in the morning the train had reached the dividing ridge of the waters at Bridger Pass, seven thousand five hundred and twenty-four feet above the level of the sea, one of the highest points attained by the track in crossing the Rocky Mountains. After going about two hundred miles, the travellers at last found themselves on one of those vast plains which extend to the Atlantic, and which nature has made so propitious for laying the iron road.
On the declivity of the Atlantic basin the first streams, branches of the North Platte River, already appeared. The whole northern and eastern horizon was bounded by the immense semi-circular curtain which is formed by the southern portion of the Rocky Mountains, the highest being Laramie Peak. Between this and the railway extended vast plains, plentifully irrigated. On the right rose the lower spurs of the mountainous mass which extends southward to the sources of the Arkansas River, one of the great tributaries of the Missouri.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
After passing this point, the train began its descent towards the Atlantic by way of Cheyenne, where it arrived at noon. Here a delay of twenty minutes occurred, during which the locomotive was inspected and the passengers had a chance to stretch their legs. The station was bustling with activity, as Cheyenne was a key junction for travelers heading in various directions.

Phileas Fogg, ever punctual and composed, took the opportunity to check his watch and ensure that their schedule was still on track. Passepartout, his loyal servant, used the time to procure some refreshments for the journey ahead. The air was crisp and invigorating, a stark contrast to the bustling cities they had left behind, and the passengers eagerly anticipated the next leg of their adventure.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At eleven in the morning the train had reached the dividing ridge of the waters at Bridger Pass, seven thousand five hundred and twenty-four feet above the level of the sea, one of the highest points attained by the track in crossing the Rocky Mountains. After leaving this point, the train, having passed the highest point, descended towards the Atlantic basin, and at a distance of two hundred miles from this point, the travelers found themselves on one of those vast plains which extend to the Atlantic, and which nature has made so propitious for laying the iron road. On the right rose the first streams of the great tributary of the North Platte River. The whole northern and eastern horizon was bounded by the immense semicircular curtain of the southern Rocky Mountains, which extended from north to south, and which the train was now approaching in a direct line. The highest point of this semicircle was marked by Laramie Peak, which was more than ten thousand feet above the level of the sea. The plains were covered with verdure, and the train rolled easily along, furnishing a view of the distant mountains, which were separated from the railway by a vast extent of prairie. To the south, the lower spurs of the mountains stretched away towards the sources of the Arkansas River, one of the great tributaries of the Missouri.

events.title: The Unsafe Bridge at Medicine Bow
detailed_summary: By 12:30 PM, the sight of Fort Halleck indicated the Rocky Mountains had been successfully traversed.
A sense of relief emerged, hoping the journey through this challenging section was complete without mishaps, especially as the snow had stopped.
The air grew colder and clearer; the landscape was described as a vast, empty desert, disturbed only by birds startled by the train.
Following a comfortable breakfast served in the train car, Fogg, Aouda, and Fix had just restarted their whist game.
Suddenly, a sharp whistle sounded, and the train came to an unexpected halt.
Passepartout looked out but could see no station or obvious reason for the stop.
Aouda and Fix grew anxious that Fogg might decide to investigate, but he merely instructed Passepartout to ascertain the problem.
Passepartout hurried out, finding that about thirty to forty passengers, including Colonel Proctor, had already disembarked.
The train was stopped before a red signal light blocking the track.
The engineer and conductor were engaged in a heated discussion with a signal-man sent from the next station, Medicine Bow.
Other passengers gathered around, with Colonel Proctor participating actively and rudely.
Passepartout joined the group and overheard the signal-man declare that the train could not proceed because the bridge at Medicine Bow was structurally unsound and unsafe for the train's weight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At half-past twelve the travellers caught sight for an instant of Fort Halleck, which commands that section; and in a few more hours the Rocky Mountains were crossed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The bridge at Medicine Bow is shaky, and would not bear the weight of the train.”

events.text_segment:
At half-past twelve the travellers caught sight for an instant of Fort Halleck, which commands that section; and in a few more hours the Rocky Mountains were crossed. There was reason to hope, then, that no accident would mark the journey through this difficult country. The snow had ceased falling, and the air became crisp and cold. Large birds, frightened by the locomotive, rose and flew off in the distance. No wild beast appeared on the plain. It was a desert in its vast nakedness.
After a comfortable breakfast, served in the car, Mr. Fogg and his partners had just resumed whist, when a violent whistling was heard, and the train stopped. Passepartout put his head out of the door, but saw nothing to cause the delay; no station was in view.
Aouda and Fix feared that Mr. Fogg might take it into his head to get out; but that gentleman contented himself with saying to his servant, “See what is the matter.”
Passepartout rushed out of the car. Thirty or forty passengers had already descended, amongst them Colonel Stamp Proctor.
The train had stopped before a red signal which blocked the way. The engineer and conductor were talking excitedly with a signal-man, whom the station-master at Medicine Bow, the next stopping place, had sent on before. The passengers drew around and took part in the discussion, in which Colonel Proctor, with his insolent manner, was conspicuous.
Passepartout, joining the group, heard the signal-man say, “No! you can’t pass. The bridge at Medicine Bow is shaky, and would not bear the weight of the train.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
There was reason to hope, then, that no accident would mark the journey through this difficult country. The snow had ceased falling, and the air became crisp and cold. Large birds, frightened by the locomotive, rose and flew off in the distance. No wild beast appeared on the plain. It was a desert in its vast nakedness. After a comfortable breakfast, served in the car, Mr. Fogg and his companions had time to take a survey of the country through which the train was passing.

The great plains of the United States, the vast expanse of territory which extends from the Mississippi to the Rocky Mountains, have no equal in the world. They are covered with wild grasses, and are only inhabited by wild animals. The train entered the great basin, and the forty-fifth parallel was reached. This was the highest point of the journey, and the train began to descend towards the Pacific, over vast plains, with but few trees, and here and there a few streams, and lakes, and ponds. The train rolled on, and soon the mountains were left behind. The passengers could now see the great Salt Lake, and the Mormon capital, Ogden, was reached at two o'clock.

The train stopped for a few minutes, and Passepartout was able to purchase some provisions. The journey was resumed, and the train soon reached the Great Salt Lake, which is about seventy miles long and thirty-five wide. The lake is surrounded by mountains, and its waters are very salty.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At half-past twelve the travellers caught sight for an instant of Fort Halleck, which commands that section; and in a few more hours the Rocky Mountains were crossed. There was reason to hope, then, that no accident would mark the journey through this difficult country. The snow had ceased falling, and the air became crisp and cold. Large birds, frightened by the locomotive, rose and flew off in the distance. No human being could be seen. Passepartout, with his eyes wide open, stared at the wild landscape, and Aouda and Fix chatted about the probable chances of success in their journey. The train sped on with great speed, and soon they reached the station of Medicine Bow. But there was no stop. The train passed on at full speed. The passengers could not see the station, nor the bridge, which was said to be dangerous. But the train did not stop. It was a moment of anxiety, and Passepartout was on the point of jumping off the train, when he was stopped by Phileas Fogg, who said, "We shall stop at the next station." Passepartout obeyed, and the train continued its course. The passengers were reassured, and the train sped on. But suddenly, at a sharp whistle, the train stopped. Passepartout, who had been watching the landscape, was startled. He looked out, but could see no station, and he was about to ask the reason of the stop, when he saw the conductor and the engineer running towards the front of the train. He followed them, and found that the train had stopped before a red signal which blocked the line. The engineer and the conductor were talking excitedly with a signal-man, who had come from the station at Medicine Bow. The passengers gathered around and listened to the conversation. Colonel Proctor, one of the passengers, was particularly active in the discussion, and Passepartout, who was anxious to know what was going on, joined the group. He heard the signal-man say, "The bridge at Medicine Bow is not safe, and the train cannot pass over it."

events.title: The Engineer's Dangerous Proposal
detailed_summary: The problematic structure was identified as a suspension bridge spanning rapids, located roughly a mile ahead.
The signal-man reiterated its dilapidated state, citing broken iron wires that made crossing extremely hazardous.
The text notes that American prudence, being rare, usually signifies genuine cause for concern.
Passepartout listened, paralyzed with tension, reluctant to inform his master of this new delay.
Colonel Proctor belligerently demanded to know if they were simply expected to remain stranded in the snow.
The conductor reported that a replacement train had been summoned from Omaha but wasn't expected for at least six hours.
Passepartout reacted with dismay to the lengthy delay.
The conductor further clarified that walking to Medicine Bow station would also take about six hours.
When a passenger noted the station was only a mile away, the conductor explained it was inaccessible due to being on the opposite side of the river.
Proctor inquired about using a boat, but the conductor dismissed this, explaining the creek was dangerously swollen and rapid, necessitating a ten-mile detour to find a safe crossing point (ford).
Enraged, Proctor swore at the railway company and conductor; Passepartout, equally furious, felt a moment of solidarity, realizing money couldn't solve this problem.
Widespread disappointment arose among passengers facing the prospect of a fifteen-mile walk through snow; their complaints didn't disturb the engrossed Fogg.
Just as Passepartout resolved to tell Fogg the bad news, the train's engineer, Forster, interjected, proposing a potential, alternative way to get across.
When questioned, Forster confirmed he meant crossing the damaged bridge itself, using their current train.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This was a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids, about a mile from the place where they now were.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “With our train.”

events.text_segment:
This was a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids, about a mile from the place where they now were. According to the signal-man, it was in a ruinous condition, several of the iron wires being broken; and it was impossible to risk the passage. He did not in any way exaggerate the condition of the bridge. It may be taken for granted that, rash as the Americans usually are, when they are prudent there is good reason for it.
Passepartout, not daring to apprise his master of what he heard, listened with set teeth, immovable as a statue.
“Hum!” cried Colonel Proctor; “but we are not going to stay here, I imagine, and take root in the snow?”
“Colonel,” replied the conductor, “we have telegraphed to Omaha for a train, but it is not likely that it will reach Medicine Bow in less than six hours.”
“Six hours!” cried Passepartout.
“Certainly,” returned the conductor, “besides, it will take us as long as that to reach Medicine Bow on foot.”
“But it is only a mile from here,” said one of the passengers.
“Yes, but it’s on the other side of the river.”
“And can’t we cross that in a boat?” asked the colonel.
“That’s impossible. The creek is swelled by the rains. It is a rapid, and we shall have to make a circuit of ten miles to the north to find a ford.”
The colonel launched a volley of oaths, denouncing the railway company and the conductor; and Passepartout, who was furious, was not disinclined to make common cause with him. Here was an obstacle, indeed, which all his master’s banknotes could not remove.
There was a general disappointment among the passengers, who, without reckoning the delay, saw themselves compelled to trudge fifteen miles over a plain covered with snow. They grumbled and protested, and would certainly have thus attracted Phileas Fogg’s attention if he had not been completely absorbed in his game.
Passepartout found that he could not avoid telling his master what had occurred, and, with hanging head, he was turning towards the car, when the engineer, a true Yankee, named Forster called out, “Gentlemen, perhaps there is a way, after all, to get over.”
“On the bridge?” asked a passenger.
“On the bridge.”
“With our train?”
“With our train.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The bridge was a crucial part of the railway line, connecting two sections of the track that were otherwise separated by the tumultuous waters below. It was a marvel of engineering, designed to withstand the forces of nature and the weight of the trains that passed over it daily.

As Phileas Fogg and his companions approached the bridge, they could hear the roar of the rapids beneath them, a constant reminder of the power of the river. The bridge itself was a lattice of iron and steel, its intricate design both functional and beautiful. It stretched across the chasm with a grace that belied its strength, a testament to the ingenuity of its builders.

The train slowed as it neared the bridge, the conductor taking no chances with the precious cargo of passengers and goods. The wheels clattered over the tracks, the sound echoing off the walls of the gorge. For a moment, it seemed as though the train was suspended in mid-air, the bridge the only thing keeping it from plunging into the depths below.

Phileas Fogg, ever the picture of calm, gazed out the window at the rushing water. He was a man of precision and order, and the sight of the bridge, with its perfect symmetry and flawless construction, pleased him. It was a reminder that even in the wildest parts of the world, human ingenuity could triumph over nature.

As the train reached the other side of the bridge, the passengers let out a collective sigh of relief. The danger had passed, and they were once again on solid ground. The journey continued, the train picking up speed as it raced towards its next destination.

For Phileas Fogg, the crossing of the bridge was just another step in his journey around the world. He was a man on a mission, determined to complete his journey in eighty days, no matter the obstacles in his path. The bridge, with its strength and beauty, was a symbol of the challenges he faced and the determination he needed to overcome them. It was a reminder that, with perseverance and ingenuity, anything was possible.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: This was a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids, about a mile from the place where they now were. The signal-man went on to explain that the bridge was in a very bad condition, and that some of the iron wires were broken, which made it extremely dangerous to pass over. He added that, in all probability, the train would not be able to reach Medicine Bow without some delay. The signal-man was not mistaken in his opinion. The passengers were informed of the situation, and the conductor added that a train from Omaha would not arrive for at least six hours, and that the best course of action would be to wait for it. Passepartout was in despair, but he did not dare to tell his master. Colonel Proctor, however, was furious, and he demanded to know if they were to remain there in the snow. The conductor explained that it would take six hours to walk to Medicine Bow, and that the station was on the other side of the river, which was swollen and rapid. Proctor suggested taking a boat, but the conductor replied that it would be necessary to make a ten-mile detour to find a ford. Proctor swore at the railway company and the conductor, and Passepartout felt a moment of solidarity with him, realizing that money could not solve this problem. The passengers were disappointed, but Phileas Fogg remained calm. Just as Passepartout was about to inform Fogg of the situation, the engineer, Forster, proposed a solution: to cross the bridge with the train itself.

events.title: Recklessness vs. Caution
detailed_summary: Passepartout paid close attention to the engineer's unfolding idea.
The conductor stressed the bridge's precarious condition.
Forster brushed off the warning, theorizing that reaching maximum speed might allow the train to clear the bridge before it failed.
Passepartout mentally exclaimed in disbelief at the sheer risk.
However, the engineer's audacious proposal quickly gained support among passengers, especially Colonel Proctor, who found it highly appealing.
Proctor recounted tales of engineers making similar leaps over rivers.
Passenger sentiment shifted towards accepting the gamble, with estimates of success ranging wildly.
Passepartout, despite his desire to continue the journey, considered the plan excessively risky, labeling it 'too American'.
He felt a simpler, safer method was being ignored.
He tried voicing his concerns to fellow passengers, suggesting the engineer's plan was dangerous.
One passenger rebuffed him, focusing on the optimistic odds.
Another dismissed the need for alternative ideas since the engineer vouched for his plan.
Passepartout attempted to advocate for prudence.
This term enraged Colonel Proctor, who insisted on 'full speed'.
Passepartout tried rephrasing, suggesting a 'more natural' approach, not necessarily 'prudent'.
His attempts at discussion were met with confusion and hostility.
Proctor challenged Passepartout, asking if he was scared.
Provoked, Passepartout declared he would prove a Frenchman could match their recklessness.
The conductor then ordered everyone back onto the train.
Passepartout boarded, privately maintaining his belief that the logical solution was for passengers to cross on foot, followed by the empty train.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout stopped short, and eagerly listened to the engineer.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “But they can’t prevent me from thinking that it would be more natural for us to cross the bridge on foot, and let the train come after!”

events.text_segment:
Passepartout stopped short, and eagerly listened to the engineer.
“But the bridge is unsafe,” urged the conductor.
“No matter,” replied Forster; “I think that by putting on the very highest speed we might have a chance of getting over.”
“The devil!” muttered Passepartout.
But a number of the passengers were at once attracted by the engineer’s proposal, and Colonel Proctor was especially delighted, and found the plan a very feasible one. He told stories about engineers leaping their trains over rivers without bridges, by putting on full steam; and many of those present avowed themselves of the engineer’s mind.
“We have fifty chances out of a hundred of getting over,” said one.
“Eighty! ninety!”
Passepartout was astounded, and, though ready to attempt anything to get over Medicine Creek, thought the experiment proposed a little too American. “Besides,” thought he, “there’s a still more simple way, and it does not even occur to any of these people! Sir,” said he aloud to one of the passengers, “the engineer’s plan seems to me a little dangerous, but—”
“Eighty chances!” replied the passenger, turning his back on him.
“I know it,” said Passepartout, turning to another passenger, “but a simple idea—”
“Ideas are no use,” returned the American, shrugging his shoulders, “as the engineer assures us that we can pass.”
“Doubtless,” urged Passepartout, “we can pass, but perhaps it would be more prudent—”
“What! Prudent!” cried Colonel Proctor, whom this word seemed to excite prodigiously. “At full speed, don’t you see, at full speed!”
“I know—I see,” repeated Passepartout; “but it would be, if not more prudent, since that word displeases you, at least more natural—”
“Who! What! What’s the matter with this fellow?” cried several.
The poor fellow did not know to whom to address himself.
“Are you afraid?” asked Colonel Proctor.
“I afraid? Very well; I will show these people that a Frenchman can be as American as they!”
“All aboard!” cried the conductor.
“Yes, all aboard!” repeated Passepartout, and immediately. “But they can’t prevent me from thinking that it would be more natural for us to cross the bridge on foot, and let the train come after!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The engineer was explaining the situation to the passengers gathered around him. "Ladies and gentlemen," he began, "we have encountered an unexpected delay. The tracks ahead have been damaged by a recent storm, and it will take some time to repair them. We are doing everything we can to ensure your journey continues as soon as possible."

Passepartout, always quick to adapt, immediately began to think of alternative solutions. He knew that his master, Phileas Fogg, was on a tight schedule, and any delay could jeopardize their entire journey around the world in eighty days.

He approached the engineer after the crowd had dispersed. "Excuse me, sir," Passepartout said politely, "but is there any other way we might continue our journey? Perhaps by hiring a carriage or some other means of transport?"

The engineer scratched his head, considering the options. "Well," he said slowly, "there might be a possibility. There's a small town not too far from here where you might be able to hire a carriage. It's a bit of a detour, but it could work if you're in a hurry."

Passepartout thanked the engineer and hurried back to inform Mr. Fogg of the situation. "Monsieur Fogg," he said, slightly out of breath, "the tracks are damaged, but the engineer mentioned a town nearby where we might hire a carriage. It could be a way to keep us on schedule."

Phileas Fogg, ever calm and composed, nodded thoughtfully. "Very well, Passepartout," he replied. "Let us make our way to this town and see if we can secure a carriage. We must not let this delay hinder our progress."

With that, the two men gathered their belongings and set off towards the town, determined to find a way to continue their journey. Passepartout, ever resourceful, was confident that they would find a solution, and Phileas Fogg, with his unwavering determination, was ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

As they walked, Passepartout couldn't help but feel a sense of adventure. Despite the obstacles, he was part of an extraordinary journey, and he was determined to see it through to the end.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Passepartout stopped short, and eagerly listened to the engineer. But the latter, instead of listening to him, was explaining to the passengers the idea he had conceived. "Gentlemen," said he, "I am going to attempt a bold experiment, and I hope to succeed."

"What is it?" asked Colonel Proctor.

"We are going to cross the bridge at full speed, and if we succeed, we shall save at least an hour."

"But the bridge is unsafe," objected Passepartout.

"Pshaw!" said the engineer, "I know what I am about. I have already crossed bridges in this way, and I am sure that we shall get over."

"But suppose we don't?" said Passepartout.

"Then we shall be precipitated into the river," replied the engineer. "But we shall not fail."

The passengers were divided in opinion; but the engineer's confidence had its effect. "Besides," added he, "we have no time to lose."

"All aboard!" cried the conductor.

The passengers re-entered the cars. Passepartout took his place without saying a word. The train started, and soon attained its maximum speed. The passengers, fairly frightened, were silent. They passed over the bridge without accident, and the train pursued its course, so that Passepartout, who had remained behind, was able to rejoin his master.

events.title: The Leap Across the Chasm
detailed_summary: Passepartout's more cautious idea remained unspoken and would likely have been ignored anyway.
All passengers re-boarded the train cars.
Passepartout returned to his seat near the whist players without detailing the perilous plan; Fogg, Aouda, and Fix remained oblivious, engrossed in their game.
The locomotive let out a powerful whistle.
The engineer reversed the train for approximately a mile, building up potential energy like an athlete before a jump.
A second whistle signaled the charge forward.
The train rapidly gained speed until it reached a terrifying velocity.
A sustained scream came from the engine as its pistons worked at incredible speed.
Moving at an estimated one hundred miles per hour, the train seemed to barely skim the rails.
The crossing occurred almost instantaneously, like a flash of light.
The bridge itself was not visible during the brief passage.
The train effectively vaulted from one riverbank to the other.
The engineer struggled to brake, finally stopping the train five miles beyond the Medicine Bow station.
Almost immediately after the train cleared the river, the compromised bridge collapsed completely and dramatically into the churning rapids below.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But no one heard this sage reflection, nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But scarcely had the train passed the river, when the bridge, completely ruined, fell with a crash into the rapids of Medicine Bow.

events.text_segment:
But no one heard this sage reflection, nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice. The passengers resumed their places in the cars. Passepartout took his seat without telling what had passed. The whist-players were quite absorbed in their game.
The locomotive whistled vigorously; the engineer, reversing the steam, backed the train for nearly a mile—retiring, like a jumper, in order to take a longer leap. Then, with another whistle, he began to move forward; the train increased its speed, and soon its rapidity became frightful; a prolonged screech issued from the locomotive; the piston worked up and down twenty strokes to the second. They perceived that the whole train, rushing on at the rate of a hundred miles an hour, hardly bore upon the rails at all.
And they passed over! It was like a flash. No one saw the bridge. The train leaped, so to speak, from one bank to the other, and the engineer could not stop it until it had gone five miles beyond the station. But scarcely had the train passed the river, when the bridge, completely ruined, fell with a crash into the rapids of Medicine Bow.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The passengers were too preoccupied with their own concerns, the crew too busy with their duties, and the captain too focused on navigating the ship through the unpredictable waters. The sea stretched endlessly around them, a vast expanse of blue that seemed to swallow all sound and thought. The wind whipped through the sails, a constant reminder of the journey's urgency, and the ship creaked and groaned as it cut through the waves.

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, stood at the bow, his eyes fixed on the horizon. He was a man of few words, his thoughts a mystery to those around him. Yet, his determination was palpable, a force that seemed to propel the ship forward as much as the wind itself. Beside him, Passepartout, his loyal servant, watched with a mixture of admiration and anxiety. He had come to trust in his master's unyielding resolve, even as doubts gnawed at the edges of his own mind.

The journey was far from over, and the challenges ahead loomed large, but for now, the ship sailed on, carrying its passengers ever closer to their destination.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But no one heard this sage reflection, nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice. The passengers resumed their places in the cars. Passepartout took his seat without saying anything of what had passed. The whist players were quite absorbed in their game. The locomotive whistled vigorously; the engineer, reversing the steam, backed the train for nearly a mile—retiring like a jumper in order to take a longer leap. Then, with another whistle, he began to move forward; the train increased its speed, and soon its rapidity became frightful; a prolonged screech issued from the locomotive, which was exerting to the utmost its strength. The train flew over the rails at a speed of a hundred miles an hour, scarcely noticing the rails. The passengers’ hearts had stopped beating. The train leaped, so to speak, from one bank to the other, and the engineer could not stop it until it had gone five miles beyond the station. But scarcely had the train passed the river, when the bridge, completely ruined, fell with a crash into the rapids of Medicine Bow.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXIX. IN WHICH CERTAIN INCIDENTS ARE NARRATED WHICH ARE ONLY TO BE MET WITH ON AMERICAN RAILROADS

events.title: Transcontinental Progress and a Historical Pause
detailed_summary: The train journey proceeded smoothly, reaching the highest point of the route at Evans Pass before beginning its descent towards the Atlantic.
A branch line to Denver, the capital of gold- and silver-rich Colorado, was noted.
After three days and nights from San Francisco, 1382 miles had been covered, with four more days expected to reach New York, keeping Phileas Fogg on schedule.
The train passed Camp Walbach, followed Lodge Pole Creek marking the Wyoming-Colorado border, and entered Nebraska.
It passed near Sedgwick and stopped at Julesburg on the Platte River.
A flashback describes the Union Pacific Railroad's inauguration at Julesburg on October 23, 1867, attended by officials like General Dodge and Thomas C. Durant.
The inauguration involved celebrations including speeches, an imitation Indian battle, fireworks, and the printing of the first 'Railway Pioneer' newspaper on the train.
The railroad is portrayed as a powerful tool for progress, destined to connect future cities across the American landscape.
The journey continued past Fort McPherson towards Omaha, following the Platte River.
The train reached the town of North Platte, situated between two merging arms of the river.
The crossing of the one hundred and first meridian was noted.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train pursued its course, that evening, without interruption, passing Fort Saunders, crossing Cheyne Pass, and reaching Evans Pass.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The one hundred and first meridian was passed.

events.text_segment:
The train pursued its course, that evening, without interruption, passing Fort Saunders, crossing Cheyne Pass, and reaching Evans Pass. The road here attained the highest elevation of the journey, eight thousand and ninety-two feet above the level of the sea. The travellers had now only to descend to the Atlantic by limitless plains, levelled by nature. A branch of the “grand trunk” led off southward to Denver, the capital of Colorado. The country round about is rich in gold and silver, and more than fifty thousand inhabitants are already settled there.
Thirteen hundred and eighty-two miles had been passed over from San Francisco, in three days and three nights; four days and nights more would probably bring them to New York. Phileas Fogg was not as yet behind-hand.
During the night Camp Walbach was passed on the left; Lodge Pole Creek ran parallel with the road, marking the boundary between the territories of Wyoming and Colorado. They entered Nebraska at eleven, passed near Sedgwick, and touched at Julesburg, on the southern branch of the Platte River.
It was here that the Union Pacific Railroad was inaugurated on the 23rd of October, 1867, by the chief engineer, General Dodge. Two powerful locomotives, carrying nine cars of invited guests, amongst whom was Thomas C. Durant, vice-president of the road, stopped at this point; cheers were given, the Sioux and Pawnees performed an imitation Indian battle, fireworks were let off, and the first number of the Railway Pioneer was printed by a press brought on the train. Thus was celebrated the inauguration of this great railroad, a mighty instrument of progress and civilisation, thrown across the desert, and destined to link together cities and towns which do not yet exist. The whistle of the locomotive, more powerful than Amphion’s lyre, was about to bid them rise from American soil.
Fort McPherson was left behind at eight in the morning, and three hundred and fifty-seven miles had yet to be traversed before reaching Omaha. The road followed the capricious windings of the southern branch of the Platte River, on its left bank. At nine the train stopped at the important town of North Platte, built between the two arms of the river, which rejoin each other around it and form a single artery, a large tributary, whose waters empty into the Missouri a little above Omaha.
The one hundred and first meridian was passed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At this point, the travelers were at an elevation of 8,092 feet above sea level, the highest point on the journey. The air was crisp and thin, and the landscape was a vast expanse of rugged terrain, dotted with sparse vegetation and the occasional silhouette of a distant mountain range.

Phileas Fogg, ever the picture of composure, sat in his seat with an air of calm determination. His eyes were fixed on the passing scenery, but his mind was undoubtedly calculating the time and distance remaining on their journey. Beside him, Passepartout, his loyal valet, was more animated, his eyes wide with wonder at the unfamiliar sights.

The train descended from the heights, winding its way through the Rocky Mountains, a feat of engineering that was a testament to human ingenuity. The passengers marveled at the views, the sheer cliffs and deep gorges that seemed to stretch endlessly into the horizon.

As night fell, the train continued its journey, the rhythmic clatter of the wheels on the tracks a soothing lullaby to the weary travelers. The stars above were bright and clear, a celestial map guiding them westward.

In the dining car, the atmosphere was lively, with passengers sharing stories and laughter over meals. Fogg, however, remained focused, his mind on the task at hand. He knew that every minute counted, and any delay could jeopardize their tight schedule.

Passepartout, ever the social butterfly, engaged in conversation with fellow travelers, his French accent adding a touch of exotic charm to his tales of adventure. He spoke of their travels across Europe and Asia, the wonders they had seen, and the challenges they had faced.

The train pressed on through the night, crossing the vast plains of Wyoming, a land of open skies and endless possibilities. The journey was far from over, but with each passing mile, they were one step closer to their goal.

As dawn broke, the train approached the bustling town of Laramie, a hub of activity and commerce. The travelers prepared for the next leg of their journey, their spirits buoyed by the progress they had made. The race against time continued, but with determination and a bit of luck, they were confident they would succeed in their quest to travel around the world in eighty days.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The train pursued its course, that evening, without interruption, passing Fort Saunders, crossing Cheyne Pass, and reaching Evans Pass, the highest point on the road, at an elevation of 7,524 feet. At this point the travellers were fifty-seven miles from the starting-point in Wyoming, and they descended the eastern slope of the Rocky Mountains to the plains of Nebraska. At eight o'clock a.m. the next day, the train stopped at the important town of Cheyenne, which connected with Denver by a branch road, and which is the chief town of the mining region of Colorado. They stopped there for twenty minutes, which was sufficient for Mr. Fogg and his party to purchase a supply of fresh game. The country around was full of wild game, and large herds of buffalo were seen as they passed along. They also saw immense prairies, immense forests, and vast rivers, which were crossed by bridges of great length. The train passed Fort McPherson, and reached North Platte, where it stopped for a few minutes. The town is situated on the river of the same name, and is the point where the two branches of the river unite. The train crossed the one hundred and first meridian, and entered the territory of Nebraska. At noon, the train stopped at Julesburg, on the southern branch of the Platte River. Here was inaugurated, on the 23rd of October, 1867, the Union Pacific Railroad, which unites the Atlantic and Pacific by a continuous line. This was a great event in the history of the United States, and was celebrated by a grand festival, at which General Dodge and Thomas C. Durant, the chief engineers, were present. Speeches were made, and an imitation Indian battle was fought, in which the soldiers of the fort took part. Fireworks were let off, and the first number of the "Railway Pioneer" was printed on the train. Thus was celebrated the inauguration of the great transcontinental line, which was to connect the future cities of the Union with the Pacific Ocean. The train continued its course, following the southern branch of the Platte River, and passed Fort Kearney. The next day, at noon, it reached Omaha, the terminus of the Union Pacific Railroad, and the point of junction with the trains of the Chicago and North Western Railway. Here the travellers were to take the train for Chicago, and thence to New York, which was the end of their journey. Mr. Fogg was now only two days behind time, and he hoped to make up the lost time by the speed of the trains on the eastern roads. The train stopped at Omaha for a few hours, and the travellers had time to visit the town, which is the capital of the state of Nebraska. They found it a thriving place, with a population of about thirty thousand inhabitants, and a great centre of trade. They visited the principal buildings, and saw the great bridge over the Missouri River, which connects Omaha with Council Bluffs, in the state of Iowa. This bridge is one of the finest in the world, and is a marvel of engineering skill. The train left Omaha at six o'clock in the evening, and crossed the Missouri River by the bridge. It then entered the state of Iowa, and passed through the towns of Council Bluffs, Des Moines, and Iowa City. The travellers were now in the heart of the great agricultural region of the United States, and they saw immense fields of corn and wheat, and vast herds of cattle and sheep. The train continued its course, and reached Chicago at eight o'clock in the morning. Here the travellers had to change cars, and take the train for New York. They had now only one day more to reach their destination, and Mr. Fogg was confident that he would arrive in time to win his wager. The train left Chicago at nine o'clock, and passed through the towns of South Bend, Toledo, and Cleveland. It then entered the state of Pennsylvania, and passed through the towns of Erie, Buffalo, and Rochester. The travellers were now in the state of New York, and they saw the great lakes, the Niagara Falls, and the Hudson River. The train continued its course, and reached New York at eight o'clock in the evening. Mr. Fogg had won his wager, and had made the tour of the world in eighty days.

events.title: A Tense Game of Whist Leads to Conflict
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg and his companions were engaged in a whist game, undisturbed by the journey's duration.
Fix, initially winning, found his luck turning but remained as focused a player as Fogg.
Chance favored Fogg during the morning, dealing him strong hands.
As Fogg prepared to make a bold play using a spade, a voice from behind advised playing a diamond instead.
Fogg, Aouda, and Fix looked up to identify the speaker as Colonel Proctor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg and his partners had resumed their game; no one—not even the dummy—complained of the length of the trip.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Fix raised their heads, and beheld Colonel Proctor.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Fogg and his partners had resumed their game; no one—not even the dummy—complained of the length of the trip. Fix had begun by winning several guineas, which he seemed likely to lose; but he showed himself a not less eager whist-player than Mr. Fogg. During the morning, chance distinctly favoured that gentleman. Trumps and honours were showered upon his hands.
Once, having resolved on a bold stroke, he was on the point of playing a spade, when a voice behind him said, “I should play a diamond.”
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Fix raised their heads, and beheld Colonel Proctor.

Mr. Fogg, with his usual composure, played with precision, his mind seemingly untroubled by the challenges of their ambitious itinerary. Passepartout, though initially anxious about the time constraints, found solace in the game, his spirits lifted by the camaraderie shared at the card table. The journey, though long, was marked by moments of quiet contentment and shared purpose.
