This delay was a significant setback in his ambitious journey to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days. Fogg, a man of precision and punctuality, was not one to be easily deterred by such challenges. He immediately began to strategize on how to make up for the lost time.

The delay had occurred due to unforeseen circumstances during their travel through India. Despite the setback, Fogg remained calm and composed, a testament to his unwavering determination and resourcefulness. He knew that every minute counted, and he was prepared to take calculated risks to ensure they stayed on track.

Fogg's loyal companion, Passepartout, was equally concerned about the delay. However, he had complete faith in Fogg's ability to navigate through any obstacles. Together, they reviewed their itinerary, looking for opportunities to accelerate their journey.

Fogg decided to take a more direct route to their next destination, even if it meant incurring additional costs. He was willing to spend whatever it took to achieve his goal. With renewed determination, Fogg and Passepartout set off, determined to make up for lost time and continue their incredible adventure around the world.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time. Passepartout, the involuntary cause of this delay, was desperate. He had ruined his master! At this moment the detective approached Mr. Fogg, and, looking him intently in the face, said:

"Seriously, sir, are you in great haste?"

"Quite seriously."

"I have a purpose in asking," resumed Fix. "Is it absolutely necessary that you should be in New York on the 11th, before nine o'clock in the evening, the time that the steamer leaves for Liverpool?"

"It is absolutely necessary."

"And, if your journey had not been interrupted by these Indians, you would have reached New York on the morning of the 11th?"

"Yes; with eleven hours to spare before the steamer left."

"Good! you are now twenty hours behind. Twelve from twenty leaves eight. You must regain eight hours. Do you wish to try to do so?"

"On foot?" asked Mr. Fogg.

"No; on a sledge," replied Fix. "On a sledge with sails. A man has proposed this method to me."

It was the man who had spoken to Fix during the night, and whose offer he had refused.

events.title: Inspecting and Hiring the Sail-Sledge
detailed_summary: After Fix indicates the man who proposed the sledge, Fogg approaches him.
Fogg and the American, Mudge, enter a nearby hut.
Inside, Fogg inspects the vehicle: a frame on sledge runners designed for multiple passengers, equipped with a tall mast, a large brigantine sail, a jib-sail, and a rudder.
These sledges are noted for rapid winter travel across frozen plains when trains are snowbound, often matching or exceeding express train speeds.
Fogg quickly makes a deal with Mudge.
Conditions are favorable: a fresh westerly wind and hardened snow.
Mudge is confident he can reach Omaha in hours, allowing Fogg to catch eastward trains.
Fogg decides to take this chance to potentially recover the lost time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was not impossible that the lost time might yet be recovered; and such an opportunity was not to be rejected.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him. An instant after, Mr. Fogg and the American, whose name was Mudge, entered a hut built just below the fort.
There Mr. Fogg examined a curious vehicle, a kind of frame on two long beams, a little raised in front like the runners of a sledge, and upon which there was room for five or six persons. A high mast was fixed on the frame, held firmly by metallic lashings, to which was attached a large brigantine sail. This mast held an iron stay upon which to hoist a jib-sail. Behind, a sort of rudder served to guide the vehicle. It was, in short, a sledge rigged like a sloop. During the winter, when the trains are blocked up by the snow, these sledges make extremely rapid journeys across the frozen plains from one station to another. Provided with more sails than a cutter, and with the wind behind them, they slip over the surface of the prairies with a speed equal if not superior to that of the express trains.
Mr. Fogg readily made a bargain with the owner of this land-craft. The wind was favourable, being fresh, and blowing from the west. The snow had hardened, and Mudge was very confident of being able to transport Mr. Fogg in a few hours to Omaha. Thence the trains eastward run frequently to Chicago and New York. It was not impossible that the lost time might yet be recovered; and such an opportunity was not to be rejected.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He was a tall, robust man, with a determined expression on his face. His attire was that of a typical American, with a wide-brimmed hat and a long coat. As Mr. Fogg approached, the man stopped his pacing and turned to face him.

"Are you Mr. Fogg?" the man asked in a gruff voice.

"I am," replied Phileas Fogg, maintaining his usual calm demeanor.

"I hear you're looking for a guide to take you across the plains," the man continued, his eyes narrowing slightly as he assessed the English gentleman before him.

"That is correct," Fogg confirmed. "I require someone who is familiar with the terrain and can ensure a swift and safe passage."

The man nodded, seemingly satisfied with Fogg's straightforwardness. "Name's Samuel Proctor," he introduced himself, extending a hand. "I've been guiding folks across these parts for over a decade. I know every trail and every danger that might come our way."

Fogg shook his hand firmly. "Very well, Mr. Proctor. I trust you will be able to meet my expectations. We must reach our destination without delay."

Proctor gave a slight smile, a hint of confidence in his expression. "You can count on me, Mr. Fogg. We'll make it through, come hell or high water."

With the arrangements made, Fogg returned to his companions, Fix and Passepartout, who had been observing the exchange from a distance. "We have our guide," Fogg announced. "Prepare yourselves; we depart at first light."

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him, and, in a few moments, the two were in the American's hut. They sat down at a table, and the American began to speak: "Your honour," said he, "I am a sledge-driver. I have a sledge with sails, and I can take you to Omaha in no time. You see, the trains are snowed up, and the only way to get across the plains is by sledge. I can get you there in five or six hours, if the wind holds."

Phileas Fogg listened attentively to the American, and, when he had finished, he said: "I will take your sledge."

"Very well, your honour," replied the American. "We will start as soon as you are ready."

Phileas Fogg and the American, whose name was Mudge, then went out to inspect the sledge. It was a curious vehicle, with a frame on sledge runners, and was designed to carry several passengers. It was equipped with a tall mast, a large brigantine sail, a jib-sail, and a rudder. These sledges were noted for their rapid winter travel across the frozen plains, and were often able to match or exceed the speed of express trains.

The conditions were favorable for the journey: a fresh westerly wind was blowing, and the snow was hard and smooth. Mudge was confident that he could reach Omaha in a few hours, which would allow Fogg to catch the eastward trains and make up for lost time.

Phileas Fogg quickly made a deal with Mudge, and they prepared to set off on their journey across the plains.

events.title: Aouda's Loyalty and Fix's Ambiguous Resolve
detailed_summary: Concerned about Aouda's comfort during the exposed sledge journey, Fogg suggests she remain at Fort Kearney with Passepartout, who could escort her to Europe later.
Aouda firmly refuses to be separated from Mr. Fogg.
Passepartout is pleased by her decision, as he doesn't want to leave his master alone with Fix.
The narrative notes the uncertainty of Fix's internal state: whether Fogg's return altered his suspicions or if he still saw Fogg as a cunning criminal nearing the end of his scheme.
Despite any potential shift in opinion, Fix remains committed to his duty and getting the group back to England swiftly.

Not wishing to expose Aouda to the discomforts of travelling in the open air, Mr. Fogg proposed to leave her with Passepartout at Fort Kearney, the servant taking upon himself to escort her to Europe by a better route and under more favourable conditions. But Aouda refused to separate from Mr. Fogg, and Passepartout was delighted with her decision; for nothing could induce him to leave his master while Fix was with him.
It would be difficult to guess the detective’s thoughts. Was this conviction shaken by Phileas Fogg’s return, or did he still regard him as an exceedingly shrewd rascal, who, his journey round the world completed, would think himself absolutely safe in England? Perhaps Fix’s opinion of Phileas Fogg was somewhat modified; but he was nevertheless resolved to do his duty, and to hasten the return of the whole party to England as much as possible.

events.title: The Sledge Journey Begins
detailed_summary: The sledge is prepared for departure at eight o'clock.
The passengers board, bundling themselves in warm travel cloaks.
The two large sails are hoisted.
Propelled by the wind, the sledge glides across the hardened snow at a remarkable forty miles per hour.
The distance to Omaha is about two hundred miles, potentially coverable in five hours if the wind persists.
Barring accidents, arrival in Omaha by one o'clock seems possible.
The narrative remarks on the extraordinary nature of the journey underway.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At eight o’clock the sledge was ready to start.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What a journey!

events.text_segment:
At eight o’clock the sledge was ready to start. The passengers took their places on it, and wrapped themselves up closely in their travelling-cloaks. The two great sails were hoisted, and under the pressure of the wind the sledge slid over the hardened snow with a velocity of forty miles an hour.
The distance between Fort Kearney and Omaha, as the birds fly, is at most two hundred miles. If the wind held good, the distance might be traversed in five hours; if no accident happened the sledge might reach Omaha by one o’clock.
What a journey!

The weather was cold, and the wind was blowing fiercely across the snow-covered landscape. Phileas Fogg, wrapped in his warmest clothes, climbed onto the sledge with Passepartout and Fix. The driver, a sturdy man accustomed to the harsh conditions, took his place at the front, gripping the reins tightly.

The sledge was equipped with sails, allowing it to glide swiftly over the frozen terrain. As they set off, the wind filled the sails, propelling them forward with surprising speed. The journey was both exhilarating and treacherous, as they navigated through the icy wilderness, determined to reach their destination on time.

events.title: High-Speed Sledding Across the Plains
detailed_summary: Bundled together, the travelers find conversation impossible due to the intense cold, which is amplified by their speed.
The sledge moves smoothly, resembling a boat gliding over water.
At times, strong gusts seem to lift the sledge slightly off the ground.
Mudge skillfully steers, maintaining a straight course and correcting any veering tendencies.
All available sails, including a jib and an additional top-mast jib, are deployed to maximize wind power.
The speed is estimated to be at least forty miles per hour.
Mudge expresses confidence in reaching their destination, provided the vehicle doesn't break.
Fogg has incentivized Mudge with a significant reward for timely arrival in Omaha.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg had made it for Mudge’s interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on, by the offer of a handsome reward.

events.text_segment:
The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going. The sledge sped on as lightly as a boat over the waves. When the breeze came skimming the earth the sledge seemed to be lifted off the ground by its sails. Mudge, who was at the rudder, kept in a straight line, and by a turn of his hand checked the lurches which the vehicle had a tendency to make. All the sails were up, and the jib was so arranged as not to screen the brigantine. A top-mast was hoisted, and another jib, held out to the wind, added its force to the other sails. Although the speed could not be exactly estimated, the sledge could not be going at less than forty miles an hour.
“If nothing breaks,” said Mudge, “we shall get there!”
Mr. Fogg had made it for Mudge’s interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on, by the offer of a handsome reward.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The train was speeding through the snow-covered landscape, the icy wind cutting through their layers of clothing. Phileas Fogg, ever composed, sat with his usual calm demeanor, though his eyes were fixed on the horizon, calculating the time they had left to reach their next destination. Passepartout, his loyal servant, shivered beside him, trying to keep warm by rubbing his hands together and stamping his feet.

Aouda, the brave and resilient woman who had joined them on their journey, wrapped her shawl tighter around her shoulders, her face flushed from the cold. Despite the discomfort, there was a sense of determination among them, a shared understanding that they were part of something greater than themselves—a race against time that had captured the imagination of the world.

The train's whistle pierced the air, a reminder of the relentless pace they had to maintain. Each mile brought them closer to their goal, and each moment was precious.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going. The sledge sped on as lightly as a boat over the waves. When the breeze came skimming the earth, the sledge seemed to be lifted off the ground by its sails. Mudge, who was at the rudder, kept in a straight line, and by a turn of his hand checked the lurches which the vehicle had a tendency to make. All the sails were up, and the jib was so arranged as not to screen the top-mast. The sledge was going at a speed of forty miles an hour. If nothing breaks, said Mudge, we shall get there! Mr. Fogg had made it a condition of success, that the sledge should reach Omaha station by a certain time; and he had promised the American a handsome reward if he succeeded. The sledge whirled on, and it was soon evident that Mudge was no novice in his profession. He was a man of the plains, and knew how to steer a sledge with remarkable skill. The wind, which was blowing from the north, was favourable, and the sledge flew over the snow with a speed that was almost incredible. The travellers were wrapped in their furs, and the cold was so intense that they could not speak. But they were not afraid, for they knew that Mudge was a man to be trusted, and that he would bring them safely to their destination.

events.title: Prairie Crossing and Passengers' Reflections
detailed_summary: The sledge traverses a vast, flat prairie, described as resembling a frozen sea or lake.
It takes a direct route, shorter than the winding railway line that follows the Platte River.
Mudge isn't concerned about the river as it is frozen solid, presenting no obstacle.
The main risks are identified as potential damage to the sledge or a drop in the wind.
The wind remains strong, causing the mast's metal lashings to vibrate and create a musical sound.
Fogg remarks on the specific musical notes produced by the vibrating lashings, his only words during the trip.
Aouda remains well-protected from the wind within her furs.
Passepartout, face reddened by the cold, starts feeling optimistic about reaching New York in time.
He feels gratitude towards Fix for arranging the sledge but maintains his reserve due to suspicion.
Passepartout deeply reflects on Fogg's selfless act of rescuing him from the Sioux, acknowledging the risk Fogg took with his life and fortune.
While the passengers are lost in their thoughts, the sledge speeds through the deserted, snow-covered landscape.
They pass ghostly trees and encounter wildlife like birds and howling prairie wolves.
Passepartout prepares his revolver as the wolves approach, but the sledge outpaces them, avoiding danger.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Had an accident then happened to the sledge, the travellers, attacked by these beasts, would have been in the most terrible danger; but it held on its even course, soon gained on the wolves, and ere long left the howling band at a safe distance behind.

events.text_segment:
The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea. It seemed like a vast frozen lake. The railroad which ran through this section ascended from the south-west to the north-west by Great Island, Columbus, an important Nebraska town, Schuyler, and Fremont, to Omaha. It followed throughout the right bank of the Platte River. The sledge, shortening this route, took a chord of the arc described by the railway. Mudge was not afraid of being stopped by the Platte River, because it was frozen. The road, then, was quite clear of obstacles, and Phileas Fogg had but two things to fear—an accident to the sledge, and a change or calm in the wind.
But the breeze, far from lessening its force, blew as if to bend the mast, which, however, the metallic lashings held firmly. These lashings, like the chords of a stringed instrument, resounded as if vibrated by a violin bow. The sledge slid along in the midst of a plaintively intense melody.
“Those chords give the fifth and the octave,” said Mr. Fogg.
These were the only words he uttered during the journey. Aouda, cosily packed in furs and cloaks, was sheltered as much as possible from the attacks of the freezing wind. As for Passepartout, his face was as red as the sun’s disc when it sets in the mist, and he laboriously inhaled the biting air. With his natural buoyancy of spirits, he began to hope again. They would reach New York on the evening, if not on the morning, of the 11th, and there were still some chances that it would be before the steamer sailed for Liverpool.
Passepartout even felt a strong desire to grasp his ally, Fix, by the hand. He remembered that it was the detective who procured the sledge, the only means of reaching Omaha in time; but, checked by some presentiment, he kept his usual reserve. One thing, however, Passepartout would never forget, and that was the sacrifice which Mr. Fogg had made, without hesitation, to rescue him from the Sioux. Mr. Fogg had risked his fortune and his life. No! His servant would never forget that!
While each of the party was absorbed in reflections so different, the sledge flew past over the vast carpet of snow. The creeks it passed over were not perceived. Fields and streams disappeared under the uniform whiteness. The plain was absolutely deserted. Between the Union Pacific road and the branch which unites Kearney with Saint Joseph it formed a great uninhabited island. Neither village, station, nor fort appeared. From time to time they sped by some phantom-like tree, whose white skeleton twisted and rattled in the wind. Sometimes flocks of wild birds rose, or bands of gaunt, famished, ferocious prairie-wolves ran howling after the sledge. Passepartout, revolver in hand, held himself ready to fire on those which came too near. Had an accident then happened to the sledge, the travellers, attacked by these beasts, would have been in the most terrible danger; but it held on its even course, soon gained on the wolves, and ere long left the howling band at a safe distance behind.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It seemed as if the sledge was gliding over a vast, frozen ocean, the snow stretching out endlessly in all directions. The wind whipped across the open expanse, biting at the faces of the travelers and howling in their ears. The sky above was a pale, wintry blue, with the sun hanging low on the horizon, casting long shadows across the snow.

Phileas Fogg, his eyes fixed ahead, sat with his usual calm demeanor, seemingly unaffected by the cold. Beside him, Passepartout was bundled up in layers of clothing, his face barely visible beneath a thick scarf. He clutched the sides of the sledge, his eyes wide with a mixture of excitement and apprehension.

The driver, a rugged man accustomed to the harsh conditions of the prairie, urged the dogs on with sharp commands. The team of huskies, their breath visible in the frigid air, pulled the sledge with tireless energy, their paws barely making a sound on the packed snow.

As they sped across the prairie, the landscape remained unchanged, a vast, white desert with no landmarks to break the monotony. Occasionally, a lone tree or a distant hill would appear on the horizon, only to vanish again as they continued their journey.

Despite the desolation, there was a stark beauty to the scene. The snow sparkled in the sunlight, and the air was crisp and clear. The travelers were alone in this frozen wilderness, with only the sound of the wind and the rhythmic panting of the dogs to accompany them.

As the hours passed, the sun began to dip lower in the sky, painting the snow in shades of pink and gold. The temperature dropped further, and Passepartout shivered despite his layers of clothing. He glanced at Mr. Fogg, who remained as composed as ever, his eyes scanning the horizon for any sign of their destination.

The journey across the prairie was a test of endurance, both for the travelers and the dogs. The sledge seemed to fly over the snow, but the cold was relentless, seeping into their bones and sapping their strength. Yet, there was no turning back. They were committed to their course, driven by the urgency of their mission.

As night fell, the sky turned a deep indigo, and stars began to appear, twinkling like diamonds in the cold, clear air. The moon rose, casting a silvery light over the snow, and the prairie took on an ethereal quality, as if they were traveling through a dream.

Finally, after what seemed like an eternity, a faint glow appeared on the horizon. It was the lights of a distant settlement, a beacon of warmth and civilization in the frozen wilderness. The sight renewed their spirits, and the dogs, sensing the end of their journey, quickened their pace.

With a final burst of speed, the sledge raced towards the lights, the travelers huddled together against the cold. As they approached the settlement, the sounds of life reached their ears, a welcome contrast to the silence of the prairie.

They had crossed the vast, frozen expanse, and now, at last, they were nearing their destination, one step closer to completing their incredible journey around the world in eighty days.

The sledge, carried forward by an irresistible force, was moving at a speed of forty miles an hour. If nothing breaks, said Mudge, we shall get there! Mr. Fogg had made it a point to take the shortest route, and now that the wind was blowing strongly, he was confident of reaching New York in time. The wind was so strong that the metal lashings of the mast vibrated like the strings of a musical instrument, and Mr. Fogg remarked on the musical notes they produced. Aouda, wrapped in her furs, was sheltered from the wind, while Passepartout, with his face reddened by the cold, was beginning to feel hopeful. He was grateful to Fix for having procured the sledge, though he still harbored suspicions about the detective. As the sledge sped across the snow-covered landscape, they passed ghostly trees and encountered wildlife, including birds and howling prairie wolves. Passepartout, ever vigilant, prepared his revolver as the wolves approached, but the sledge, driven by the strong wind, outpaced them, leaving the danger behind.

events.title: Arrival in Omaha
detailed_summary: Around midday, Mudge identifies landmarks indicating they are crossing the Platte River.
He silently calculates they are about twenty miles from Omaha.
Less than an hour later, he releases the rudder and lowers the sails.
The sledge continues for another half-mile due to its momentum before finally stopping.
Mudge points towards snow-covered roofs and announces their arrival.
They have reached the Omaha station, a hub with frequent train connections to the East Coast.
Passepartout and Fix disembark first, stretching, followed by Fogg and Aouda.
Fogg pays Mudge generously, and Passepartout shakes his hand warmly.
The group immediately proceeds towards the Omaha railway station.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About noon Mudge perceived by certain landmarks that he was crossing the Platte River.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg generously rewarded Mudge, whose hand Passepartout warmly grasped, and the party directed their steps to the Omaha railway station.

events.text_segment:
About noon Mudge perceived by certain landmarks that he was crossing the Platte River. He said nothing, but he felt certain that he was now within twenty miles of Omaha. In less than an hour he left the rudder and furled his sails, whilst the sledge, carried forward by the great impetus the wind had given it, went on half a mile further with its sails unspread.
It stopped at last, and Mudge, pointing to a mass of roofs white with snow, said: “We have got there!”
Arrived! Arrived at the station which is in daily communication, by numerous trains, with the Atlantic seaboard!
Passepartout and Fix jumped off, stretched their stiffened limbs, and aided Mr. Fogg and the young woman to descend from the sledge. Phileas Fogg generously rewarded Mudge, whose hand Passepartout warmly grasped, and the party directed their steps to the Omaha railway station.

He signaled to the travelers that they were making good progress. The vast plains stretched out before them, a seemingly endless expanse of grassland, dotted with occasional clusters of trees and the distant silhouette of the Rocky Mountains. The air was crisp and clear, the sky a brilliant blue, unmarred by clouds.

Phileas Fogg, ever composed, sat in the sledge, his eyes scanning the horizon with a calm determination. Beside him, Passepartout was more animated, his eyes wide with wonder at the vastness of the American landscape. The sledge glided smoothly over the snow, the runners hissing softly as they cut through the frozen surface.

As they continued their journey, the sun climbed higher in the sky, casting long shadows across the plains. The travelers were making excellent time, and Mudge was confident they would reach their destination without delay.

He did not speak, but he was certain that they would arrive on time. They had indeed reached the station at Omaha, which is in regular communication with the eastern coast of the United States. Phileas Fogg generously rewarded Mudge, whose hand Passepartout warmly grasped, and the party directed their steps to the Omaha railway station.

events.title: Race Across America by Train and Final Disappointment
detailed_summary: Omaha serves as the terminus for the Pacific Railroad and connects eastward via the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad.
Upon reaching the Omaha station, Fogg and his party find a train ready to depart and board immediately.
They forgo any sightseeing in Omaha, prioritizing speed.
The train travels swiftly through Iowa (Council Bluffs, Des Moines, Iowa City), crosses the Mississippi River at Davenport during the night, and enters Illinois via Rock Island.
They arrive in Chicago, depicted as rebuilt and thriving, on the afternoon of the 10th.
With nine hundred miles remaining to New York, Fogg immediately transfers to the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, and Chicago Railway train.
The train speeds through Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, passing rapidly through towns.
Finally, the Hudson River comes into view.
At 11:15 PM on the evening of the 11th, the train arrives at the New York station, right beside the Cunard line pier.
They learn immediately that the Liverpool steamer, the "China," had departed just 45 minutes earlier.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The “China,” for Liverpool, had started three-quarters of an hour before!

events.text_segment:
The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town. Omaha is connected with Chicago by the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad, which runs directly east, and passes fifty stations.
A train was ready to start when Mr. Fogg and his party reached the station, and they only had time to get into the cars. They had seen nothing of Omaha; but Passepartout confessed to himself that this was not to be regretted, as they were not travelling to see the sights.
The train passed rapidly across the State of Iowa, by Council Bluffs, Des Moines, and Iowa City. During the night it crossed the Mississippi at Davenport, and by Rock Island entered Illinois. The next day, which was the 10th, at four o’clock in the evening, it reached Chicago, already risen from its ruins, and more proudly seated than ever on the borders of its beautiful Lake Michigan.
Nine hundred miles separated Chicago from New York; but trains are not wanting at Chicago. Mr. Fogg passed at once from one to the other, and the locomotive of the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, and Chicago Railway left at full speed, as if it fully comprehended that that gentleman had no time to lose. It traversed Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey like a flash, rushing through towns with antique names, some of which had streets and car-tracks, but as yet no houses. At last the Hudson came into view; and, at a quarter-past eleven in the evening of the 11th, the train stopped in the station on the right bank of the river, before the very pier of the Cunard line.
The “China,” for Liverpool, had started three-quarters of an hour before!

The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town, which is none other than Omaha. Omaha serves as a significant hub in the network of railroads that crisscross the United States, connecting the eastern and western parts of the country. The completion of the Pacific Railroad was a monumental achievement in American history, symbolizing the unification of the nation through the iron rails that spanned the continent.

In "Around the World in Eighty Days," the Pacific Railroad plays a crucial role in Phileas Fogg's ambitious journey. As Fogg and his companions travel across the United States, the railroad provides a vital link in their quest to circumnavigate the globe in just eighty days. The journey across the American landscape is fraught with challenges, including the threat of attacks by Native American tribes and the harsh conditions of the frontier.

Omaha, as the terminus of the Pacific Railroad, represents both a beginning and an end. For travelers heading west, it is the starting point of their journey into the vast, untamed territories of the American West. For those coming from the west, it marks the end of their long trek across the continent, a place where they can finally rest and recuperate before continuing their travels eastward.

The significance of Omaha and the Pacific Railroad in "Around the World in Eighty Days" highlights the transformative power of transportation and the ways in which it reshaped the world during the 19th century. It underscores the theme of progress and the relentless march of technology that characterizes the era, as well as the spirit of adventure and exploration that drives Fogg and his companions on their incredible journey.

Leaving Omaha, they had but a single night to cross the State of Iowa, with its wide extent of prairies, its great towns of Council Bluffs, Des Moines, and Iowa City, its rolling rivers and streams. The train sped on with all possible speed, and the next morning they had crossed the Mississippi, and reached Davenport, whence they passed into the State of Illinois, through Rock Island, and on to Chicago. It was there that the great fire had occurred, and the city was still rebuilding, but it was already a thriving place. They arrived in Chicago on the afternoon of the 10th, and had but nine hundred miles more to travel to reach New York. Phileas Fogg immediately transferred to the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, and Chicago Railway train, which sped through Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, passing rapidly through towns and cities, until the Hudson River came into view. At 11:15 PM on the evening of the 11th, the train arrived at the New York station, right beside the Cunard line pier, only to learn that the Liverpool steamer, the "China," had departed just 45 minutes earlier.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXII. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG ENGAGES IN A DIRECT STRUGGLE WITH BAD FORTUNE

events.title: Missed Steamer and Passepartout's Guilt
detailed_summary: The departure of the steamship "China" dashes Phileas Fogg's most apparent chance of crossing the Atlantic in time.
Consulting his "Bradshaw" guide confirms that alternative steamers from French, Hamburg, or Inman lines are unsuitable due to destinations or schedules, rendering Fogg's efforts potentially futile.
Passepartout feels utterly crushed, blaming himself for the missed connection and other obstacles he feels he placed in his master's path throughout their journey.
He reflects on the significant sums of money spent, partly due to his own errors, and the immense financial ruin Fogg faces if the wager is lost.
Despite Passepartout's self-reproach, Phileas Fogg remains calm, does not blame him, and suggests they postpone decision-making until the following day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Come.”

events.text_segment:
The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope. None of the other steamers were able to serve his projects. The “Pereire,” of the French Transatlantic Company, whose admirable steamers are equal to any in speed and comfort, did not leave until the 14th; the Hamburg boats did not go directly to Liverpool or London, but to Havre; and the additional trip from Havre to Southampton would render Phileas Fogg’s last efforts of no avail. The Inman steamer did not depart till the next day, and could not cross the Atlantic in time to save the wager.
Mr. Fogg learned all this in consulting his “Bradshaw,” which gave him the daily movements of the transatlantic steamers.
Passepartout was crushed; it overwhelmed him to lose the boat by three-quarters of an hour. It was his fault, for, instead of helping his master, he had not ceased putting obstacles in his path! And when he recalled all the incidents of the tour, when he counted up the sums expended in pure loss and on his own account, when he thought that the immense stake, added to the heavy charges of this useless journey, would completely ruin Mr. Fogg, he overwhelmed himself with bitter self-accusations. Mr. Fogg, however, did not reproach him; and, on leaving the Cunard pier, only said: “We will consult about what is best to-morrow. Come.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
None of the other ships at Hong Kong were able to take him to Yokohama; neither did he have the means of chartering a vessel. Despair was beginning to settle in, but Fogg, ever the man of method and precision, refused to succumb to it. He knew that his journey was not yet over, and he was determined to find a way to continue.

Passepartout, his loyal servant, was equally disheartened but remained hopeful that his master would find a solution. Aouda, the young woman they had rescued in India, was also anxious about their predicament but trusted in Fogg's resourcefulness.

As they pondered their next move, Fogg's mind was already at work, calculating the possibilities and considering every option. He knew that time was of the essence, and any delay could mean the loss of the wager he had staked his fortune on.

In the midst of this uncertainty, Fogg's calm demeanor and unwavering resolve provided a sense of reassurance to his companions. He was a man who thrived on challenges, and this was just another obstacle to overcome in his quest to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days.

With determination and ingenuity, Fogg set out to find an alternative route, knowing that his journey was far from over and that every moment counted.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The "China," in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope. None of the other steamers in the "Bradshaw" were available to him. The "Pereire," of the French Transatlantic Company, was announced to sail on the 14th; and it was not due to arrive in Liverpool till the 21st. The "Hamburg" boats did not go directly to Liverpool or London, but to Havre; and the additional trip from Havre to Southampton would render Fogg’s last efforts of no avail. The Inman steamer did not depart till the next day, and could not cross the Atlantic in time to save the wager. Fogg learned all this in consulting his "Bradshaw," which gave him the daily movements of the transatlantic steamers.

Passepartout was crushed; it overwhelmed him to think that he had ruined his master! It was his fault that Fogg had missed the steamer; yes, but for his blunder, the "China" would not have gone without them; and it was his fault also that Fogg had been compelled to make the detour of the United States, and the expense of this detour, which he had not even the money to pay! Passepartout did not dare to look at his master. Phileas Fogg was not the man to be crushed by a misfortune, however heavy; he was calm, as usual, but there was a look of anxiety on his face. He was reflecting on the means of reaching England in time. Passepartout was on the verge of tears. He reproached himself bitterly. It was his fault, he who had been so faithful, so devoted, and who had never once thought of betraying his master! And yet, he had betrayed him, and at the moment when he should have been most faithful! He was thinking of all this when Mr. Fogg said to him, "It is not your fault, Passepartout; it is mine. I was too confident, and I did not foresee the obstacles. But, no matter; we will consider the matter tomorrow. Come, let us go to bed."

events.title: An Anxious Night and Calculated Odds
detailed_summary: The group travels by ferry from Jersey City across the Hudson River and takes a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel on Broadway.
They secure rooms for the night.
Phileas Fogg sleeps soundly, apparently unaffected by the setback.
In contrast, Aouda and the others (including Passepartout and likely Fix) are too agitated and worried to rest properly.
The narrative marks the date as December 12th and calculates the precise time remaining: nine days, thirteen hours, and forty-five minutes until the deadline at 8:45 PM on December 21st.
It explicitly states that catching the "China" would have allowed Fogg to reach Liverpool and London within the required timeframe.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If Phileas Fogg had left in the “China,” one of the fastest steamers on the Atlantic, he would have reached Liverpool, and then London, within the period agreed upon.

events.text_segment:
The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway. Rooms were engaged, and the night passed, briefly to Phileas Fogg, who slept profoundly, but very long to Aouda and the others, whose agitation did not permit them to rest.
The next day was the 12th of December. From seven in the morning of the 12th to a quarter before nine in the evening of the 21st there were nine days, thirteen hours, and forty-five minutes. If Phileas Fogg had left in the “China,” one of the fastest steamers on the Atlantic, he would have reached Liverpool, and then London, within the period agreed upon.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was about seven o'clock in the evening when they arrived, and the bustling streets of New York were alive with the energy of the city. The hotel, a grand establishment, was known for its luxurious accommodations and attentive service. As they entered the lobby, the opulence of the surroundings was immediately apparent, with its richly decorated interiors and the hum of well-dressed guests moving about.

Phileas Fogg, ever punctual and composed, checked in with his usual efficiency, while Passepartout marveled at the grandeur of the place. Aouda, too, was impressed by the elegance and vibrancy of the city.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway. At six o'clock the following morning, it was still dark, and the gas was still burning in the streets. Phileas Fogg, who was never in a hurry, was ready before the time appointed for starting. He had not lost a second in reaching New York, and he would not lose a second in leaving it. The steamer "China," bound for Liverpool, was to leave at nine o'clock. Mr. Fogg, after bidding good-bye to his whist partners, left the hotel, and went to the "China's" wharf, where he was immediately taken on board. He was followed by Aouda and Passepartout, and the steamer soon left the pier. It was a clear day, and the sun was shining brightly. The "China" was a fine steamer, and Phileas Fogg was soon comfortably installed in his cabin. He had not lost a second in reaching New York, and he would not lose a second in leaving it. events.title: Fogg's Solo Search for Passage
detailed_summary: Fogg leaves the hotel by himself.
He instructs Passepartout to stay behind and ensure Aouda is prepared for a potentially sudden departure.
Fogg proceeds to the banks of the Hudson River.
He meticulously scans the numerous vessels moored or anchored, searching for one suitable for immediate departure.
He notes that while many ships are preparing to leave with the morning tide, demonstrating the port's busyness, most are sailing ships.
Fogg recognizes that sailing vessels lack the necessary speed and are therefore useless for his purpose.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant’s notice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But they were mostly sailing vessels, of which, of course, Phileas Fogg could make no use.

events.text_segment: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant’s notice. He proceeded to the banks of the Hudson, and looked about among the vessels moored or anchored in the river, for any that were about to depart. Several had departure signals, and were preparing to put to sea at morning tide; for in this immense and admirable port there is not one day in a hundred that vessels do not set out for every quarter of the globe. But they were mostly sailing vessels, of which, of course, Phileas Fogg could make no use.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He proceeded to the American consulate, where he hoped to find some information regarding the next steamer to Europe. The consul, a courteous gentleman, informed him that the "China," belonging to the Cunard Line, and leaving on the 11th, was the only vessel at present in port. Mr. Fogg then inquired about the time of departure, and was told that the steamer would leave at nine o'clock in the evening. Having obtained this information, Mr. Fogg returned to the hotel, determined to make the necessary arrangements for their departure.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant’s notice. He proceeded to the banks of the Hudson, and began to look about among the vessels moored or anchored in the river, for any that were about to depart. Several had departure signals, and were preparing to put to sea at morning tide; for in this immense and admirable port there is not one day in a hundred that vessels do not set out for every quarter of the globe. But they were mostly sailing vessels, of which Phileas Fogg needed not. He would have been obliged to wait at least a month for a steamer to start on its regular course. The Hudson is a river which empties into the sea, and on which there are many vessels of all kinds, but not one of them was of any use to him.

events.title: Spotting the "Henrietta"
detailed_summary: Just as his hopes seem to dwindle, Fogg observes a trading vessel anchored near the Battery.
The ship possesses a screw propeller and its smoking funnel indicates it is actively preparing to depart soon.
Acting quickly, Fogg hails a small boat.
He gets into the boat and is rowed out to the vessel.
He boards the ship, which is identified as the "Henrietta," noted for its iron hull and wooden upper structure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable’s length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He ascended to the deck, and asked for the captain, who forthwith presented himself.

events.text_segment:
He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable’s length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure.
Phileas Fogg hailed a boat, got into it, and soon found himself on board the “Henrietta,” iron-hulled, wood-built above. He ascended to the deck, and asked for the captain, who forthwith presented himself.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: This sight rekindled his determination, and he quickly made his way towards the ship. He approached the captain, inquiring about the destination and the possibility of securing passage for himself and his companions.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable’s length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure. Phileas Fogg hailed a boat, got into it, and soon found himself on board the Henrietta. He ascended to the deck, and asked for the captain, who forthwith presented himself. He was a man of fifty, a sort of sea-wolf, with big eyes, a complexion of oxidised copper, red hair and thick neck, and a growling voice. "The captain?" asked Mr. Fogg. "I am the captain." "I am Phileas Fogg, of London." "And I am Andrew Speedy, of Cardiff." "You are going to put to sea?" "In an hour." "You are bound for—" "Bordeaux." "And your cargo?" "No freight. Going in ballast." "Have you any passengers?" "No passengers. Never have passengers. Too much in the way." "Is your vessel a swift one?" "Between eleven and twelve knots. The Henrietta, well known." "Will you carry me and three other persons to Liverpool?" "To Liverpool? Why not to China?" "I said Liverpool." "No!" "No?" "No. I am setting out for Bordeaux, and shall go to Bordeaux." "Money is no object?" "None." The captain spoke in a tone which did not admit of a reply. "But the owners of the Henrietta—" resumed Phileas Fogg. "The owners are myself," replied the captain. "The vessel belongs to me." "I will freight it for you." "No." "I will buy it of you." "No." Phileas Fogg did not betray the least disappointment; but the situation was a grave one. It was not at New York as at Hong Kong, nor with the captain of the Henrietta as with the captain of the Tankadere. Up to this time money had smoothed away every obstacle. Now money failed. Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon—which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice. It seemed that Phileas Fogg had an idea, for he said to the captain, "Well, will you carry me to Bordeaux?" "No, not if you paid me two hundred dollars." "I offer you two thousand." "Apiece?" "Apiece." "And there are four of you?" "Four." Captain Speedy began to scratch his head. There were eight thousand dollars to gain, without changing his route; for which it was well worth conquering the repugnance he had for all kinds of passengers. Besides, passengers at two thousand dollars are no longer passengers, but valuable merchandise. "I start at nine o’clock," said Captain Speedy, simply. "Are you and your party ready?" "We will be on board at nine o’clock," replied, no less simply, Mr. Fogg. It was half-past eight. To disembark from the Henrietta, jump into a hack, hurry to the St. Nicholas, and return with Aouda, Passepartout, and even the inseparable Fix, was the work of a brief time, and was performed by Mr. Fogg with the coolness which never abandoned him. They were on board when the Henrietta made ready to weigh anchor.

events.title: Confronting Captain Speedy
detailed_summary: Fogg encounters the ship's captain, Andrew Speedy, described as a fifty-year-old, rugged "sea-wolf" type from Cardiff.
Speedy confirms he is the captain and the ship, the "Henrietta," is departing within the hour.
He states his destination is Bordeaux and clarifies he is sailing without freight ("in ballast").
Speedy explicitly states he never takes passengers, finding them inconvenient.
He confirms the vessel's speed capability is between eleven and twelve knots.
Fogg directly requests passage for himself and three others to Liverpool.
Captain Speedy bluntly refuses, reiterating his unchangeable destination is Bordeaux.
Speedy dismisses Fogg's inquiry about cost, indicating money is not a deciding factor.
The captain asserts his sole ownership of the vessel when Fogg attempts to appeal to potential owners.
He rejects Fogg's offers to freight or even buy the ship.
Fogg remains outwardly calm, but recognizes the gravity of the situation, as his usual reliance on money to overcome obstacles has failed.

He devises a new strategy and asks Captain Speedy if he would take the party to his intended destination, Bordeaux.
Speedy initially scoffs, saying he wouldn't even for two hundred dollars.
Fogg then makes a substantial offer of two thousand dollars per passenger.
Upon realizing this amounts to eight thousand dollars for the four passengers, Captain Speedy hesitates, scratching his head.
The significant financial incentive overrides his aversion to passengers, whom he now mentally categorizes as valuable cargo rather than nuisances.
Speedy curtly agrees to take them to Bordeaux, confirming the departure time is nine o'clock.
Fogg simply states that he and his party will be on board by then.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Phileas Fogg, ever the resourceful gentleman, pondered over the possibilities. The steamers were the most reliable option, but their schedules were fixed, and any delay could jeopardize his entire journey. He considered chartering a private vessel, but the cost and availability were uncertain. The idea of a balloon, while romantic and adventurous, was dismissed due to its impracticality and the unpredictable nature of the winds.

Fogg's mind raced through the options, weighing the risks and benefits of each. He knew that time was of the essence, and any misstep could mean failure. His determination, however, was unwavering. He resolved to explore every avenue, consult with every possible contact, and leave no stone unturned in his quest to complete his journey around the world in eighty days.

Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon—which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice. It seemed that Phileas Fogg had an idea, for he said to Captain Speedy, "Will you carry me to Bordeaux?"

"No, if you paid me two hundred dollars."

"I offer you two thousand."

"Apiece?"

"Apiece."

Captain Speedy began to scratch his head. He was an American, and the prospect of making a fortune was not displeasing to him. He fixed his eyes upon Mr. Fogg, struggled within himself, but finally said, "Why not, after all? I’ll take you. You’ve got a charter-party?"

"Yes," replied Mr. Fogg.

"Then we’ll go on board at nine o’clock."

"At nine o’clock," said Mr. Fogg, simply.

events.title: Swift Return and Departure on the "Henrietta"
detailed_summary: It is now half-past eight, leaving only thirty minutes before the scheduled departure.
Fogg executes his plan with remarkable speed and characteristic coolness.
He disembarks the "Henrietta," hails a carriage, speeds back to the St. Nicholas Hotel.
He efficiently gathers Aouda, Passepartout, and the ever-present Fix.
Fogg successfully returns with the entire party to the "Henrietta" just as the ship is preparing to weigh anchor.

To disembark from the “Henrietta,” jump into a hack, hurry to the St. Nicholas, and return with Aouda, Passepartout, and even the inseparable Fix was the work of a brief time, and was performed by Mr. Fogg with the coolness which never abandoned him. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The door of the little saloon opened, and Mr. Fogg appeared. Aouda was waiting for him, and rose to meet him. He took her hand, and led her to the sofa, saying, "I wish to speak with you, madam."

"You have been very kind to me, Mr. Fogg," she said, "and I owe you everything. Would you have me leave you now?"

"Aouda," replied Phileas Fogg, "it is I who owe everything to you. You have brought happiness into my life, and I cannot imagine it without you."

Aouda looked at him with eyes full of emotion. "Mr. Fogg," she murmured, "I... I do not wish to leave you either."

Phileas Fogg's usually impassive face softened. "Then, Aouda, will you be my wife?"

Aouda's response was a smile that spoke more than words ever could.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was half-past eight. Phileas Fogg, with his usual composure, executed his plan with remarkable speed. He disembarked from the "Henrietta," hailed a carriage, and sped back to the St. Nicholas Hotel. There, he efficiently gathered Aouda, Passepartout, and the ever-present Fix. With the entire party in tow, Fogg returned to the "Henrietta" just as the ship was preparing to weigh anchor. Upon learning the cost of this unexpected voyage segment, Passepartout let out a long, expressive sound of shock. Meanwhile, Fix mused internally that the Bank of England was unlikely to fare well financially in this affair, estimating that Fogg's expenditures would have already surpassed seven thousand pounds by the time they reached England.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXIII. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG SHOWS HIMSELF EQUAL TO THE OCCASION

events.title: Fogg Takes Command of the Henrietta
detailed_summary: The Henrietta departs New York City, heading east.
Phileas Fogg is revealed to be commanding the ship from the bridge, not Captain Speedy.
Captain Speedy is confined to his cabin, vocally expressing his fury.
Fogg, initially denied passage to Liverpool by Speedy, had booked for Bordeaux.
During the first thirty hours, Fogg used his money to persuade the temporary crew, who disliked Speedy, to mutiny and follow his orders.
Fogg now directs the ship towards Liverpool, demonstrating considerable seamanship.
Aouda feels apprehensive but remains silent.
Passepartout considers Fogg's takeover a brilliant move.
The ship maintains a speed of eleven to twelve knots as predicted by the former captain.
Potential obstacles like rough seas, adverse winds, or mechanical failures still pose risks to completing the voyage in the required nine days (by December 21st).
The narrator notes that Fogg's actions regarding the ship, combined with the bank robbery suspicion, could lead to future complications.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It is true that, once arrived, the affair on board the “Henrietta,” added to that of the Bank of England, might create more difficulties for Mr. Fogg than he imagined or could desire.

events.text_segment:
An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea. During the day she skirted Long Island, passed Fire Island, and directed her course rapidly eastward.
At noon the next day, a man mounted the bridge to ascertain the vessel’s position. It might be thought that this was Captain Speedy. Not the least in the world. It was Phileas Fogg, Esquire. As for Captain Speedy, he was shut up in his cabin under lock and key, and was uttering loud cries, which signified an anger at once pardonable and excessive.
What had happened was very simple. Phileas Fogg wished to go to Liverpool, but the captain would not carry him there. Then Phileas Fogg had taken passage for Bordeaux, and, during the thirty hours he had been on board, had so shrewdly managed with his banknotes that the sailors and stokers, who were only an occasional crew, and were not on the best terms with the captain, went over to him in a body. This was why Phileas Fogg was in command instead of Captain Speedy; why the captain was a prisoner in his cabin; and why, in short, the “Henrietta” was directing her course towards Liverpool. It was very clear, to see Mr. Fogg manage the craft, that he had been a sailor.
How the adventure ended will be seen anon. Aouda was anxious, though she said nothing. As for Passepartout, he thought Mr. Fogg’s manœuvre simply glorious. The captain had said “between eleven and twelve knots,” and the “Henrietta” confirmed his prediction.
If, then—for there were “ifs” still—the sea did not become too boisterous, if the wind did not veer round to the east, if no accident happened to the boat or its machinery, the “Henrietta” might cross the three thousand miles from New York to Liverpool in the nine days, between the 12th and the 21st of December. It is true that, once arrived, the affair on board the “Henrietta,” added to that of the Bank of England, might create more difficulties for Mr. Fogg than he imagined or could desire.

events.title: Smooth Sailing and Character Reactions
detailed_summary: The initial part of the voyage proceeds without major issues.
The sea conditions are favorable, the wind holds steady from the north-east, and the ship makes good progress under sail and steam.
Passepartout is overjoyed by his master's bold actions, oblivious to potential negative outcomes.
He becomes very popular with the crew, impressing them with his agility and positive attitude, praising their seamanship and the stokers' efforts.
His cheerful demeanor spreads throughout the ship.
He puts past troubles behind him, focusing solely on the imminent successful conclusion of the journey, occasionally becoming very impatient.
He frequently observes Fix with suspicion but avoids interaction due to their broken relationship.
Fix is utterly bewildered by Fogg's actions – commandeering a ship, bribing a crew, and expertly sailing it.
He speculates that Fogg, having stolen money, might now be acting as a pirate, planning to sail the Henrietta to a safe haven rather than Liverpool.
The detective regrets becoming involved in the pursuit.
Captain Speedy remains locked away, loudly protesting.
Passepartout delivers Speedy's meals cautiously.
Fogg appears completely indifferent to the presence of the imprisoned captain.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: During the first days, they went along smoothly enough.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg did not seem even to know that there was a captain on board.

events.text_segment:
During the first days, they went along smoothly enough. The sea was not very unpropitious, the wind seemed stationary in the north-east, the sails were hoisted, and the “Henrietta” ploughed across the waves like a real transatlantic steamer.
Passepartout was delighted. His master’s last exploit, the consequences of which he ignored, enchanted him. Never had the crew seen so jolly and dexterous a fellow. He formed warm friendships with the sailors, and amazed them with his acrobatic feats. He thought they managed the vessel like gentlemen, and that the stokers fired up like heroes. His loquacious good-humour infected everyone. He had forgotten the past, its vexations and delays. He only thought of the end, so nearly accomplished; and sometimes he boiled over with impatience, as if heated by the furnaces of the “Henrietta.” Often, also, the worthy fellow revolved around Fix, looking at him with a keen, distrustful eye; but he did not speak to him, for their old intimacy no longer existed.
Fix, it must be confessed, understood nothing of what was going on. The conquest of the “Henrietta,” the bribery of the crew, Fogg managing the boat like a skilled seaman, amazed and confused him. He did not know what to think. For, after all, a man who began by stealing fifty-five thousand pounds might end by stealing a vessel; and Fix was not unnaturally inclined to conclude that the “Henrietta” under Fogg’s command, was not going to Liverpool at all, but to some part of the world where the robber, turned into a pirate, would quietly put himself in safety. The conjecture was at least a plausible one, and the detective began to seriously regret that he had embarked on the affair.
As for Captain Speedy, he continued to howl and growl in his cabin; and Passepartout, whose duty it was to carry him his meals, courageous as he was, took the greatest precautions. Mr. Fogg did not seem even to know that there was a captain on board.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The sea was not very unpropitious, the wind seemed stationary in the north-east, the sails were hoisted, and the Tankadere ploughed across the water. Passepartout was delighted with the voyage; he had never been on a vessel before, and the seaman's life was new to him. He was charmed with the fresh air and the freedom on the deck, and he was constantly on the lookout for the land to appear.

Fix, on the other hand, was not as enthusiastic. He was still preoccupied with his mission to arrest Fogg, and the thought of the detective's duty weighed heavily on him. He spent much of his time in contemplation, pondering the best course of action once they reached Hong Kong.

As for Phileas Fogg, he remained as calm and collected as ever. He spent his time reading, playing whist with Aouda, and occasionally taking a turn around the deck. His demeanor was as unflappable as it had been since the beginning of the journey, and he showed no signs of concern about the progress of their voyage.

Aouda, meanwhile, was grateful for the opportunity to travel in safety and comfort. She enjoyed the company of Fogg and Passepartout, and she found the sea voyage to be a pleasant change from the overland journey they had undertaken through India.

The days passed in this manner, with the Tankadere making steady progress towards Hong Kong. The weather remained favorable, and the crew worked diligently to ensure the ship stayed on course. Passepartout, eager to learn, often assisted the sailors with their tasks, much to their amusement.

As they neared their destination, the passengers began to prepare for their arrival in Hong Kong. Passepartout was particularly excited, as he had never been to the city before and was eager to explore its sights and sounds. Fix, however, remained focused on his objective, determined to apprehend Fogg as soon as they set foot on land.

events.title: Storm Hits the Atlantic Crossing
detailed_summary: The ship reaches the hazardous Banks of Newfoundland.
Weather conditions deteriorate, foreshadowed by a falling barometer the previous evening.
The temperature drops, and the wind shifts to the south-east.
This shift is problematic, forcing Fogg to furl the sails to stay on course and rely solely on steam.
The ship's speed diminishes due to rough seas with large waves breaking over the stern.
The vessel pitches violently, hindering its progress.
The wind intensifies into a storm, raising concerns about the ship's stability.
Passepartout's mood darkens, and he endures two days of intense fear.
Phileas Fogg, however, proves himself a courageous and skilled mariner, maintaining course and steam power.
The Henrietta often cuts through waves rather than riding over them, frequently washing the deck but remaining intact.
Sometimes the propeller lifts out of the water when the stern is raised by large waves, but the ship maintains its heading.
The storm doesn't reach hurricane intensity but persists.
Crucially, the wind remains fixed in the south-east, making the sails unusable for assisting their eastward journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It continued fresh, but, unhappily, it remained obstinately in the south-east, rendering the sails useless.

events.text_segment:
On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind. Ever since the evening before the barometer, suddenly falling, had indicated an approaching change in the atmosphere; and during the night the temperature varied, the cold became sharper, and the wind veered to the south-east.
This was a misfortune. Mr. Fogg, in order not to deviate from his course, furled his sails and increased the force of the steam; but the vessel’s speed slackened, owing to the state of the sea, the long waves of which broke against the stern. She pitched violently, and this retarded her progress. The breeze little by little swelled into a tempest, and it was to be feared that the “Henrietta” might not be able to maintain herself upright on the waves.
Passepartout’s visage darkened with the skies, and for two days the poor fellow experienced constant fright. But Phileas Fogg was a bold mariner, and knew how to maintain headway against the sea; and he kept on his course, without even decreasing his steam. The “Henrietta,” when she could not rise upon the waves, crossed them, swamping her deck, but passing safely. Sometimes the screw rose out of the water, beating its protruding end, when a mountain of water raised the stern above the waves; but the craft always kept straight ahead.
The wind, however, did not grow as boisterous as might have been feared; it was not one of those tempests which burst, and rush on with a speed of ninety miles an hour. It continued fresh, but, unhappily, it remained obstinately in the south-east, rendering the sails useless.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The weather, however, was quite favorable, the sea was calm, and the wind steady. The "China," under full steam, rolled but little, and the passengers almost forgot that they were on the Atlantic. But Phileas Fogg did not forget it, and he passed his time in conversing with his companions, and in playing whist. He was a man who could not be disturbed by the roughest weather, and he was always ready to take advantage of the calm to enjoy his favorite game.

Passepartout, on the other hand, was not so indifferent to the sea's moods. He was often on deck, watching the waves and the horizon, and he was always ready to lend a hand to the sailors when needed. He had become quite popular with the crew, who appreciated his willingness to help and his cheerful disposition.

As they approached the American coast, the weather began to change. The sky became overcast, and the wind picked up, causing the "China" to pitch and roll more noticeably. Passepartout found himself spending more time below deck, where he could avoid the worst of the motion.

Despite the worsening weather, Phileas Fogg remained unperturbed. He continued to play whist with his usual calm demeanor, seemingly oblivious to the ship's movements. His companions marveled at his composure, and even the captain, who was used to the sea's caprices, was impressed by Fogg's stoicism.

On the morning of the 14th, the fog lifted, revealing the distant outline of the American coast. The passengers gathered on deck to catch their first glimpse of the New World, and there was a palpable sense of excitement as the "China" steamed steadily towards its destination.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind. There were signs of a storm ahead, and the barometer announced a speedy change, the mercury rising and falling capriciously. The wind, too, had shifted to the south-east, which was a bad direction for the Henrietta. She had to beat against it; and, unfortunately, the steam was not as powerful as the sails. The vessel pitched violently, and this retarded her progress. The storm burst upon her at last. It was a tempest, the wind blew a gale, and the waves rose mountains high. Passepartout was seized with a mortal terror, and clasped his hands, and prayed to Heaven. He was in the habit of praying, sometimes, in the most desperate cases. But Phileas Fogg, with a perfect coolness and composure, kept the Henrietta to the wind, allowing her to drift a little with the force of the waves. A few sails were hoisted, and under the pressure of the wind, the steamer made rapid progress along the coast. The storm, however, did not last long, and the Henrietta resumed her course, so that on the 18th she was within three hundred miles of Liverpool. Passepartout was relieved, but he was still anxious, for the least delay might ruin all.

events.title: Coal Shortage Crisis Emerges
detailed_summary: By December 16th, day 75, the voyage is roughly half complete without major delays, despite passing difficult areas.
Success seems likely in summer, but the winter season makes the outcome uncertain.
Passepartout remains hopeful, relying on the steam engines if the wind fails.
The ship's engineer approaches Fogg for a serious discussion.
Passepartout feels a sense of foreboding and strains to overhear their conversation.
He catches Fogg asking the engineer for confirmation of his statement.
The engineer confirms that while they had enough coal for a low-steam trip to Bordeaux, the constant high-steam usage means they lack sufficient coal to reach Liverpool.
Fogg calmly states he will consider the situation.
Passepartout grasps the critical nature of the problem: they are running out of coal.
He mutters that if Fogg can overcome this, he'll truly be remarkable.
He feels compelled to share the news with Fix.
Fix sarcastically asks if Passepartout still believes they are heading to Liverpool.
Passepartout affirms this, to which Fix replies dismissively, calling him an 'Ass'.
Passepartout is initially angered but stops himself, reasoning that Fix is likely bitter and embarrassed by his fruitless pursuit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg’s departure from London, and the “Henrietta” had not yet been seriously delayed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout was on the point of vigorously resenting the epithet, the reason of which he could not for the life of him comprehend; but he reflected that the unfortunate Fix was probably very much disappointed and humiliated in his self-esteem, after having so awkwardly followed a false scent around the world, and refrained.

events.text_segment:
The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg’s departure from London, and the “Henrietta” had not yet been seriously delayed. Half of the voyage was almost accomplished, and the worst localities had been passed. In summer, success would have been well-nigh certain. In winter, they were at the mercy of the bad season. Passepartout said nothing; but he cherished hope in secret, and comforted himself with the reflection that, if the wind failed them, they might still count on the steam.
On this day the engineer came on deck, went up to Mr. Fogg, and began to speak earnestly with him. Without knowing why it was a presentiment, perhaps Passepartout became vaguely uneasy. He would have given one of his ears to hear with the other what the engineer was saying. He finally managed to catch a few words, and was sure he heard his master say, “You are certain of what you tell me?”
“Certain, sir,” replied the engineer. “You must remember that, since we started, we have kept up hot fires in all our furnaces, and, though we had coal enough to go on short steam from New York to Bordeaux, we haven’t enough to go with all steam from New York to Liverpool.” “I will consider,” replied Mr. Fogg.
Passepartout understood it all; he was seized with mortal anxiety. The coal was giving out! “Ah, if my master can get over that,” muttered he, “he’ll be a famous man!” He could not help imparting to Fix what he had overheard.
“Then you believe that we really are going to Liverpool?”
“Of course.”
“Ass!” replied the detective, shrugging his shoulders and turning on his heel.
Passepartout was on the point of vigorously resenting the epithet, the reason of which he could not for the life of him comprehend; but he reflected that the unfortunate Fix was probably very much disappointed and humiliated in his self-esteem, after having so awkwardly followed a false scent around the world, and refrained.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The weather was fine, and the wind was favorable. The steamer ploughed the waves like a true transatlantic vessel, and passed without accident the long range of the Azores Islands. But the crew of the "Henrietta" was far from sharing the confidence of Phileas Fogg. They were anxious and restless, seeing that the ship was not being steered on the course for New York, but for Liverpool. 

The captain had at first absolutely refused to go to Liverpool, but Fogg had an irresistible argument, and, after a long discussion, the captain consented to change his course. The crew, however, were not satisfied, and they muttered their discontent. Fix was not without fear that they might refuse to obey the captain, and so the "Henrietta" might be compelled to stop at some port. 

But the captain had a strong hold on his men, and they obeyed him, though they murmured. The "Henrietta" was now on the direct route to Liverpool. Phileas Fogg was determined to reach London by the 21st of December, to win his wager. He had already spent a large part of his fortune in the attempt, and he was not going to be stopped by a mutinous crew. 

Passepartout, who had been very uneasy, was reassured by the calm demeanor of his master. Fix, on the other hand, was more anxious than ever. He had a presentiment that Fogg would succeed, and he was determined to prevent it. He had already telegraphed to the police in Liverpool to arrest Fogg on his arrival, and he was now waiting impatiently for the moment when he could put his plan into execution. 

The "Henrietta" continued her course without accident, and on the 20th of December, at eleven o'clock in the morning, she sighted the coast of Ireland. At one o'clock in the afternoon, she entered Queenstown harbor, and Phileas Fogg set foot on European soil.

Passepartout said nothing; but he cherished hope in secret, and comforted himself with the reflection that, if the wind failed them, they might still count on the steam.

On this day, the engineer came on deck, went up to Mr. Fogg, and began to speak earnestly with him. Without knowing why it was—a presentiment, doubtless—Passepartout became vaguely uneasy. He would have given one of his ears to hear with the other what the engineer was saying. He finally managed to catch a few words, and was sure he heard his master say, "You are certain of what you tell me?"

"Certain, sir," replied the engineer. "You must remember that, since we started, we have kept up hot fires in all our furnaces, and, though we had coal enough to go on short steam from New York to Bordeaux, we haven’t enough to go with all steam from New York to Liverpool."

"I will consider," replied Mr. Fogg.

Passepartout understood it all; he was seized with mortal anxiety. The coal was giving out! "Ah, if my master can get over that," muttered he, "he’ll be a famous man!" He could not help imparting to Fix what he had overheard.
